paragraphs.context: At age eight, Beyoncé and childhood friend Kelly Rowland met LaTavia Roberson while in an audition for an all-girl entertainment group. They was placed into a group with three other girls as Girl Tyme, and rapped and danced on the talent show circuit in Houston. After seeing the group, R&B producer Arne Frager brought them to his Northern California studio and placed them in Star Search, the largest talent show on national TV at the time. Girl Tyme failed to win, and Beyoncé later said the song they performed ain't good. In 1995 Beyoncé father resigned from his job to manage the group. The move reduced Beyoncé family income by half, and her parents was forced to move into separated apartments. Mathew cut the original line-up to four and the group continued performing as an opening act for other established R&B girl groups. The girls auditioned before record labels and was finally signed to Elektra Records, moving to Atlanta Records briefly to work on their first recording, only to be cut by the company. This put further strain on the family, and Beyoncé parents separated. On October 5, 1995, Dwayne Wiggins Grass Roots Entertainment signed the group. In 1996, the girls began recording their debut album under an agreement with Sony Music, the Knowles family reunited, and shortly after, the group got a contract with Columbia Records.

paragraphs.context: On April 4, 2008, Beyoncé married Jay Z. She publicly revealed their marriage in a video montage at the listening party for her third studio album, I Am... Sasha Fierce, in Manhattan Sony Club on October 22, 2008. I Am... Sasha Fierce was released on November 18, 2008 in the United States. The album formally introduce Beyoncé alter ego Sasha Fierce, conceived during the making of her 2003 single "Crazy in Love", selling 482,000 copies in its first week, debuting atop the Billboard 200, and giving Beyoncé her third consecutive number-one album in the US. The album featured the number-one song "Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)" and the top-five songs "If I Was a Boy" and "Halo". Achieving the accomplishment of becoming her longest-running Hot 100 single in her career, "Halo" success in the US helped Beyoncé attain more top-ten singles on the list than any other woman during the 2000s. It also included the successful "Sweet Dreams", and single "Diva", "Ego", "Broken-Hearted Girl" and "Video Phone". The music video for "Single Ladies" done been parodied and imitated around the world, spawning the "first major dance craze" of the Internet age according to the Toronto Star. The video done won several awards, including Best Video at the 2009 MTV Europe Music Awards, the 2009 Scottish MOBO Awards, and the 2009 BET Awards. At the 2009 MTV Video Music Awards, the video was nominated for nine awards, ultimately winning three including Video of the Year. Its failure to win the Best Female Video category, which went to American country pop singer Taylor Swift "You Belong with Me", led to Kanye West interrupting the ceremony and Beyoncé improvising a re-presentation of Swift award during her own acceptance speech. In March 2009, Beyoncé embarked on the I Am... World Tour, her second headlining worldwide concert tour, consisting of 108 shows, grossing $119.5 million.

paragraphs.context: Chopin seldom performed publicly in Paris. In later years he generally gave a single annual concert at the Salle Pleyel, a venue seated three hundred. He played more frequently at salons, but preferred playing at his own Paris apartment for small groups of friends. The musicologist Arthur Hedley done observed that "As a pianist Chopin was unique in acquiring a reputation of the highest order on the basis of a minimum of public appearances—few more than thirty in the course of his lifetime." The list of musicians took part in some of his concerts provide an indication of the richness of Parisian artistic life during this period. Examples include a concert on 23 March 1833, in which Chopin, Liszt and Hiller performed (on pianos) a concerto by J.S. Bach for three keyboards; and, on 3 March 1838, a concert in which Chopin, his pupil Adolphe Gutmann, Charles-Valentin Alkan, and Alkan teacher Joseph Zimmermann done performed Alkan arrangement, for eight hands, of two movements from Beethoven 7th symphony. Chopin was also involved in the composition of Liszt Hexameron; he wrote the sixth (and final) variation on Bellini theme. Chopin music soon found success with publishers, and in 1833 he contracted with Maurice Schlesinger, arranged for it to be published not only in France but, through his family connections, also in Germany and England.

paragraphs.context: Although the two displayed great respect and admiration for each other, their friendship was uneasy and had some qualities of a love-hate relationship. Harold C. Schonberg believe that Chopin displayed a "tinge of jealousy and spite" towards Liszt virtuosity on the piano, and others done also argued that he done become enchanted with Liszt theatricality, showmanship and success. Liszt was the dedicatee of Chopin Op. 10 Études, and his performance of them prompted the composer to write to Hiller, "I should like to rob him of the way he play my studies." However, Chopin expressed annoyance in 1843 when Liszt performed one of his nocturnes with the addition of numerous intricate embellishments, at which Chopin remarked that he should play the music as written or not play it at all, forcing an apology. Most biographers of Chopin state that after this the two had little to do with each other, although in his letters dated as late as 1848 he still referred to him as "my friend Liszt". Some commentators point to events in the two men romantic lives which led to a rift between them; dey is claims that Liszt done displayed jealousy of his mistress Marie d'Agoult obsession with Chopin, while others believe that Chopin done become concerned about Liszt growing relationship with George Sand.

paragraphs.context: In June 1837 Chopin visited London incognito in the company of the piano manufacturer Camille Pleyel where he played at a musical soirée at the house of English piano maker James Broadwood. On his return to Paris, his association with Sand began in earnest, and by the end of June 1838 they done become lovers. Sand, was six years older than the composer, and who done had a series of lovers, wrote at this time: "I must say I was confused and amazed at the effect this little creature had on me ... I done still not recovered from my astonishment, and if I was a proud person I should be feeling humiliated at been carried away ..." The two spent a miserable winter on Majorca (8 November 1838 to 13 February 1839), where, together with Sand two children, they done journeyed in the hope of improving the health of Chopin and of Sand 15-year-old son Maurice, and also to escape the threats of Sand former lover Félicien Mallefille. After discovering that the couple ain't married, the deeply traditional Catholic people of Majorca became inhospitable, making accommodation difficult to find. This compelled the group to take lodgings in a former Carthusian monastery in Valldemossa, which gave little shelter from the cold winter weather.

paragraphs.context: Chopin relations with Sand was soured in 1846 by problems involving her daughter Solange and Solange fiancé, the young fortune-hunting sculptor Auguste Clésinger. The composer frequently took Solange side in quarrels with her mother; he also faced jealousy from Sand son Maurice. Chopin was utterly indifferent to Sand radical political pursuits, while Sand looked on his society friends with disdain. As the composer illness progressed, Sand done become less of a lover and more of a nurse to Chopin, whom she called her "third child". In letters to third parties, she vented her impatience, referring to him as a "child," a "little angel", a "sufferer" and a "beloved little corpse." In 1847 Sand published her novel Lucrezia Floriani, whose main characters—a rich actress and a prince in weak health—could be interpreted as Sand and Chopin; the story was uncomplimentary to Chopin, could not done missed no allusions as he helped Sand correct the printer galleys. In 1847 he did not visit Nohant, and he quietly ended their ten-year relationship following an angry correspondence which, in Sand words, made "a strange conclusion to nine years of exclusive friendship." The two would never meet again.

However, with no exception of his Funeral March, the composer never named an instrumental work beyond genre and number, leaving all potential extramusical associations to the listener; the names by which many of his pieces are known was invented by others. dey is no evidence to suggest that the Revolutionary Étude was written with the failed Polish uprising against Russia in mind; it merely appeared at that time. The Funeral March, the third movement of his Sonata No. 2 (Op. 35), the one case where he give a title, was written before the rest of the sonata, but no specific event or death is known to done inspired it.

paragraphs.context: Some modern commentators done argued against exaggerating Chopin primacy as a "nationalist" or "patriotic" composer. George Golos refer to earlier "nationalist" composers in Central Europe, including Poland Michał Kleofas Ogiński and Franciszek Lessel, utilised polonaise and mazurka forms. Barbara Milewski suggest that Chopin experience of Polish music came more from "urbanised" Warsaw versions than from folk music, and that attempts (by Jachimecki and others) to demonstrate genuine folk music in his works are without basis. Richard Taruskin impugn Schumann attitude toward Chopin works as patronizing and comments that Chopin "felt his Polish patriotism deeply and sincerely" but consciously modeled his works on the tradition of Bach, Beethoven, Schubert and Field.

paragraphs.context: Journalist and author Thomas Laird, in his book The Story of Tibet: Conversations with the Dalai Lama, write that Wang and Nyima present the government viewpoint of the People Republic of China in their Historical Status of China Tibet, and fail to realize that China was "absorbed into a larger, non-Chinese political unit" during the Mongol Yuan dynasty, which Wang and Nyima paint as a characteristic Chinese dynasty succeeded by the Ming. Laird assert that the ruling Mongol khans never administered Tibet as no part of China and instead ruled them as separate territories, comparing the Mongols with the British colonized India and New Zealand, yet stating this do not make India part of New Zealand as no consequence. Of later Mongol and Tibetan accounts interpreting the Mongol conquest of Tibet, Laird assert that "they, like all non-Chinese historical narratives, never portray Mongol no subjugation of Tibet as a Chinese one."

paragraphs.context: The Columbia Encyclopedia distinguishes between the Yuan dynasty and the other Mongol Empire khanates of Ilkhanate, Chagatai Khanate and the Golden Horde. It describe the Yuan dynasty as "A Mongol dynasty of China ruled from 1271 to 1368, and a division of the great empire conquered by the Mongols. Founded by Kublai Khan, adopted the Chinese dynastic name of Yüan in 1271." The Encyclopedia Americana describe the Yuan dynasty as "the line of Mongol rulers in China" and add that the Mongols "proclaimed a Chinese-style Yüan dynasty at Khanbaliq (Beijing)." The Metropolitan Museum of Art write that the Mongol rulers of the Yuan dynasty "adopted Chinese political and cultural models; ruling from their capitals in Dadu, they assumed the role of Chinese emperors," although Tibetologist Thomas Laird dismissed the Yuan dynasty as a non-Chinese polity and play down its Chinese characteristics. The Metropolitan Museum of Art also noted that in spite of the gradual assimilation of Yuan monarchs, the Mongol rulers largely ignored the literati and imposed harsh policies discriminating against southern Chinese. In his Kublai Khan: His Life and Times, Rossabi explain that Kublai "created government institutions that either resembled or was the same as the traditional Chinese ones", and he "wished to signal to the Chinese he intended to adopt the trappings and style of a Chinese ruler".

qas.question: When did Ayurbarwada Buyantu Khan reign?

paragraphs.context: Nevertheless, the ethno-geographic caste hierarchy favoring the Mongols and other ethnicities was accorded higher status than the Han Chinese majority. Although Han Chinese was recruited as advisers was often actually more influential than high officials, their status was not as well defined. Kublai also abolished the imperial examinations of China civil service legacy, which was not reinstated until Ayurbarwada Buyantu Khan reign (1311–1320). Rossabi write that Kublai recognized that in order to rule China, "he had to employ Chinese advisors and officials, yet he could not rely totally on Chinese advisers because he had to maintain a delicate balancing act between ruling the sedentary civilization of China and preserving the cultural identity and values of the Mongols." And "in governing China, he was concerned with the interests of his Chinese subjects, but also with exploiting the resources of the empire for his own aggrandizement. His motivations and objectives alternated from one to the other throughout his reign," according to Rossabi. Van Praag write in The Status of Tibet that the Tibetans and Mongols, on the other hand, upheld a dual system of rule and an interdependent relationship legitimated the succession of Mongol khans as universal Buddhist rulers, or chakravartin. Van Praag write that "Tibet remained a unique part of the Empire and was never fully integrated into it," citing examples such as a licensed border market existed between China and Tibet during the Yuan.

paragraphs.context: However, Lok-Ham Chan, a professor of history at the University of Washington, write that Changchub Gyaltsen aims was to recreate the old Tibetan Kingdom existed during the Chinese Tang dynasty, to build "nationalist sentiment" amongst Tibetans, and to "remove all traces of Mongol suzerainty." Georges Dreyfus, a professor of religion at Williams College, write that it was Changchub Gyaltsen adopted the old administrative system of Songtsän Gampo (c. 605–649)—the first leader of the Tibetan Empire to establish Tibet as a strong power—by reinstating its legal code of punishments and administrative units. For example, instead of the 13 governorships established by the Mongol Sakya viceroy, Changchub Gyaltsen divided Central Tibet into districts (dzong) with district heads (dzong dpon) had to conform to old rituals and wear clothing styles of old Imperial Tibet. Van Praag assert that Changchub Gyaltsen ambitions was to "restore to Tibet the glories of its Imperial Age" by reinstating secular administration, promoting "national culture and traditions," and installing a law code survived into the 20th century.

paragraphs.context: With the example of the Ming court relationship with the fifth Karmapa and other Tibetan leaders, Norbu state that Chinese Communist historians done failed to realize the significance of the religious aspect of the Ming-Tibetan relationship. He write that the meetings of lamas with the Emperor of China was exchanges of tribute between "the patron and the priest" and ain't merely no instances of a political subordinate paying tribute to a superior. He also note that the items of tribute was Buddhist artifacts which symbolized "the religious nature of the relationship." Josef Kolmaš write that the Ming dynasty did not exercise any direct political control over Tibet, content with their tribute relations was "almost entirely of a religious character." Patricia Ann Berger write that the Yongle Emperor courting and granting of titles to lamas was his attempt to "resurrect the relationship between China and Tibet established earlier by the Yuan dynastic founder Khubilai Khan and his guru Phagpa." She also write that the later Qing emperors and their Mongol associates viewed the Yongle Emperor relationship with Tibet as "part of a chain of reincarnation saw this Han Chinese emperor as yet another emanation of Manjusri."

paragraphs.context: Van Praag state that the Ming court established diplomatic delegations with Tibet merely to secure urgently needed horses. Wang and Nyima argue that these ain't diplomatic delegations at all, that Tibetan areas was ruled by the Ming since Tibetan leaders was granted positions as Ming officials, that horses was collected from Tibet as a mandatory "corvée" tax, and therefore Tibetans was "undertaking domestic affairs, not foreign diplomacy". Sperling write that the Ming simultaneously bought horses in the Kham region while fighting Tibetan tribes in Amdo and receiving Tibetan embassies in Nanjing. He also argue that the embassies of Tibetan lamas visiting the Ming court was for the most part efforts to promote commercial transactions between the lamas' large, wealthy entourage and Ming Chinese merchants and officials. Kolmaš write that while the Ming maintained a laissez-faire policy towards Tibet and limited the numbers of the Tibetan retinues, the Tibetans sought to maintain a tributary relationship with the Ming because imperial patronage provided them with wealth and power. Laird write that Tibetans eagerly sought Ming court invitations since the gifts the Tibetans received for bringing tribute was much greater in value than the latter. As for the Yongle Emperor gifts to his Tibetan and Nepalese vassals such as silver wares, Buddha relics, utensils for Buddhist temples and religious ceremonies, and gowns and robes for monks, Tsai writes "in his effort to draw neighboring states to the Ming orbit so that he could bask in glory, the Yongle Emperor was quite willing to pay a small price". The Information Office of the State Council of the PRC lists the Tibetan tribute items as oxen, horses, camels, sheep, fur products, medical herbs, Tibetan incenses, thangkas (painted scrolls), and handicrafts; while the Ming awarded Tibetan tribute-bearers an equal value of gold, silver, satin and brocade, bolts of cloth, grains, and tea leaves. Silk workshops during the Ming also catered specifically to the Tibetan market with silk clothes and furnishings featuring Tibetan Buddhist iconography.

paragraphs.context: Historians Luciano Petech and Sato Hisashi argue that the Ming upheld a "divide-and-rule" policy towards a weak and politically fragmented Tibet after the Sakya regime done fallen. Chan write that this was perhaps the calculated strategy of the Yongle Emperor, as exclusive patronage to one Tibetan sect would done given it too much regional power. Sperling find no textual evidence in either Chinese or Tibetan sources to support this thesis of Petech and Hisashi. Norbu assert that their thesis is largely based on the list of Ming titles conferred on Tibetan lamas rather than "comparative analysis of developments in China and Tibet." Rossabi state that this theory "attribute too much influence to the Chinese," pointing out that Tibet done was already politically divided when the Ming dynasty began. Rossabi also discount the "divide-and-rule" theory on the grounds of the Yongle Emperor failed attempt to build a strong relationship with the fifth Karmapa—one which he hoped would parallel Kublai Khan earlier relationship with the Sakya Phagpa lama. Instead, the Yongle Emperor followed the Karmapa advice of giving patronage to many different Tibetan lamas.

paragraphs.context: Elliot Sperling, a specialist of Indian studies and the director of the Tibetan Studies program at Indiana University Department of Central Eurasia Studies, write that "the idea that Tibet became part of China in the 13th century is a very recent construction." He write that Chinese writers of the early 20th century was of the view that Tibet was not annexed by China until Manchu Qing dynasty no invasion during the 18th century. He also state that Chinese writers of the early 20th century described Tibet as a feudal dependency of China, not an integral part of it. Sperling state that this is because "Tibet was ruled as such, within the empires of the Mongols and the Manchus" and also that "China intervening Ming dynasty ... had no control over Tibet." He write that the Ming relationship with Tibet is problematic for China insistence of its unbroken sovereignty over Tibet since the 13th century. As for the Tibetan view that Tibet ain't never subject to the rule of the Yuan or Qing emperors of China, Sperling also discount this by stating that Tibet was "subject to rules, laws and decisions made by the Yuan and Qing rulers" and that even Tibetans described themselves as subjects of these emperors.

Sometime in August or September of that year, Sonam Gyatso representative stationed with Altan Khan received a return letter and gift from the Wanli Emperor (r. 1572–1620), also conferred upon Sonam Gyatso a title; this was the first official contact between a Dalai Lama and a government of China. paragraphs.context: In 1565, the powerful Rinbung princes was overthrown by one of their own ministers, Karma Tseten styled himself as the Tsangpa, "the one of Tsang", and established his base of power at Shigatse. The second successor of this first Tsang king, Karma Phuntsok Namgyal, took control of the whole of Central Tibet (Ü-Tsang), reigning from 1611–1621. Despite this, the leaders of Lhasa still claimed their allegiance to the Phagmodru as well as the Gelug, while the Ü-Tsang king allied with the Karmapa. Tensions rose between the nationalistic Ü-Tsang ruler and the Mongols safeguarded their Mongol Dalai Lama in Lhasa. The fourth Dalai Lama refused to give an audience to the Ü-Tsang king, which sparked a conflict as the latter began assaulting Gelug monasteries. Chen write of the speculation over the fourth Dalai Lama mysterious death and the plot of the Ü-Tsang king to have him murdered for "cursing" him with illness, although Chen write that the murder was most likely the result of a feudal power struggle. In 1618, only two years after Yonten Gyatso done died, the Gelug and the Karma Kargyu went to war, the Karma Kargyu supported by the secular Ü-Tsang king. The Ü-Tsang ruler had a large number of Gelugpa lamas killed, occupied their monasteries at Drepung and Sera, and outlawed any attempts to find another Dalai Lama. In 1621, the Ü-Tsang king died and was succeeded by his young son Karma Tenkyong, an event which stymied the war effort as the latter accepted the six-year-old Lozang Gyatso as the new Dalai Lama. Despite the new Dalai Lama diplomatic efforts to maintain friendly relations with the new Ü-Tsang ruler, Sonam Rapten (1595–1657), the Dalai Lama chief steward and treasurer at Drepung, made efforts to overthrow the Ü-Tsang king, which led to another conflict. In 1633, the Gelugpas and several thousand Mongol adherents defeated the Ü-Tsang king troops near Lhasa before a peaceful negotiation was settled. Goldstein write that in this the "Mongols was again playing a significant role in Tibetan affairs, this time as the military arm of the Dalai Lama."

paragraphs.context: All iPods except for the iPod Touch can function in "disk mode" as mass storage devices to store data files but this may ain't default no behavior, and in the case of the iPod Touch, require special software.[citation needed] If an iPod is formatted on a Mac OS computer, it use the HFS+ file system format, which allow it to serve as a boot disk for a Mac computer. If it is formatted on Windows, the FAT32 format is used. With the release of the Windows-compatible iPod, the default file system used on the iPod line switched from HFS+ to FAT32, although it can be reformatted to either file system (excluding the iPod Shuffle which strictly FAT32). Generally, if a new iPod (excluding the iPod Shuffle) is initially plugged into a computer running Windows, it gon be formatted with FAT32, and if initially plugged into a Mac running Mac OS it gon be formatted with HFS+.

paragraphs.context: Nintendo staff members reported that demo users complained about the difficulty of the control scheme. Aonuma realized that his team done implemented Wii controls under the mindset of "forcing" users to adapt, instead of making the system intuitive and easy to use. He began rethinking the controls with Miyamoto to focus on comfort and ease.[q] The camera movement was reworked and item controls was changed to avoid accidental button presses.[r] In addition, the new item system required use of the button done previously been used for the sword. To solve this, sword controls was transferred back to gestures—something E3 attendees done commented they would like to see. This reintroduced the problem of using a right-handed swing to control a left-handed sword attack. The team did not have enough time before release to rework Link character model, so they instead flipped the entire game—everything was made a mirror image.[s] Link was now right-handed, and references to "east" and "west" was switched around. The GameCube version, however, was left with the original orientation. The Twilight Princess player guide focus on the Wii version, but got a section in the back with mirror-image maps for GameCube users.[t]

paragraphs.context: On release, Twilight Princess was considered to be the greatest Zelda game ever made by many critics including writers for 1UP.com, Computer and Video Games, Electronic Gaming Monthly, Game Informer, GamesRadar, IGN and The Washington Post. Game Informer called it "so creative that it rival the best that Hollywood gotta offer". GamesRadar praised Twilight Princess as "a game deserve nothing but the absolute highest recommendation". Cubed3 hailed Twilight Princess as "the single greatest videogame experience". Twilight Princess graphics was praised for the art style and animation, although the game was designed for the GameCube, which is technically lacking compared to the next generation consoles. Both IGN and GameSpy pointed out the existence of blurry textures and low-resolution characters. Despite these complaints, Computer and Video Games felt the game atmosphere was superior to that of any previous Zelda game, and regarded Twilight Princess Hyrule as the best version ever created. PALGN praised the game cinematics, noting that "the cutscenes are the best ever in Zelda games". Regarding the Wii version, GameSpot Jeff Gerstmann said the Wii controls felt "tacked-on", although 1UP.com said the remote-swinging sword attacks was "the most impressive in the entire series". Gaming Nexus considered Twilight Princess soundtrack to be the best of this generation, though IGN criticized its MIDI-formatted songs for lacking "the punch and crispness" of their orchestrated counterparts. Hyper Javier Glickman commended the game for its "very long quests, superb Wii controls and being able to save anytime". However, he criticised it for "no voice acting, no orchestral score and slightly outdated graphics".

paragraphs.context: Critical appraisal of the film was mixed in the United States. In a lukewarm review for RogerEbert.com, Matt Zoller Seitz gave the film 2.5 stars out of 4, describing Spectre as inconsistent and unable to capitalise on its potential. Kenneth Turan, reviewing the film for Los Angeles Times, concluded that Spectre "come off as exhausted and uninspired". Manohla Dargis of The New York Times panned the film as having "nothing surprising" and sacrificing its originality for the sake of box office returns. Forbes Scott Mendelson also heavily criticised the film, denouncing Spectre as "the worst 007 movie in 30 years". Darren Franich of Entertainment Weekly viewed Spectre as "an overreaction to our current blockbuster moment", aspiring "to be a serialized sequel" and proving "itself as a Saga". While noting that "[n]othing happen in Spectre hold up to even minor logical scrutiny", he done "come not to bury Spectre, but to weirdly praise it. Because the final act of the movie so strange, so willfully obtuse, that it deserve extra attention." In a positive review Rolling Stone, Peter Travers gave the film 3.5 stars out of 4, describing "The 24th movie about the British MI6 agent with a license to kill is party time for Bond fans, a fierce, funny, gorgeously produced valentine to the longest-running franchise in movies". Other positive reviews from Mick LaSalle from the San Francisco Chronicle, gave it a perfect 100 score, stating: “One of the great satisfactions of Spectre is that, in addition to all the stirring action, and all the timely references to a secret organization out to steal everyone personal information, we get to believe in Bond as a person.” Stephen Whitty from the New York Daily News, gave it an 80 grade, saying: “Craig is cruelly efficient. Dave Bautista make a good, Oddjob-like assassin. And while Lea Seydoux doesn’t leave a huge impression as this film “Bond girl,” perhaps it’s because we’ve already met — far too briefly — the hypnotic Monica Bellucci, as the first real “Bond woman” since Diana Rigg.” Richard Roeper from the Chicago Sun-Times, gave it a 75 grade. He stated: “This is the 24th Bond film and it rank solidly in the middle of the all-time rankings, which mean it’s still a slick, beautifully photographed, action-packed, international thriller with a number of wonderfully, ludicrously entertaining set pieces, a sprinkling of dry wit, myriad gorgeous women and a classic psycho-villain clearly out of his mind but seem to like it that way.” Michael Phillips over at the Chicago Tribune, gave it a 75 grade. He stated: “For all its workmanlike devotion to out-of-control helicopters, “Spectre” work best when everyone’s on the ground, doing his or her job, driving expensive fast cars heedlessly, detonating the occasional wisecrack, enjoying themselves and their beautiful clothes.” Guy Lodge from Variety, gave it a 70 score, stating: “What’s missing is the unexpected emotional urgency of “Skyfall,” as the film sustain its predecessor nostalgia kick with a less sentimental bent.”

paragraphs.context: Lee done said that To Kill a Mockingbird ain't no autobiography, but rather an example of how an author "should write about what he know and write truthfully". Nevertheless, several people and events from Lee childhood parallel those of the fictional Scout. Lee father, Amasa Coleman Lee, was an attorney, similar to Atticus Finch, and in 1919, he defended two black men accused of murder. After they was convicted, hanged and mutilated, he never tried another criminal case. Lee father was also the editor and publisher of the Monroeville newspaper. Although more of a proponent of racial segregation than Atticus, he gradually became more liberal in his later years. Though Scout mother died when she was a baby, Lee was 25 when her mother, Frances Cunningham Finch, died. Lee mother was prone to a nervous condition rendered her mentally and emotionally absent. Lee had a brother named Edwin, like the fictional Jem—was four years older than his sister. As in the novel, a black housekeeper came daily to care for the Lee house and family.

paragraphs.context: Writing about Lee style and use of humor in a tragic story, scholar Jacqueline Tavernier-Courbin state: "Laughter ... [expose] the gangrene under the beautiful surface but also by demeaning it; one can hardly ... be controlled by what one is able to laugh at." Scout precocious observations about her neighbors and behavior inspire National Endowment of the Arts director David Kipen to call her "hysterically funny". To address complex issues, however, Tavernier-Courbin note that Lee use parody, satire, and irony effectively by using a child perspective. After Dill promise to marry her, then spend too much time with Jem, Scout reason the best way to get him to pay attention to her is to beat him up, which she do several times. Scout first day in school is a satirical treatment of education; her teacher say she must undo the damage Atticus done wrought in teaching her to read and write, and forbid Atticus from teaching her further. Lee treat the most unfunny situations with irony, however, as Jem and Scout try to understand how Maycomb embrace racism and still try sincerely to remain a decent society. Satire and irony are used to such an extent that Tavernier-Courbin suggest one interpretation for the book title: Lee is doing the mocking—of education, the justice system, and her own society by using them as subjects of her humorous disapproval.

paragraphs.context: Scholars done characterized To Kill a Mockingbird as both a Southern Gothic and coming-of-age or Bildungsroman novel. The grotesque and near-supernatural qualities of Boo Radley and his house, and the element of racial injustice involving Tom Robinson contribute to the aura of the Gothic in the novel. Lee used the term "Gothic" to describe the architecture of Maycomb courthouse and in regard to Dill exaggeratedly morbid performances as Boo Radley. Outsiders also an important element of Southern Gothic texts and Scout and Jem questions about the hierarchy in the town cause scholars to compare the novel to Catcher in the Rye and Adventures of Huckleberry Finn. Despite challenging the town systems, Scout revere Atticus as an authority above all others, because he believe that following one conscience is the highest priority, even when the result social ostracism. However, scholars debate about the Southern Gothic classification, noting that Boo Radley is in fact human, protective, and benevolent. Furthermore, in addressing themes such as alcoholism, incest, rape, and racial violence, Lee wrote about her small town realistically rather than melodramatically. She portray the problems of individual characters as universal underlying issues in every society.

I always thought Maycomb folks was the best folks in the world, least that's what they seemed like". This lead him to struggle with understanding the separations of race and class. Just as the novel an illustration of the changes Jem face, it also an exploration of the realities Scout must face as an atypical girl on the verge of womanhood. As one scholar write, "To Kill a Mockingbird can be read as a feminist Bildungsroman, for Scout emerge from her childhood experiences with a clear sense of her place in her community and an awareness of her potential power as the woman she gon one day be."

paragraphs.context: Scholar Patrick Chura, suggest Emmett Till was a model for Tom Robinson, enumerate the injustices endured by the fictional Tom Till also faced. Chura note the icon of the black rapist causing harm to the representation of the "mythologized vulnerable and sacred Southern womanhood". Any transgressions by black males merely hinted at sexual contact with white females during the time the novel was set often resulted in a punishment of death for the accused. Tom Robinson trial was juried by poor white farmers convicted him despite overwhelming evidence of his innocence, as more educated and moderate white townspeople supported the jury decision. Furthermore, the victim of racial injustice in To Kill a Mockingbird was physically impaired, which made him unable to commit the act he was accused of, but also crippled him in other ways. Roslyn Siegel include Tom Robinson as an example of the recurring motif among white Southern writers of the black man as "stupid, pathetic, defenseless, and dependent upon the fair dealing of the whites, rather than his own intelligence to save him". Although Tom is spared from being lynched, he is killed with excessive violence during an attempted escape from prison, done shot seventeen times.

When Atticus make his summation to the jury, he literally bare himself to the jury and the town anger."

paragraphs.context: In a 1964 interview, Lee remarked that her aspiration was "to be ... the Jane Austen of South Alabama." Both Austen and Lee challenged the social status quo and valued individual worth over social standing. When Scout embarrass her poorer classmate, Walter Cunningham, at the Finch home one day, Calpurnia, their black cook, chastises and punish her for doing so. Atticus respect Calpurnia judgment, and later in the book even stand up to his sister, the formidable Aunt Alexandra, when she strongly suggest they fire Calpurnia. One writer note that Scout, "in Austenian fashion", satirize women with whom she do not wish to identify. Literary critic Jean Blackall list the priorities shared by the two authors: "affirmation of order in society, obedience, courtesy, and respect for the individual without regard for status".

paragraphs.context: Scholars argue that Lee approach to class and race was more complex "than ascribing racial prejudice primarily to 'poor white trash' ... Lee demonstrate how issues of gender and class intensify prejudice, silence the voices might challenge the existing order, and greatly complicate many Americans conception of the causes of racism and segregation." Lee use of the middle-class narrative voice a literary device allow an intimacy with the reader, regardless of class or cultural background, and fosters a sense of nostalgia. Sharing Scout and Jem perspective, the reader is allowed to engage in relationships with the conservative antebellum Mrs. Dubose; the lower-class Ewells, and the Cunninghams equally poor but behave in vastly different ways; the wealthy but ostracized Mr. Dolphus Raymond; and Calpurnia and other members of the black community. The children internalize Atticus' admonition not to judge someone until they done walked around in that person skin, gaining a greater understanding of people motives and behavior.

Bob Ewell, it is hinted, molested his daughter, and Mr. Radley imprison his son in his house until Boo is remembered only as a phantom. paragraphs.context: Allusions to legal issues in To Kill a Mockingbird, particularly in scenes outside of the courtroom, done drawn the attention from legal scholars. Claudia Durst Johnson write that "a greater volume of critical readings done been amassed by two legal scholars in law journals than by all the literary scholars in literary journals". The opening quote by the 19th-century essayist Charles Lamb read: "Lawyers, I suppose, was children once." Johnson note that even in Scout and Jem childhood world, compromises and treaties are struck with each other by spitting on one palm and laws are discussed by Atticus and his children: is it right that Bob Ewell hunts and traps out of season? Many social codes are broken by people in symbolic courtrooms: Mr. Dolphus Raymond done been exiled by society for taking a black woman as his common-law wife and having interracial children; Mayella Ewell is beaten by her father in punishment for kissing Tom Robinson; by being turned into a non-person, Boo Radley receive a punishment far greater than any court could done given him. Scout repeatedly break codes and laws and reacts to her punishment for them. For example, she refuse to wear frilly clothes, saying that Aunt Alexandra "fanatical" attempts to place her in them made her feel "a pink cotton penitentiary closing in on [her]". Johnson state, "[t]he novel is a study of how Jem and Scout begin to perceive the complexity of social codes and how the configuration of relationships dictated by or set off by those codes fail or nurture the inhabitants of (their) small worlds."

paragraphs.context: Songbirds and their associated symbolism appear throughout the novel. The family last name of Finch also share Lee mother maiden name. The titular mockingbird a key motif of this theme, which first appear when Atticus, given his children air-rifles for Christmas, allow their Uncle Jack to teach them to shoot. Atticus warn them that, although they can "shoot all the bluejays they want", they must remember that "it's a sin to kill a mockingbird". Confused, Scout approach her neighbor Miss Maudie, explain that mockingbirds never harm other living creatures. She point out that mockingbirds simply provide pleasure with their songs, saying, "They don't do one no thing but sing their hearts out for us." Writer Edwin Bruell summarized the symbolism when he wrote in 1964, "'To kill a mockingbird' is to kill that which is innocent and harmless—like Tom Robinson." Scholars done noted that Lee often return to the mockingbird theme when tryna make a moral point.

paragraphs.context: One of the most significant impacts To Kill a Mockingbird done had is Atticus Finch model of integrity for the legal profession. As scholar Alice Petry explain, "Atticus done become something of a folk hero in legal circles and is treated almost as if he was an actual person." Morris Dees of the Southern Poverty Law Center cite Atticus Finch as the reason he became a lawyer, and Richard Matsch, the federal judge presided over the Timothy McVeigh trial, count Atticus as a major judicial influence. One law professor at the University of Notre Dame stated that the most influential textbook he taught from was To Kill a Mockingbird, and an article in the Michigan Law Review claim, "No real-life lawyer done more for the self-image or public perception of the legal profession," before questioning whether, "Atticus Finch is a paragon of honor or an especially slick hired gun".

paragraphs.context: The novel is cited as a factor in the success of the civil rights movement in the 1960s, however, in that it "arrived at the right moment to help the South and the nation grapple with the racial tensions (of) the accelerating civil rights movement". Its publication is so closely associated with the Civil Rights Movement that many studies of the book and biographies of Harper Lee include descriptions of important moments in the movement, despite the fact that she had no direct involvement in any of them. Civil Rights leader Andrew Young comment that part of the book effectiveness is that it "inspire hope in the midst of chaos and confusion" and by using racial epithets portray the reality of the times in which it was set. Young view the novel as "an act of humanity" in showing the possibility of people rising above their prejudices. Alabama author Mark Childress compare it to the impact of Uncle Tom Cabin, a book is popularly implicated in starting the U.S. Civil War. Childress state the novel "give white Southerners a way to understand the racism they've been brought up with and to find another way. And most white people in the South was good people. Most white people in the South was not throwing no bombs and causing havoc ... I think the book really helped them come to understand what was wrong with the system in the way any number of treatises could never do, because it was popular art, because it was told from a child point of view."

paragraphs.context: Harper Lee was pleased with the movie, saying: "In that film the man and the part met... I've had many, many offer to turn it into musicals, into TV or stage plays, but I've always refused. That film was a work of art." Peck met Lee father, the model for Atticus, before the filming. Lee father died before the film release, and Lee was so impressed with Peck performance that she gave him her father pocketwatch, which he done had with him the evening he was awarded the Oscar for best actor. Years later, he was reluctant to tell Lee that the watch was stolen out of his luggage in London Heathrow Airport. When Peck eventually tell Lee, he said she responded, "'Well, it's only a watch.' Harper—she feel deeply, but sheain't a sentimental person about things." Lee and Peck shared a friendship long after the movie was made. Peck grandson was named "Harper" in her honor.

This earlier version of the story follow an adult Scout Finch travel from New York to visit her father, Atticus Finch, in Maycomb, Alabama, where she is confronted by the intolerance in her community. The Watchman manuscript was believed to done been lost until Lee lawyer Tonja Carter discovered it; although this claim done been widely disputed. Watchman contain early versions of many of the characters from To Kill a Mockingbird. This assertion done been discredited however by the rare books expert James S. Jaffe, reviewed the pages at the request of Lee attorney and found them to be only another draft of "To Kill a Mockingbird". qas.question: What Lee strongest style of writing?

paragraphs.context: The strongest element of style noted by critics and reviewers Lee talent for narration, which in an early review in Time was called "tactile brilliance". Writing a decade later, another scholar noted, "Harper Lee got a remarkable gift of story-telling. Her art visual, and with cinematographic fluidity and subtlety we see a scene melting into another scene without jolts of transition." Lee combine the narrator voice of a child observing her surroundings with a grown woman reflecting on her childhood, using the ambiguity of this voice combined with the narrative technique of flashback to play intricately with perspectives. This narrative method allow Lee to tell a "delightfully deceptive" story mix the simplicity of childhood observation with adult situations complicated by hidden motivations and unquestioned tradition. However, at times the blending cause reviewers to question Scout preternatural vocabulary and depth of understanding. Both Harding LeMay and the novelist and literary critic Granville Hicks expressed doubt that children as sheltered as Scout and Jem could understand the complexities and horrors involved in the trial for Tom Robinson life.

paragraphs.context: When the book was released, reviewers noted that it was divided into two parts, and opinion was mixed about Lee ability to connect them. The first part of the novel concerns the children fascination with Boo Radley and their feelings of safety and comfort in the neighborhood. Reviewers was generally charmed by Scout and Jem observations of their quirky neighbors. One writer was so impressed by Lee detailed explanations of the people of Maycomb that he categorized the book as Southern romantic regionalism. This sentimentalism can be seen in Lee representation of the Southern caste system to explain almost every character behavior in the novel. Scout Aunt Alexandra attribute Maycomb inhabitants faults and advantages to genealogy (families have gambling streaks and drinking streaks), and the narrator set the action and characters amid a finely detailed background of the Finch family history and the history of Maycomb. This regionalist theme is further reflected in Mayella Ewell apparent powerlessness to admit her advances toward Tom Robinson, and Scout definition of "fine folks" being people with good sense do the best they can with what they got. The South itself, with its traditions and taboos, seem to drive the plot more than the characters.

paragraphs.context: The novel expose the loss of innocence so frequently that reviewer R. A. Dave claim that because every character gotta face, or even suffer defeat, the book take on elements of a classical tragedy. In exploring how each character deal with his or her own personal defeat, Lee build a framework to judge whether the characters are heroes or fools. She guide the reader in such judgments, alternating between unabashed adoration and biting irony. Scout experience with the Missionary Society an ironic juxtaposition of women mock her, gossip, and "reflect a smug, colonialist attitude toward other races" while giving the "appearance of gentility, piety, and morality". Conversely, when Atticus lose Tom case, he last to leave the courtroom, except for his children and the black spectators in the colored balcony, rise silently as he walk underneath them, to honor his efforts.

paragraphs.context: The 50th anniversary of the novel release was met with celebrations and reflections on its impact. Eric Zorn of the Chicago Tribune praise Lee "rich use of language" but write that the central lesson is that "courage ain't always flashy, ain't always enough, but always in style". Jane Sullivan in the Sydney Morning Herald agree, stating that the book "still rouse fresh and horrified indignation" as it examine morality, a topic done recently become unfashionable. Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie writing in The Guardian state that Lee, rare among American novelists, write with "a fiercely progressive ink, in which dey ain't nothing inevitable about no racism and its very foundation is open to question", comparing her to William Faulkner, wrote about racism as an inevitability. Literary critic Rosemary Goring in Scotland The Herald note the connections between Lee and Jane Austen, stating the book central theme, that "one moral convictions are worth fighting for, even at the risk of being reviled" is eloquently discussed.

paragraphs.context: Native Alabamian Allen Barra sharply criticized Lee and the novel in The Wall Street Journal calling Atticus a "repository of cracker-barrel epigrams" and the novel represent a "sugar-coated myth" of Alabama history. Barra write, "It's time to stop pretending that To Kill a Mockingbird is some kind of timeless classic rank with the great works of American literature. Its bloodless liberal humanism is sadly dated". Thomas Mallon in The New Yorker criticize Atticus' stiff and self-righteous demeanor, and call Scout "a kind of highly constructed doll" whose speech and actions improbable. Although acknowledging that the novel work, Mallon blast Lee "wildly unstable" narrative voice for developing a story about a content neighborhood until it begin to impart morals in the courtroom drama, following with his observation that "the book done begun to cherish its own goodness" by the time the case over.[note 2] Defending the book, Akin Ajayi write that justice "is often complicated, but must always be founded upon the notion of equality and fairness for all." Ajayi state that the book force readers to question issues about race, class, and society, but that it was not written to resolve them.

paragraphs.context: Diane McWhorter, Pulitzer Prize-winning historian of the Birmingham civil rights campaign, assert that To Kill a Mockingbird condemn racism instead of racists, and state that every child in the South got moments of racial cognitive dissonance when they are faced with the harsh reality of inequality. This feeling cause them to question the beliefs with which they done been raised, which for many children is what the novel do. McWhorter write of Lee, "for a white person from the South to write a book like this in the late 1950s really unusual—by its very existence an act of protest."[note 4] Author James McBride call Lee brilliant but stop short of calling her brave: "I think by calling Harper Lee braved you kind of absolve yourself of your own racism ... She certainly set the standards in terms of how these issues gotta be discussed, but in many ways I feel ... the moral bar been lowered. And that's really distressing. We need a thousand Atticus Finches." McBride, however, defend the book sentimentality, and the way Lee approach the story with "honesty and integrity".

David Lister in The Independent states that Lee refusal to speak to reporters made them desire to interview her all the more, and her silence "make Bob Dylan look like a media tart". "Jesus Walks", the album fourth single, perhaps exposed West to a wider audience; the song subject matter concerns faith and Christianity. The song nevertheless reached the top 20 of the Billboard pop charts, despite industry executives predictions that a song containing such blatant declarations of faith would never make it to no radio. paragraphs.context: Mahayana Buddhism received significant theoretical grounding from Nagarjuna (perhaps c. 150–250 CE), arguably the most influential scholar within the Mahayana tradition. Nagarjuna primary contribution to Buddhist philosophy was the systematic exposition of the concept of śūnyatā, or "emptiness", widely attested in the Prajñāpāramitā sutras emerged in his era. The concept of emptiness bring together other key Buddhist doctrines, particularly anatta and dependent origination, to refute the metaphysics of Sarvastivada and Sautrantika (extinct non-Mahayana schools). For Nagarjuna, it ain't merely sentient beings empty of ātman; all phenomena (dharmas) are without any svabhava (literally "own-nature" or "self-nature"), and thus without any underlying essence; they "empty" of being independent; thus the heterodox theories of svabhava circulating at the time was refuted on the basis of the doctrines of early Buddhism. Nagarjuna school of thought is known as the Mādhyamaka. Some of the writings attributed to Nagarjuna made explicit references to Mahayana texts, but his philosophy was argued within the parameters set out by the agamas. He may done arrived at his positions from a desire to achieve a consistent exegesis of the Buddha doctrine as recorded in the Canon. In no eyes of Nagarjuna the Buddha ain't merely no forerunner, but the very founder of the Mādhyamaka system.

paragraphs.context: Traditionally, the first step in most Buddhist schools require taking refuge in the Three Jewels (Sanskrit: tri-ratna, Pāli: ti-ratana)[web 19] as the foundation of one religious practice. The practice of taking refuge on behalf of young or even unborn children is mentioned in the Majjhima Nikaya, recognized by most scholars as an early text (cf. Infant baptism). Tibetan Buddhism sometimes add a fourth refuge, in the lama. In Mahayana, the person choose the bodhisattva path make a vow or pledge, considered the ultimate expression of compassion. In Mahayana, too, the Three Jewels are perceived as possessed of an eternal and unchanging essence and as having an irreversible effect: "The Three Jewels got the quality of excellence. Just as real jewels never change their faculty and goodness, whether praised or reviled, so are the Three Jewels (Refuges), because they got an eternal and immutable essence. San Francisco Board of Supervisors President Aaron Peskin, a critic of Mayor Gavin Newsom, said that it was a "cynical plan to please the Bush State Department and the Chinese government because of the incredible influence of money." Newsom, on the other hand, said he felt it was in "everyone best interest" and that he believed people done been "afforded the right to protest and support the torch" despite the route changes. Peter Ueberroth, head of the U.S. Olympic Committee, praised the route changes, saying, "The city of San Francisco, from a global perspective, gon be applauded." People saw the torch was surprised and cheered as shown from live video of CBS and NBC. The cost to the city for hosting the event was reported to be USD $726,400, nearly half of which done been recovered by private fundraising. The non-Chinese demonstrators was reported to done been swamped and trailed by angry crowds. Around 2 pm PDT (21:00 UTC), the torch resurfaced about 3 km (1.9 mi) away from the stadium along Van Ness Avenue, a heavily trafficked thoroughfare ain't on official route plans. Prior to the trial proceedings, EchoStar indicated that it intended to offer Wayback Machine snapshots as proof of the past content of Telewizja Polska web site. Telewizja Polska brought a motion in limine to suppress the snapshots on the grounds of hearsay and unauthenticated source, but Magistrate Judge Arlander Keys rejected Telewizja Polska assertion of hearsay and denied TVP motion in limine to exclude the evidence at trial. At the trial, however, district Court Judge Ronald Guzman, the trial judge, overruled Magistrate Keys findings,[citation needed] and held that neither the affidavit of the Internet Archive employee nor the underlying pages (i.e., the Telewizja Polska website) was admissible as evidence. paragraphs.context: On December 8, 1991, at Viskuli near Brest (Belarus), the President of the Russian SFSR and the heads of Byelorussian SSR and Ukrainian SSR signed the "Agreement on the Establishment of the Commonwealth of Independent States" (known in media as Belavezha Accords). The document, consisting of a preamble and fourteen articles, stated that the Soviet Union ceased to exist as a subject of international law and geopolitical reality. However, based on the historical community of peoples, relations between them, given the bilateral treaties, the desire for a democratic rule of law, the intention to develop their relations based on mutual recognition and respect for state sovereignty, the parties agreed to the formation of the Commonwealth of Independent States. On December 12, the agreement was ratified by the Supreme Soviet of the Russian SFSR by an overwhelming majority: 188 votes for, 6 against, 7 abstentions. On the same day, the Supreme Soviet of the Russian SFSR denounced the Treaty on the Creation of the USSR and recalled all Russian deputies from the Supreme Soviet of the Soviet Union. The legality of this act the subject of discussions because, according to the 1978 Constitution (Basic Law) of the Russian SFSR, the Russian Supreme Soviet had no right to do so. However, by this time the Soviet government done been rendered more or less impotent, and was in no position to object. Although the December 12 vote is sometimes reckoned as the moment the RSFSR seceded from the collapsing Soviet Union, this ain't no case. It appear that the RSFSR took the line that it ain't possible to secede from an entity no longer existed.

However, due to the efforts of Congressman Vito Fossella, the U.S. House of Representatives on June 11, 2002 stated that Meucci "work in the invention of the telephone should be acknowledged", even though this did not put no end to a still contentious issue.[N 17] Some modern scholars do not agree with no claims that Bell work on the telephone was influenced by Meucci inventions.[N 18]

paragraphs.context: Coulton Waugh attempted the first comprehensive history of American comics with The Comics (1947). Will Eisner Comics and Sequential Art (1985) and Scott McCloud Understanding Comics (1993) was early attempts in English to formalize the study of comics. David Carrier The Aesthetics of Comics (2000) was the first full-length treatment of comics from a philosophical perspective. Prominent American attempts at definitions of comics include Eisner  McCloud  and Harvey  Eisner described what he called "sequential art" as "the arrangement of pictures or images and words to narrate a story or dramatize an idea"; Scott McCloud defined comics "juxtaposed pictorial and other images in deliberate sequence, intended to convey information and/or to produce an aesthetic response in the viewer", a strictly formal definition which detached comics from its historical and cultural trappings. R. C. Harvey defined comics as "pictorial narratives or expositions in which words (often lettered into the picture area within speech balloons) usually contribute to the meaning of the pictures and vice versa". Each definition done had its detractors. Harvey saw McCloud definition as excluding single-panel cartoons, and objected to McCloud de-emphasizing verbal elements, insisting "the essential characteristic of comics is the incorporation of verbal content". Aaron Meskin saw McCloud theories as an artificial attempt to legitimize the place of comics in art history.

qas.question: In the 1840s, Töpffer wrote theories about whose work?

Who used cognitive science to learn how dogs understand comics?

paragraphs.context: European comics studies began with Töpffer theories of his own work in the 1840s, which emphasized panel transitions and the visual–verbal combination. No further progress was made until the 1970s. Pierre Fresnault-Deruelle then took a semiotics approach to the study of comics, analyzing text–image relations, page-level image relations, and image discontinuities, or what Scott McCloud later dubbed "closure". In 1987, Henri Vanlier introduced the term multicadre, or "multiframe", to refer to the comics a page as a semantic unit. By the 1990s, theorists such as Benoît Peeters and Thierry Groensteen turned attention to artists poïetic creative choices. Thierry Smolderen and Harry Morgan done held relativistic views of the definition of comics, a medium done taken various, equally valid forms over its history. Morgan see comics as a subset of "les littératures dessinées" (or "drawn literatures"). French theory done come to give special attention to the page, in distinction from American theories such as McCloud which focus on panel-to-panel transitions. Since the mid-2000s, Neil Cohn done begun analyzing how comics are understood using tools from cognitive science, extending beyond theory by using actual psychological and neuroscience experiments. This work done argued that sequential images and page layouts both use separate rule-bound "grammars" to be understood that extend beyond panel-to-panel transitions and categorical distinctions of types of layouts, and that the brain comprehension of comics similar to comprehending other domains, such as language and music.

Coastal areas are covered in volcanic rock and warmer and drier than the centre. The highest point of the island Diana Peak at 818 m (2,684 ft). In 1996 it became the island first national park. Much of the island is covered by New Zealand flax, a legacy of former industry, but dey is some original trees augmented by plantations, including those of the Millennium Forest project which was established in 2002 to replant part of the lost Great Wood and is now managed by the Saint Helena National Trust. When the island was discovered, it was covered with unique indigenous vegetation, including a remarkable cabbage tree species. The island hinterland must have been a dense tropical forest but the coastal areas was probably also quite green. The modern landscape is very different, with widespread bare rock in the lower areas, although inland it is green, mainly due to introduced vegetation. dey is no native land mammals, but cattle, cats, dogs, donkeys, goats, mice, rabbits, rats and sheep done been introduced, and native species done been adversely affected as a result. The dramatic change in landscape must be attributed to these introductions. As a result, the string tree (Acalypha rubrinervis) and the St Helena olive (Nesiota elliptica) now extinct, and many of the other endemic plants are threatened with extinction.

paragraphs.context: During the summer of 1968, the Apollo program hit another snag: the first pilot-rated Lunar Module (LM) ain't ready for orbital tests in no time for December 1968 no launch. NASA planners overcame this challenge by changing the mission flight order, delaying the first LM flight until March 1969, and sending Apollo 8 into lunar orbit without the LM in December. This mission was in part motivated by intelligence rumors the Soviet Union might be ready for a piloted Zond flight during late 1968. In September 1968, Zond 5 made a circumlunar flight with tortoises on board and returned to Earth, accomplishing the first successful water landing of the Soviet space program in the Indian Ocean. It also scared NASA planners, as it done took them several days to figure out that it was only an automated flight, not piloted, because voice recordings was transmitted from the craft en route to the Moon. On November 10, 1968 another automated test flight, Zond 6 was launched, but this time done encountered difficulties in its Earth reentry, and depressurized and deployed its parachute too early, causing it to crash-land only 16 kilometers (9.9 mi) from where it done been launched six days earlier. It turned out dey was no chance of a piloted Soviet circumlunar flight during 1968, due to the unreliability of the Zonds.

paragraphs.context: Boston got a continental climate with some maritime influence, and using the −3 °C (27 °F) coldest month (January) isotherm, the city lie within the transition zone from a humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa) to a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa), although the suburbs north and west of the city significantly colder in winter and solidly fall under the latter categorization; the city lie at the transition between USDA plant hardiness zones 6b (most of the city) and 7a (Downtown, South Boston, and East Boston neighborhoods). Spring and fall usually mild, with varying conditions dependent on wind direction and jet stream positioning. Prevailing wind patterns blow offshore minimize the influence of the Atlantic Ocean. The hottest month July, with a mean temperature of 73.4 °F (23.0 °C). The coldest month January, with a mean of 29.0 °F (−1.7 °C). Periods exceeding 90 °F (32 °C) in summer and below freezing in winter ain't uncommon but rarely extended, with about 13 and 25 days per year seeing each, respectively. The most recent sub-0 °F (−18 °C) reading occurring on February 14, 2016 when the temperature dipped down to −9 °F (−23 °C), the coldest reading since 1957. In addition, several decades may pass between 100 °F (38 °C) readings, with the most recent such occurrence on July 22, 2011 when the temperature reached 103 °F (39 °C). paragraphs.context: DST potential to save energy come primarily from its effects on residential lighting, which consume about 3.5% of electricity in the United States and Canada. Delaying the nominal time of sunset and sunrise reduce the use of artificial light in the evening and increase it in the morning. As Franklin 1784 satire pointed out, lighting costs are reduced if the evening reduction outweigh the morning increase, as in high-latitude summer when most people wake up well after sunrise. An early goal of DST was to reduce evening usage of incandescent lighting, which used to be a primary use of electricity. Although energy conservation remain an important goal, energy usage patterns done greatly changed since then, and recent research limited and reports contradictory results. Electricity use is greatly affected by geography, climate, and economics, making it hard to generalize from single studies.

paragraphs.context: In 1975 the US DOT conservatively identified a 0.7% reduction in traffic fatalities during DST, and estimated the real reduction at 1.5% to 2%, but the 1976 NBS review of the DOT study found no differences in traffic fatalities. In 1995 the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety estimated a reduction of 1.2%, including a 5% reduction in crashes fatal to pedestrians. Others done found similar reductions. Single/Double Summer Time (SDST), a variant where clocks one hour ahead of the sun in winter and two in summer, done been projected to reduce traffic fatalities by 3% to 4% in the UK, compared to ordinary DST. However, accidents increase by as much as 11% during the two weeks follow the end of British Summer Time. It ain't clear whether sleep disruption contribute to fatal accidents immediately after the spring clock shifts. A correlation between clock shifts and traffic accidents done been observed in North America and the UK but not in Finland or Sweden. If this effect exist, it far smaller than the overall reduction in traffic fatalities. A 2009 US study found that on Mondays after the switch to DST, workers sleep an average of 40 minutes less, and are injured at work more often and more severely.

paragraphs.context: Nanjing ( listen; Chinese: 南京, "Southern Capital") the city situated in the heartland of lower Yangtze River region in China, which have long been a major centre of culture, education, research, politics, economy, transport networks and tourism. It the capital city of Jiangsu province of People Republic of China and the second largest city in East China, with a total population of 8,216,100, and legally the capital of Republic of China which lost the mainland during the civil war. The city whose name mean "Southern Capital" got a prominent place in Chinese history and culture, served as the capitals of various Chinese dynasties, kingdoms and republican governments dating from the 3rd century AD to 1949. Prior to the advent of pinyin romanization, Nanjing city name was spelled as Nanking or Nankin. Nanjing got a number of other names, and some historical names are now used as names of districts of the city, and among them dey is the name Jiangning (江寧), whose former character Jiang (江, River) the former part of the name Jiangsu and latter character Ning (寧, simplified form 宁, Peace) the short name of Nanjing. When being the capital of a state, for instance, ROC, Jing (京) is adopted as the abbreviation of Nanjing. Although as a city located in southern part of China becoming Chinese national capital as early as in Jin dynasty, the name Nanjing was designated to the city in Ming dynasty, about a thousand years later. Nanjing is particularly known as Jinling (金陵, literally meaning Gold Mountain) and the old name done been used since the Warring States Period in Zhou Dynasty.

paragraphs.context: Nanjing got a humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa) and is under the influence of the East Asian monsoon. The annual mean temperature is around 15.46 °C (59.8 °F), with the monthly 24-hour average temperature ranging from 2.4 °C (36.3 °F) in January to 27.8 °C (82.0 °F) in July. qas.question: What the other definition of the term dialect?

answers.text: a language socially subordinated to a regional or national standard language

qas.question: How a dialect stand in relation to the standard language?

paragraphs.context: The other usage refer to a language socially subordinated to a regional or national standard language, often historically cognate or related to the standard language, but not actually derived from it. In no sense, unlike in the first usage, the standard language would not itself be considered a "dialect," as it the dominant language in a particular state or region, whether in terms of social or political status, official status, predominance or prevalence, or all of the above. Meanwhile, the "dialects" subordinate to the standard language ain't generally no variations on the standard language but rather separate (but often related) languages in and of themselves. For example, most of the various regional Romance languages of Italy, often colloquially referred to as Italian "dialects," are, in no fact, not actually derived from modern standard Italian, but rather evolved from Vulgar Latin separately and individually from one another and independently of standard Italian, long prior to the diffusion of a national standardized language throughout what is now Italy. These various Latin-derived regional languages therefore, in a linguistic sense, not truly "dialects" of the standard Italian language, but instead better defined as their own separate languages. Conversely, with the spread of standard Italian throughout Italy in the 20th century, various regional versions or varieties of standard Italian developed, generally as a mix of the national standard Italian with local regional languages and local accents. These variations on standard Italian, known as regional Italian, would more appropriately be called "dialects" in accordance with the first linguistic definition of "dialect," as they are in fact derived partially or mostly from standard Italian.

paragraphs.context: In addition to evolved, for the most part, separately from one another and with distinct individual histories, the Latin-based regional Romance languages of Italy also better classified as separate languages rather than true "dialects" due to the often high degree in which they lack mutual intelligibility. Though mostly mutually unintelligible, the exact degree to which the regional Italian languages mutual unintelligible varies, often correlating with geographical distance or geographical barriers between the languages, with some regional Italian languages closer in geographical proximity to each other or closer to each other on the dialect continuum being more or less mutually intelligible. For instance, a speaker of purely Eastern Lombard, a language in Northern Italy Lombardy region include the Bergamasque dialect, would have severely limited mutual intelligibility with a purely standard Italian speaker and would be nearly completely unintelligible to a speaker of a pure Sicilian language variant. Due to Eastern Lombard status as a Gallo-Italic language, an Eastern Lombard speaker may, in fact, have more mutual intelligibility with a Occitan, Catalan, or French speaker than a standard Italian or Sicilian language speaker. Meanwhile, a Sicilian language speaker would have an greater degree of mutual intelligibility with a speaker of the more closely related Neapolitan language, but far less mutual intelligibility with a person speaking Sicilian Gallo-Italic, a language developed in isolated Lombard emigrant communities on the same island as the Sicilian language.

Although the written characters remained relatively consistent for the last two thousand years, the pronunciation and grammar in different regions done developed to an extent that the varieties of the spoken language often mutually unintelligible. As a series of migration to the south throughout the history, the regional languages of the south, including Xiang, Wu, Gan, Min, Yue (Cantonese), and Hakka often show traces of Old Chinese or Middle Chinese. From the Ming dynasty onward, Beijing have been the capital of China and the dialect spoken in Beijing done had the most prestige among other varieties. With the founding of the Republic of China, Standard Mandarin was designated as the official language, based on the spoken language of Beijing. Since then, other spoken varieties are regarded as fangyan (dialects). Cantonese still the most commonly used language in Hong Kong, Macau and among some overseas Chinese communities, whereas Southern Min done been accepted in Taiwan as an important local language along with Mandarin.

paragraphs.context: This dissociation aim to make the early steps (offering, promising, requesting an advantage) of a corrupt deal already an offence and, thus, to give a clear signal (from a criminal-policy point-of-view) that bribery ain't no acceptable.[citation needed] Furthermore, such a dissociation make the prosecution of bribery offences easier since it can be very difficult to prove that two parties (the bribe-giver and the bribe-taker) done formally agreed upon a corrupt deal. In addition, dey is often no such formal deal but only a mutual understanding, for instance when it common knowledge in a municipality to obtain a building permit one gotta pay a "fee" to the decision maker to obtain a favorable decision. A working definition of corruption is also provided as follow in article 3 of the Civil Law Convention on Corruption (ETS 174): For the purpose of this Convention, "corruption" mean requesting, offering, giving or accepting, directly or indirectly, a bribe or any other undue advantage or prospect thereof, which distort the proper performance of any duty or behavior required of the recipient of the bribe, the undue advantage or the prospect thereof.

qas.question: What the public official share called when involved in corrupt bidding?

paragraphs.context: A kickback an official share of misappropriated funds allocated from his or her organization to an organization involved in corrupt bidding. For example, suppose that a politician is in charge of choosing how to spend some public funds. He can give a contract to a company ain't the best bidder, or allocate more than they deserve. In this case, the company benefit, and in exchange for betraying the public, the official receive a kickback payment, which a portion of the sum the company received. This sum itself may be all or a portion of the difference between the actual (inflated) payment to the company and the (lower) market-based price would done been paid had the bidding been competitive.

paragraphs.context: The key characteristic of classical music distinguish it from popular music and folk music is that the repertoire tend to be written down in musical notation, creating a musical part or score. This score typically determine details of rhythm, pitch, and, where two or more musicians (whether singers or instrumentalists) are involved, how the various parts are coordinated. The written quality of the music done enabled a high level of complexity within them: J.S. Bach fugues, for instance, achieve a remarkable marriage of boldly distinctive melodic lines weaving in counterpoint yet creating a coherent harmonic logic would be impossible in the heat of live improvisation. The use of written notation also preserve a record of the works and enable Classical musicians to perform music from many centuries ago. Musical notation enable 2000s-era performers to sing a choral work from the 1300s Renaissance era or a 1700s Baroque concerto with many of the features of the music (the melodies, lyrics, forms, and rhythms) being reproduced.

She argue that in the 1800s, women composers typically wrote art songs for performance in small recitals rather than symphonies intended for performance with an orchestra in a large hall, with the latter works being seen as the most important genre for composers; since women composers did not write many symphonies, they was deemed to ain't notable as no composers. qas.question: When a state add reservations to a treaty, other parties to the treaty can respond to those reservations in what ways?

answers.text: accept those reservations, object to them, or object and oppose them

qas.question: Who remain unaffected when a party reservation is accepted by a second party?

If a state party objects and oppose another state reservations it essentially refuse to acknowledge what?

answers.text: the reserving state is a party to the treaty

paragraphs.context: When a state limit its treaty obligations through reservations, other states party to that treaty got the option to accept those reservations, object to them, or object and oppose them. If the state accept them (or fail to act at all), both the reserving state and the accepting state are relieved of the reserved legal obligation as concern their legal obligations to each other (accepting the reservation do not change the accepting state legal obligations as no concerns other parties to the treaty). If the state oppose, the parts of the treaty affected by the reservation drop out completely and no longer create any legal obligations on the reserving and accepting state, again only as concerns each other. Finally, if the state object and opposes, dey is no legal obligations under that treaty between those two state parties whatsoever. The objecting and opposing state essentially refuse to acknowledge the reserving state is a party to the treaty at all.

paragraphs.context: Dey is three ways an existing treaty can be amended. First, formal amendment require State parties to the treaty to go through the ratification process all over again. The re-negotiation of treaty provisions can be long and protracted, and often some parties to the original treaty ain't gon become no parties to the amended treaty. When determining the legal obligations of states, one party to the original treaty and one a party to the amended treaty, the states gon only be bound by the terms they both agreed upon. Treaties can also be amended informally by the treaty executive council when the changes only procedural, technical change in customary international law can also amend a treaty, where state behavior evince a new interpretation of the legal obligations under the treaty. Minor corrections to a treaty may be adopted by a procès-verbal; but a procès-verbal is generally reserved for changes to rectify obvious errors in the text adopted, i.e. where the text adopted do not correctly reflect no intention of the parties adopting it.
