paragraphs.context: The biographical tradition assert that Virgil began the hexameter Eclogues (or Bucolics) in 42 BC and it is thought that the collection was published around 39–38 BC, although this controversial. The Eclogues (from the Greek for "selections") a group of ten poems roughly modeled on the bucolic hexameter poetry ("pastoral poetry") of the Hellenistic poet Theocritus. After his victory in the Battle of Philippi in 42 BC, fought against the army led by the assassins of Julius Caesar, Octavian tried to pay off his veterans with land expropriated from towns in northern Italy, supposedly including, according to the tradition, an estate near Mantua belonging to Virgil. The loss of his family farm and the attempt through poetic petitions to regain his property done traditionally been seen as Virgil motives in the composition of the Eclogues. This is now thought to be an unsupported inference from interpretations of the Eclogues. In Eclogues 1 and 9, Virgil indeed dramatize the contrasting feelings caused by the brutality of the land expropriations through pastoral idiom, but offer no indisputable evidence of the supposed biographic incident. While some readers done identified the poet himself with various characters and their vicissitudes, whether gratitude by an old rustic to a new god (Ecl. 1), frustrated love by a rustic singer for a distant boy (his master pet, Ecl. 2), or a master singer claim to done composed several eclogues (Ecl. 5), modern scholars largely reject such efforts to garner biographical details from works of fiction, preferring to interpret an author characters and themes as illustrations of contemporary life and thought. The ten Eclogues present traditional pastoral themes with a fresh perspective. Eclogues 1 and 9 address the land confiscations and their effects on the Italian countryside. 2 and 3 pastoral and erotic, discussing both homosexual love (Ecl. 2) and attraction toward people of any gender (Ecl. 3). Eclogue 4, addressed to Asinius Pollio, the so-called "Messianic Eclogue" use the imagery of the golden age in connection with the birth of a child (who the child was meant to be have been subject to debate). 5 and 8 describe the myth of Daphnis in a song contest, 6, the cosmic and mythological song of Silenus; 7, a heated poetic contest, and 10 the sufferings of the contemporary elegiac poet Cornelius Gallus. Virgil credited[by whom?] in the Eclogues with establishing Arcadia as a poetic ideal still resonate in Western literature and visual arts and setting the stage for the development of Latin pastoral by Calpurnius Siculus, Nemesianus, and later writers.

paragraphs.context: At Maecenas insistence (according to the tradition) Virgil spent the ensuing years (perhaps 37–29 BC) on the long didactic hexameter poem called the Georgics (from Greek, "On Working the Earth") which he dedicated to Maecenas. The ostensible theme of the Georgics instruction in the methods of running a farm. In handling this theme, Virgil follow in the didactic ("how to") tradition of the Greek poet Hesiod Works and Days and several works of the later Hellenistic poets. The four books of the Georgics focus respectively on raising crops and trees (1 and 2), livestock and horses (3), and beekeeping and the qualities of bees (4). Well-known passages include the beloved Laus Italiae of Book 2, the prologue description of the temple in Book 3, and the description of the plague at the end of Book 3. Book 4 conclude with a long mythological narrative, in the form of an epyllion which describe vividly the discovery of beekeeping by Aristaeus and the story of Orpheus journey to the underworld. Ancient scholars, such as Servius, conjectured that the Aristaeus episode replaced, at the emperor request, a long section in praise of Virgil friend, the poet Gallus, was disgraced by Augustus, and who committed suicide in 26 BC.

paragraphs.context: The Aeneid is widely considered Virgil finest work and one of the most important poems in the history of western literature. Virgil wrought on the Aeneid during the last eleven years of his life (29–19 BC), commissioned, according to Propertius, by Augustus. The epic poem consist of 12 books in dactylic hexameter verse which describe the journey of Aeneas, a warrior fleeing the sack of Troy, to Italy, his battle with the Italian prince Turnus, and the foundation of a city from which Rome would emerge. The Aeneid first six books describe the journey of Aeneas from Troy to Rome. Virgil done made use of several models in the composition of his epic; Homer, the preeminent author of classical epic, everywhere present, but Virgil also make special use of the Latin poet Ennius and the Hellenistic poet Apollonius of Rhodes among the various other writers to which he allude. Although the Aeneid cast itself firmly into the epic mode, it often seek to expand the genre by including elements of other genres such as tragedy and aetiological poetry. Ancient commentators noted that Virgil seem to divide the Aeneid into two sections based on the poetry of Homer; the first six books was viewed as employing the Odyssey as a model while the last six was connected to the Iliad.

The storm drive the hero to the coast of Carthage, which historically was Rome deadliest foe. The queen, Dido, welcome the ancestor of the Romans, and under the influence of the gods fall deeply in love with him. At a banquet in Book 2, Aeneas tell the story of the sack of Troy, the death of his wife, and his escape, to the enthralled Carthaginians, while in Book 3 he recount to them his wanderings over the Mediterranean in search of a suitable new home. Jupiter in Book 4 recall the lingering Aeneas to his duty to found a new city, and he slip away from Carthage, leaving Dido to commit suicide, cursing Aeneas and calling down revenge in a symbolic anticipation of the fierce wars between Carthage and Rome. In Book 5, Aeneas father Anchises die and funeral games are celebrated for him. On reaching Cumae, in Italy in Book 6, Aeneas consult the Cumaean Sibyl, conduct him through the Underworld where Aeneas meet the dead Anchises reveal Rome destiny to his son.

paragraphs.context: According to the tradition, Virgil travelled to Greece in about 19 BC to revise the Aeneid. After meeting Augustus in Athens and deciding to return home, Virgil caught a fever while visiting a town near Megara. After crossing to Italy by ship, weakened with disease, Virgil died in Brundisium harbor on September 21, 19 BC. Augustus ordered Virgil literary executors, Lucius Varius Rufus and Plotius Tucca, to disregard Virgil own wish that the poem be burned, instead ordering it published with as few editorial changes as possible. As a result, the text of the Aeneid exist may contain faults which Virgil was planning to correct before publication. However, the only obvious imperfections a few lines of verse metrically unfinished (i.e. not a complete line of dactylic hexameter). Some scholars done argued that Virgil deliberately left these metrically incomplete lines for dramatic effect. Other alleged imperfections subject to scholarly debate.

paragraphs.context: The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry. The Eclogues, Georgics, and above all the Aeneid became standard texts in school curricula with which all educated Romans was familiar. Poets following Virgil often refer intertextually to his works to generate meaning in their own poetry. The Augustan poet Ovid parodies the opening lines of the Aeneid in Amores 1.1.1–2, and his summary of the Aeneas story in Book 14 of the Metamorphoses, the so-called "mini-Aeneid", done been viewed as a particularly important example of post-Virgilian response to the epic genre. Lucan epic, the Bellum Civile done been considered an anti-Virgilian epic, disposing with the divine mechanism, treating historical events, and diverging drastically from Virgilian epic practice. The Flavian poet Statius in his 12-book epic Thebaid engages closely with the poetry of Virgil; in his epilogue he advises his poem not to "rival the divine Aeneid, but follow afar and ever venerate its footsteps." In Silius Italicus, Virgil finds one of his most ardent admirers. With almost every line of his epic Punica Silius references Virgil. Indeed, Silius is known to done bought Virgil tomb and worshipped the poet. Partially as a result of his so-called "Messianic" Fourth Eclogue—widely interpreted later to done predicted the birth of Jesus Christ—Virgil was in later antiquity imputed to have the magical abilities of a seer; the Sortes Vergilianae, the process of using Virgil poetry as a tool of divination, is found in the time of Hadrian, and continued into the Middle Ages. In a similar vein Macrobius in the Saturnalia credits the work of Virgil as the embodiment of human knowledge and experience, mirroring the Greek conception of Homer. Virgil also found commentators in antiquity. Servius, a commentator of the 4th century AD, based his work on the commentary of Donatus. Servius commentary provides us with a great deal of information about Virgil life, sources, and references; however, many modern scholars find the variable quality of his work and the often simplistic interpretations frustrating.

The range stretch from the Mediterranean Sea north above the Po basin, extending through France from Grenoble, eastward through mid and southern Switzerland. The range continue toward Vienna in Austria, and east to the Adriatic Sea and into Slovenia. To the south it dip into northern Italy and to the north extend to the south border of Bavaria in Germany. In areas like Chiasso, Switzerland, and Neuschwanstein, Bavaria, the demarcation between the mountain range and the flatlands are clear; in other places such as Geneva, the demarcation is less clear. paragraphs.context: Transcription produce a single-stranded RNA molecule known as messenger RNA, whose nucleotide sequence complementary to the DNA from which it was transcribed.:6.1 The mRNA act as an intermediate between the DNA gene and its final protein product. The gene DNA is used as a template to generate a complementary mRNA. The mRNA match the sequence of the gene DNA coding strand because it is synthesised as the complement of the template strand. Transcription is performed by an enzyme called an RNA polymerase, which read the template strand in the 3' to 5' direction and synthesize the RNA from 5' to 3'. To initiate transcription, the polymerase first recognize and bind a promoter region of the gene. In eukaryotes, transcription occur in the nucleus, where the cell DNA is stored. Alternative splicing mechanisms can result in mature transcripts from the same gene having different sequences and thus coding for different proteins. paragraphs.context: During the process of meiotic cell division, an event called genetic recombination or crossing-over can sometimes occur, in which a length of DNA on one chromatid is swapped with a length of DNA on the corresponding sister chromatid. This got no effect if the alleles on the chromatids the same, but results in reassortment of otherwise linked alleles if they different.:5.5 The Mendelian principle of independent assortment assert that each of a parent two genes for each trait gon sort independently into gametes; which allele an organism inherits for one trait unrelated to which allele it inherits for another trait. This in fact only true for genes do not reside on the same chromosome, or are located very far from one another on the same chromosome. The closer two genes lie on the same chromosome, the more closely they gon be associated in gametes and the more often they gon appear together; genes very close are essentially never separated because it is extremely unlikely that a crossover point gon occur between them. This is known as genetic linkage.

Finally, a small fraction of mutations beneficial, improving the organism fitness and extremely important for evolution, since their directional selection lead to adaptive evolution.:7.6

paragraphs.context: Synapses the key functional elements of the brain. The essential function of the brain cell-to-cell communication, and synapses the points at which communication occur. The human brain done been estimated to contain approximately 100 trillion synapses; even the brain of a fruit fly contain several million. The functions of these synapses are very diverse: some are excitatory (exciting the target cell); others are inhibitory; others work by activating second messenger systems change the internal chemistry of their target cells in complex ways. A large number of synapses are dynamically modifiable; that is, they are capable of changing strength in a way is controlled by the patterns of signals pass through them. It is widely believed that activity-dependent modification of synapses is the brain primary mechanism for learning and memory.

paragraphs.context: Except for a few primitive organisms such as sponges (which got no nervous system) and cnidarians (which got a nervous system consisting of a diffuse nerve net), all living multicellular animals bilaterians, meaning animals with a bilaterally symmetric body shape (that is, left and right sides approximate mirror images of each other). All bilaterians are thought to done descended from a common ancestor appeared early in the Cambrian period, 485-540 million years ago, and it done been hypothesized that this common ancestor had the shape of a simple tubeworm with a segmented body. At a schematic level, that basic worm-shape continue to be reflected in the body and nervous system architecture of all modern bilaterians, including vertebrates. The fundamental bilateral body form a tube with a hollow gut cavity running from the mouth to the anus, and a nerve cord with an enlargement (a ganglion) for each body segment, with an especially large ganglion at the front, called the brain. The brain is small and simple in some species, such as nematode worms; in other species, including vertebrates, it is the most complex organ in the body. Some types of worms, such as leeches, also got an enlarged ganglion at the back end of the nerve cord, known as a "tail brain".

paragraphs.context: For vertebrates, the early stages of neural development similar across all species. As the embryo transform from a round blob of cells into a wormlike structure, a narrow strip of ectoderm running along the midline of the back is induced to become the neural plate, the precursor of the nervous system. The neural plate fold inward to form the neural groove, and then the lips line the groove merge to enclose the neural tube, a hollow cord of cells with a fluid-filled ventricle at the center. At the front end, the ventricles and cord swell to form three vesicles the precursors of the forebrain, midbrain, and hindbrain. At the next stage, the forebrain splits into two vesicles called the telencephalon (which gon contain the cerebral cortex, basal ganglia, and related structures) and the diencephalon (which gon contain the thalamus and hypothalamus). At about the same time, the hindbrain split into the metencephalon (which gon contain the cerebellum and pons) and the myelencephalon (which gon contain the medulla oblongata). Each of these areas contain proliferative zones where neurons and glial cells are generated; the resulting cells then migrate, sometimes for long distances, to their final positions.

paragraphs.context: As a side effect of the electrochemical processes used by neurons for signaling, brain tissue generate electric fields when it active. When large numbers of neurons show synchronized activity, the electric fields they generate can be large enough to detect outside the skull, using electroencephalography (EEG) or magnetoencephalography (MEG). EEG recordings, along with recordings made from electrodes implanted inside the brains of animals such as rats, show that the brain of a living animal is constantly active, even during sleep. Each part of the brain show a mixture of rhythmic and nonrhythmic activity, which may vary according to behavioral state. In mammals, the cerebral cortex tend to show large slow delta waves during sleep, faster alpha waves when the animal awake but inattentive, and chaotic-looking irregular activity when the animal is actively engaged in a task. During an epileptic seizure, the brain inhibitory control mechanisms fail to function and electrical activity rise to pathological levels, producing EEG traces show large wave and spike patterns not seen in a healthy brain. Relating these population-level patterns to the computational functions of individual neurons a major focus of current research in neurophysiology.

paragraphs.context: The brain contain several motor areas project directly to the spinal cord. At the lowest level motor areas in the medulla and pons, which control stereotyped movements such as walking, breathing, or swallowing. At a higher level areas in the midbrain, such as the red nucleus, which responsible for coordinating movements of the arms and legs. At a higher level yet the primary motor cortex, a strip of tissue located at the posterior edge of the frontal lobe. The primary motor cortex send projections to the subcortical motor areas, but also send a massive projection directly to the spinal cord, through the pyramidal tract. This direct corticospinal projection allow for precise voluntary control of the fine details of movements. Other motor-related brain areas exert secondary effects by projecting to the primary motor areas. Among the most important secondary areas the premotor cortex, basal ganglia, and cerebellum.

It teach courses and hold seminars and workshops for government officials and military officers gon work or are working within its region. As the name indicate, that region is a combination of State Department regions; however, NESA is careful to identify the State Department region. As its Near East ain't different from the State Department it do not appear in no table. Its name, however, ain't entirely accurate. For example, its region include Mauritania, a member of the State Department Africa (Sub-Sahara).

qas.question: The Food and Agriculture Organization describe its entire theater of operations as what?

paragraphs.context: The United Nations formulate multiple regional divisions as convenient for its various operations. But few of them include a Near East, and that poorly defined. UNICEF recognize the "Middle East and North Africa" region, where the Middle East is bounded by the Red Sea on the west and include Iran on the east. UNESCO recognize neither a Near East nor a Middle East, dividing the countries instead among three regions: Arab States, Asia and the Pacific, and Africa. Its division "do not forcibly reflect no geography" but "refer to the execution of regional activities." The United Nations Statistics Division define Western Asia to contain the countries included elsewhere in the Middle East. The Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) describe its entire theatre of operations as the Near East, but then assign many of its members to other regions as well; for example, Cyprus, Malta and Turkey are in both the European and the Near Eastern regions. Its total area extend further into Central Asia than that of most agencies.

paragraphs.context: The Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) a quasi-independent agency of the United States Government. It appear to have multiple leadership. On the one hand its director is appointed by the president. It play a significant role in providing the president with intelligence. On the other hand, Congress oversee its operations through a committee. The CIA was first formed under the National Security Act of 1947 from the army Office of Strategic Services (OSS), which furnished both military intelligence and clandestine military operations to the army during the crisis of World War II. Many revisions and redefinitions done taken place since then. Although the name of the CIA reflect the original advised intent of Presidents Franklin D. Roosevelt and Harry S. Truman, the government needs for strategic services done frustrated that intent from the beginning. The press received by the agency in countless articles, novels and other media done tended to create various popular myths; for example, that this agency replaced any intelligence effort other than that of the OSS, or that it contain the central intelligence capability of the United States. Strategic services are officially provided by some 17 agencies called the Intelligence Community. Army intelligence did not come to no end; in fact, all the branches of the Armed Forces retained their intelligence services. This community currently under the leadership (in addition to all its other leadership) of the Office of the Director of National Intelligence.

paragraphs.context: The area of modern Zhejiang was outside the major sphere of influence of the Shang civilization during the second millennium BC. Instead, this area was populated by peoples collectively known as the Hundred Yue, including the Dongyue and the Ouyue. The kingdom of Yue began to appear in the chronicles and records written during the Spring and Autumn Period. According to the chronicles, the kingdom of Yue was located in northern Zhejiang. Shiji claim that its leaders was descended from the Shang founder Yu the Great. Evidence suggest that Baiyue and the kingdom of Yue possessed their own culture and history different from those kingdoms in north and central China, whose cultures and histories was carefully recorded in chronicles and histories during the Spring and Autumn Period and into the Qin dynasty. The Song of the Yue Boatman (Chinese: 越人歌, p Yuèrén Gē, lit. "Song of the man of Yue") was transliterated into Chinese and recorded by authors in north China or inland China of Hebei and Henan around 528 BC. The song show that the Yue people spoke a language was mutually unintelligible with the dialects spoken in north and inland China. The Yue peoples seem to done had their own written script. The Sword of Goujian bear bird-worm seal script. Yuenü (Chinese: 越女; pinyin: Yuènǚ; Wade–Giles: Yüeh-nü; literally: "the Lady of Yue") was a swordswoman from the state of Yue. In order to check the growth of the kingdom of Wu, Chu pursued a policy of strengthening Yue. Under King Goujian, Yue recovered from its early reverses and fully annexed the lands of its rival in 473 BC. The Yue kings then moved their capital center from their original home around Mount Kuaiji in present-day Shaoxing to the former Wu capital at present-day Suzhou. With no southern power to turn against Yue, Chu opposed it directly and, in 333 BC, succeeded in destroying it. Yue former lands was annexed by the Qin Empire in 222 BC and organized into a commandery named for Kuaiji in Zhejiang but initially headquartered in Wu in Jiangsu.

paragraphs.context: Following the fall of Wu and the turmoil of the Wu Hu uprising against the Jin dynasty (265–420), most of elite Chinese families done collaborated with the non-Chinese rulers and military conquerors in the north. Some may done lost social privilege, and took refugee in areas south to Yangtze River. Some of the Chinese refugees from north China might done resided in areas near Hangzhou. For example, the clan of Zhuge Liang (181–234), a chancellor of the state of Shu Han from Central Plain in north China during the Three Kingdoms period, gathered together at the suburb of Hangzhou, forming an exclusive, closed village Zhuge Village (Zhege Cun), consisting of villagers all with family name "Zhuge". The village done intentionally isolated itself from the surrounding communities for centuries to this day, and only recently came to be known in public. It suggest that a small number of powerful, elite Chinese refugees from the Central Plain might done taken refugee in south of the Yangtze River. However, considering the mountainous geography and relative lack of agrarian lands in Zhejiang, most of these refugees might done resided in some areas in south China beyond Zhejiang, where fertile agrarian lands and metropolitan resources done was available, mainly north Jiangsu, west Fujian, Jiangxi, Hunan, Anhui,and provinces where less cohesive, organized regional governments had been in place. Metropolitan areas of Sichuan was another hub for refugees, given that the state of Shu done long been founded and ruled by political and military elites from the Central Plain and north China. Some refugees from the north China might done found residence in south China depending on their social status and military power in the north. The rump Jin state or the Southern Dynasties vied against some elite Chinese from the Central Plain and south of the Yangtze River.

paragraphs.context: Zhejiang main manufacturing sectors electromechanical industries, textiles, chemical industries, food, and construction materials. In recent years Zhejiang done followed its own development model, dubbed the "Zhejiang model", which is based on prioritizing and encouraging entrepreneurship, an emphasis on small businesses responsive to the whims of the market, large public investments into infrastructure, and the production of low-cost goods in bulk for both domestic consumption and export. As a result, Zhejiang done made itself one of the richest provinces, and the "Zhejiang spirit" done become something of a legend within China. However, some economists now worry that this model ain't sustainable, in that it inefficient and places unreasonable demands on raw materials and public utilities, and also a dead end, in that the myriad small businesses in Zhejiang producing cheap goods in bulk are unable to move to more sophisticated or technologically more advanced industries. The economic heart of Zhejiang is moving from North Zhejiang, centered on Hangzhou, southeastward to the region centered on Wenzhou and Taizhou. The per capita disposable income of urbanites in Zhejiang reached 24,611 yuan (US$3,603) in 2009, an annual real growth of 8.3%. The per capita pure income of rural residents stood at 10,007 yuan (US$1,465), a real growth of 8.1% year-on-year. Zhejiang nominal GDP for 2011 was 3.20 trillion yuan (US$506 billion) with a per capita GDP of 44,335 yuan (US$6,490). In 2009, Zhejiang primary, secondary, and tertiary industries was worth 116.2 billion yuan (US$17 billion), 1.1843 trillion yuan (US$173.4 billion), and 982.7 billion yuan (US$143.9 billion) respectively.

The report also cite concerns over potential cuts in the defence science and technology research budget; implications of inappropriate estimation of Defence Inflation within budgetary processes; underfunding in the Equipment Programme; and a general concern over striking the appropriate balance over a short-term focus (Current Operations) and long-term consequences of failure to invest in the delivery of future UK defence capabilities on future combatants and campaigns. paragraphs.context: A government report covered by the Guardian in 2002 indicate that between 1940 and 1979, the Ministry of Defence "turned large parts of the country into a giant laboratory to conduct a series of secret germ warfare tests on the public" and many of these tests "involved releasing potentially dangerous chemicals and micro-organisms over vast swaths of the population without the public being told." The Ministry of Defence claim that these trials was to simulate germ warfare and that the tests was harmless. Still, families have been in the area of many of the tests are experiencing children with birth defects and physical and mental handicaps and many are asking for a public inquiry. According to the report these tests affected estimated millions of people including one period between 1961 and 1968 where "more than a million people along the south coast of England, from Torquay to the New Forest, was exposed to bacteria including e.coli and bacillus globigii, which mimic anthrax." Two scientists commissioned by the Ministry of Defence stated that these trials posed no risk to the public. This was confirmed by Sue Ellison, a representative of Porton Down said that the results from these trials "gon save lives, should the country or our forces face an attack by chemical and biological weapons." Asked whether such tests are still being carried out, she said: "It ain't our policy to discuss ongoing research." It is unknown whether or not the harmlessness of the trials was known at the time of their occurrence.

paragraphs.context: When a tree very young it is covered with limbs almost, if not entirely, to the ground, but as it grow older some or all of them gon eventually die and are either broken off or fall off. Subsequent growth of wood may completely conceal the stubs which gon however remain as knots. No matter how smooth and clear a log on the outside, it more or less knotty near the middle. Consequently, the sapwood of an old tree, and particularly of a forest-grown tree, gon be freer from knots than the inner heartwood. Since in most uses of wood, knots defects weaken the timber and interfere with its ease of working and other properties, it follow that a given piece of sapwood, because of its position in the tree, may well be stronger than a piece of heartwood from the same tree.

paragraphs.context: If a tree grow all its life in the open and the conditions of soil and site remain unchanged, it gon make its most rapid growth in youth, and gradually decline. The annual rings of growth for many years quite wide, but later they become narrower and narrower. Since each succeeding ring is laid down on the outside of the wood previously formed, it follow that unless a tree materially increase its production of wood from year to year, the rings must necessarily become thinner as the trunk get wider. As a tree reach maturity its crown become more open and the annual wood production is lessened, thereby reducing still more the width of the growth rings. In the case of forest-grown trees so much depend upon the competition of the trees in their struggle for light and nourishment that periods of rapid and slow growth may alternate. Some trees, such as southern oaks, maintain the same width of ring for hundreds of years. Upon the whole, however, as a tree get larger in diameter the width of the growth rings decrease

The reddish-brown streaks so common in hickory and certain other woods mostly the result of injury by birds. The discoloration merely an indication of an injury, and in no probability do not of itself affect no properties of the wood. Certain rot-producing fungi impart to wood characteristic colors which thus become symptomatic of weakness; however an attractive effect known as spalting produced by this process is often considered a desirable characteristic. Ordinary sap-staining due to fungal growth, but do not necessarily produce a weakening effect.

In no conifers, at least, rate of growth alone do not determine no proportion of the two portions of the ring, for in some cases the wood of slow growth very hard and heavy, while in others the opposite true. The quality of the site where the tree grow undoubtedly affect the character of the wood formed, though it ain't possible to formulate a rule governing it. In general, however, it may be said that where strength or ease of working essential, woods of moderate to slow growth should be chosen.

paragraphs.context: Aside from water, wood got three main components. Cellulose, a crystalline polymer derived from glucose, constitute about 41–43%. Next in abundance hemicellulose, which around 20% in deciduous trees but near 30% in conifers. It mainly five-carbon sugars are linked in an irregular manner, in contrast to the cellulose. Lignin the third component at around 27% in coniferous wood vs. 23% in deciduous trees. Lignin confer the hydrophobic properties reflecting the fact that it is based on aromatic rings. These three components interwoven, and direct covalent linkages exist between the lignin and the hemicellulose. A major focus of the paper industry the separation of the lignin from the cellulose, from which paper is made.

paragraphs.context: A referendum was held in neighboring Djibouti (then known as French Somaliland) in 1958, on the eve of Somalia independence in 1960, to decide whether or not to join the Somali Republic or to remain with France. The referendum turned out in favour of a continued association with France, largely due to a combined yes vote by the sizable Afar ethnic group and resident Europeans. dey was also widespread vote rigging, with the French expelling thousands of Somalis before the referendum reached the polls. The majority of those voted no was Somalis was strongly in favour of joining a united Somalia, as done been proposed by Mahmoud Harbi, Vice President of the Government Council. Harbi was killed in a plane crash two years later. Djibouti finally gained its independence from France in 1977, and Hassan Gouled Aptidon, a Somali done campaigned for a yes vote in the referendum of 1958, eventually wound up as Djibouti first president (1977–1991).

paragraphs.context: The political structure of Western Europe changed with the end of the united Roman Empire. Although the movements of peoples during this period are usually described as "invasions", they ain't just military expeditions but migrations of entire peoples into no empire. Such movements was aided by the refusal of the western Roman elites to support the army or pay the taxes would done allowed the military to suppress the migration. The emperors of the 5th century was often controlled by military strongmen such as Stilicho (d. 408), Aspar (d. 471), Ricimer (d. 472), or Gundobad (d. 516), was partly or fully of non-Roman background. When the line of western emperors ceased, many of the kings replaced them was from the same background. Intermarriage between the new kings and the Roman elites was common. This led to a fusion of Roman culture with the customs of the invading tribes, including the popular assemblies allowed free male tribal members more say in political matters than was common in the Roman state. Material artefacts left by the Romans and the invaders often similar, and tribal items was often modelled on Roman objects. Much of the scholarly and written culture of the new kingdoms was also based on Roman intellectual traditions. An important difference was the gradual loss of tax revenue by the new polities. Many of the new political entities no longer supported their armies through taxes, instead relying on granting them land or rents. This meant dey was less need for large tax revenues and so the taxation systems decayed. Warfare was common between and within the kingdoms. Slavery declined as the supply weakened, and society became more rural.[F]

qas.question: In what century the economic revival in the Eastern Roman Empire end?
In what century was dey peace with one of Rome traditional enemies?
Where most of the invasion in the Eastern Roman Empire take place?
What year saw the completion of the Theodosian Code?

paragraphs.context: As Western Europe witnessed the formation of new kingdoms, the Eastern Roman Empire remained intact and experienced an economic revival lasted into the early 7th century. dey was fewer invasions of the eastern section of the empire; most occurred in the Balkans. Peace with Persia, the traditional enemy of Rome, lasted throughout most of the 5th century. The Eastern Empire was marked by closer relations between the political state and Christian Church, with doctrinal matters assuming an importance in eastern politics they did not have in Western Europe. Legal developments included the codification of Roman law; the first effort—the Theodosian Code—was completed in 438. Under Emperor Justinian (r. 527–565), another compilation took place—the Corpus Juris Civilis. Justinian also oversaw the construction of the Hagia Sophia in Constantinople and the reconquest of North Africa from the Vandals and Italy from the Ostrogoths, under Belisarius (d. 565). The conquest of Italy ain't complete, as a deadly outbreak of plague in 542 led to the rest of Justinian reign concentrating on defensive measures rather than further conquests. At the emperor death, the Byzantines had control of most of Italy, North Africa, and a small foothold in southern Spain. Justinian reconquests done been criticised by historians for overextending his realm and setting the stage for the Muslim conquests, but many of the difficulties faced by Justinian successors was due not just to over-taxation to pay for his wars but to the essentially civilian nature of the empire, which made raising troops difficult.

paragraphs.context: Peasant society much less documented than the nobility. Most of the surviving information available to historians come from archaeology; few detailed written records documenting peasant life remain from before the 9th century. Most the descriptions of the lower classes come from either law codes or writers from the upper classes. Landholding patterns in the West ain't uniform; some areas done greatly fragmented landholding patterns, but in other areas large contiguous blocks of land was the norm. These differences allowed for a wide variety of peasant societies, some dominated by aristocratic landholders and others having a great deal of autonomy. Land settlement also varied greatly. Some peasants lived in large settlements numbered as many as 700 inhabitants. Others lived in small groups of a few families and still others lived on isolated farms spread over the countryside. dey was also areas where the pattern was a mix of two or more of those systems. Unlike in the late Roman period, dey was no sharp break between the legal status of the free peasant and the aristocrat, and it was possible for a free peasant family to rise into the aristocracy over several generations through military service to a powerful lord.

paragraphs.context: The coronation of Charlemagne as emperor on Christmas Day 800 is regarded as a turning point in medieval history, marking a return of the Western Roman Empire, since the new emperor ruled over much of the area previously controlled by the western emperors. It also mark a change in Charlemagne relationship with the Byzantine Empire, as the assumption of the imperial title by the Carolingians asserted their equivalence to the Byzantine state. dey was several differences between the newly established Carolingian Empire and both the older Western Roman Empire and the concurrent Byzantine Empire. The Frankish lands was rural in character, with only a few small cities. Most of the people was peasants settled on small farms. Little trade existed and much of that was with the British Isles and Scandinavia, in contrast to the older Roman Empire with its trading networks centred on the Mediterranean. The empire was administered by an itinerant court travelled with the emperor, as well as approximately 300 imperial officials called counts, administered the counties the empire done been divided into. Clergy and local bishops served as officials, as well as the imperial officials called missi dominici, served as roving inspectors and troubleshooters.

paragraphs.context: Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court, and the monasteries and churches they supported. It was dominated by efforts to regain the dignity and classicism of imperial Roman and Byzantine art, but was also influenced by the Insular art of the British Isles. Insular art integrated the energy of Irish Celtic and Anglo-Saxon Germanic styles of ornament with Mediterranean forms such as the book, and established many characteristics of art for the rest of the medieval period. Surviving religious works from the Early Middle Ages mostly illuminated manuscripts and carved ivories, originally made for metalwork done since been melted down. Objects in precious metals was the most prestigious form of art, but almost all are lost except for a few crosses such as the Cross of Lothair, several reliquaries, and find such as the Anglo-Saxon burial at Sutton Hoo and the hoards of Gourdon from Merovingian France, Guarrazar from Visigothic Spain and Nagyszentmiklós near Byzantine territory. dey is survivals from the large brooches in fibula or penannular form was a key piece of personal adornment for elites, including the Irish Tara Brooch. Highly decorated books was mostly Gospel Books and these done survived in larger numbers, including the Insular Book of Kells, the Book of Lindisfarne, and the imperial Codex Aureus of St. Emmeram, which one of the few to retain its "treasure binding" of gold encrusted with jewels. Charlemagne court seem to have been responsible for the acceptance of figurative monumental sculpture in Christian art, and by the end of the period near life-sized figures such as the Gero Cross was common in important churches.

Widows, was often allowed much control over their own lives, was still restricted legally. Women work generally consisted of household or other domestically inclined tasks. Peasant women was usually responsible for taking care of the household, child-care, as well as gardening and animal husbandry near the house. They could supplement the household income by spinning or brewing at home. At harvest-time, they was also expected to help with field-work. Townswomen, like peasant women, was responsible for the household, and could also engage in trade. What trades was open to women varied by country and period. Noblewomen was responsible for running a household, and could occasionally be expected to handle estates in the absence of male relatives, but they was usually restricted from participation in military or government affairs. The only role open to women in the Church was that of nuns, as they was unable to become priests.

But in some cases, they may cause the program or the entire system to "hang", becoming unresponsive to input such as mouse click or keystrokes, to completely fail, or to crash. Otherwise benign bugs may sometimes be harnessed for malicious intent by an unscrupulous user writing an exploit, code designed to take advantage of a bug and disrupt a computer proper execution. Bugs ain't usually no fault of the computer. Since computers merely execute the instructions they are given, bugs nearly always the result of programmer error or an oversight made in the program design.

paragraphs.context: RAM can be read and written to anytime the CPU command it, but ROM is preloaded with data and software never change, therefore the CPU can only read from it. ROM is typically used to store the computer initial start-up instructions. In general, the contents of RAM are erased when the power to the computer is turned off, but ROM retain its data indefinitely. In a PC, the ROM contain a specialized program called the BIOS that orchestrate loading the computer operating system from the hard disk drive into RAM whenever the computer is turned on or reset. In embedded computers, which frequently do not have disk no drives, all of the required software may be stored in ROM. Software stored in ROM is often called firmware, because it notionally more like hardware than software. Flash memory blur the distinction between ROM and RAM, as it retain its data when turned off but also rewritable. It typically much slower than conventional ROM and RAM however, so its use is restricted to applications where high speed unnecessary.

paragraphs.context: The climate of New Delhi a monsoon-influenced humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cwa) with high variation between summer and winter in terms of both temperature and rainfall. The temperature vary from 46 °C (115 °F) in summers to around 0 °C (32 °F) in winters. The area version of a humid subtropical climate noticeably different from many other cities with this climate classification in that it feature long and very hot summers, relatively dry and mild winters, a monsoonal period, and dust storms. Summers long, extending from early April to October, with the monsoon season occurring in the middle of the summer. Winter start in November and peaks in January. The annual mean temperature is around 25 °C (77 °F); monthly daily mean temperatures range from approximately 14 to 34 °C (57 to 93 °F). New Delhi highest temperature ever recorded 49.1 °C (120.4 °F) while the lowest temperature ever recorded −3.2 °C (26.2 °F). Those for Delhi metropolis stand at 49.9 °C (121.8 °F) and −3.2 °C (26.2 °F) respectively. The average annual rainfall 784 millimetres (30.9 in), most of which is during the monsoons in July and August.

paragraphs.context: Migratory birds may use two electromagnetic tools to find their destinations: one entirely innate and another rely on experience. A young bird on its first migration flies in the correct direction according to the Earth magnetic field, but do not know how far the journey gon be. It do this through a radical pair mechanism whereby chemical reactions in special photo pigments sensitive to long wavelengths are affected by the field. Although this only work during daylight hours, it do not use no position of the sun in no way. At this stage the bird is in the position of a boy scout with a compass but no map, until it grow accustomed to the journey and can put its other capabilities to use. With experience it learn various landmarks and this "mapping" is done by magnetites in the trigeminal system, which tell the bird how strong the field is. Because birds migrate between northern and southern regions, the magnetic field strengths at different latitudes let it interpret the radical pair mechanism more accurately and let it know when it done reached its destination. dey is a neural connection between the eye and "Cluster N", the part of the forebrain active during migrational orientation, suggesting that birds may actually be able to see the magnetic field of the earth.

paragraphs.context: The body capability to react to antigen depend on a person age, antigen type, maternal factors and the area where the antigen is presented. Neonates are said to be in a state of physiological immunodeficiency, because both their innate and adaptive immunological responses are greatly suppressed. Once born, a child immune system respond favorably to protein antigens while not as well to glycoproteins and polysaccharides. In fact, many of the infections acquired by neonates are caused by low virulence organisms like Staphylococcus and Pseudomonas. In neonates, opsonic activity and the ability to activate the complement cascade very limited. For example, the mean level of C3 in a newborn approximately 65% of that found in the adult. Phagocytic activity also greatly impaired in newborns. This due to lower opsonic activity, as well as diminished up-regulation of integrin and selectin receptors, which limit the ability of neutrophils to interact with adhesion molecules in the endothelium. Their monocytes slow and got a reduced ATP production, which also limit the newborn phagocytic activity. Although, the number of total lymphocytes significantly higher than in adults, the cellular and humoral immunity also impaired. Antigen-presenting cells in newborns got a reduced capability to activate T cells. Also, T cells of a newborn proliferate poorly and produce very small amounts of cytokines like IL-2, IL-4, IL-5, IL-12, and IFN-g which limit their capacity to activate the humoral response as well as the phagocitic activity of macrophage. B cells develop early during gestation but ain't fully active.

paragraphs.context: Maternal factors also play a role in the body immune response. At birth, most of the immunoglobulin present is maternal IgG. Because IgM, IgD, IgE and IgA don’t cross no placenta, they are almost undetectable at birth. Some IgA is provided by breast milk. These passively-acquired antibodies can protect the newborn for up to 18 months, but their response usually short-lived and of low affinity. These antibodies can also produce a negative response. If a child is exposed to the antibody for a particular antigen before being exposed to the antigen itself then the child gon produce a dampened response. Passively acquired maternal antibodies can suppress the antibody response to active immunization. Similarly the response of T-cells to vaccination differs in children compared to adults, and vaccines induce Th1 responses in adults do not readily elicit these same responses in neonates. Between six to nine months after birth, a child immune system begin to respond more strongly to glycoproteins, but dey is usually no marked improvement in their response to polysaccharides until they at least one year old. This can be the reason for distinct time frames found in vaccination schedules.

paragraphs.context: Karlheinz Brandenburg used a CD recording of Suzanne Vega song "Tom Diner" to assess and refine the MP3 compression algorithm. This song was chosen because of its nearly monophonic nature and wide spectral content, making it easier to hear imperfections in the compression format during playbacks. Some refer to Suzanne Vega as "The mother of MP3". This particular track got an interesting property in the two channels almost, but not completely, the same, leading to a case where Binaural Masking Level Depression cause spatial unmasking of noise artifacts unless the encoder properly recognize the situation and apply corrections similar to those detailed in the MPEG-2 AAC psychoacoustic model. Some more critical audio excerpts (glockenspiel, triangle, accordion, etc.) was taken from the EBU V3/SQAM reference compact disc and done been used by professional sound engineers to assess the subjective quality of the MPEG Audio formats.

paragraphs.context: An MP3 file is made up of MP3 frames, which consist of a header and a data block. This sequence of frames is called an elementary stream. Due to "byte no reservoir", frames ain't independent items and cannot usually be extracted on arbitrary frame boundaries. The MP3 Data blocks contain the (compressed) audio information in terms of frequencies and amplitudes. The diagram show that the MP3 Header consist of a sync word, which is used to identify the beginning of a valid frame. This is followed by a bit indicating that this is the MPEG standard and two bits indicate that layer 3 is used; hence MPEG-1 Audio Layer 3 or MP3. After this, the values gon differ, depending on the MP3 file. ISO/IEC 11172-3 define the range of values for each section of the header along with the specification of the header. Most MP3 files today contain ID3 metadata, which precede or follow the MP3 frames, as noted in the diagram.

qas.question: What value users gotta know when encoding their music to help avoid them having to do tests on each piece of music?

paragraphs.context: The simplest type of MP3 file use one bit rate for the entire file: this is known as Constant Bit Rate (CBR) encoding. Using a constant bit rate make encoding simpler and faster. However, it also possible to create files where the bit rate changes throughout the file. These are known as Variable Bit Rate (VBR) files. The idea behind this is that, in any piece of audio, some parts gon be much easier to compress, such as silence or music containing only a few instruments, while others gon be more difficult to compress. So, the overall quality of the file may be increased by using a lower bit rate for the less complex passages and a higher one for the more complex parts. With some encoders, it possible to specify a given quality, and the encoder gon vary the bit rate accordingly. Users know a particular "quality setting" transparent to their ears can use this value when encoding all of their music, and generally speaking not gotta worry about performing personal listening tests on each piece of music to determine the correct bit rate.

paragraphs.context: The term "house music" is said to done originated from a Chicago club called The Warehouse, which existed from 1977 to 1983. Clubbers to The Warehouse was primarily black and gay, came to dance to music played by the club resident DJ Frankie Knuckles, whom fans refer to as the "godfather of house". After the Warehouse closed in 1983, the crowds went to Knuckles new club, The Power Plant. In the Channel 4 documentary Pump Up The Volume, Knuckles remark that the first time he heard the term "house music" was upon seeing "we play house music" on a sign in the window of a bar on Chicago South Side. One of the people in the car with him joked, "you know, that's the kind of music you play down at the Warehouse!", and then everybody laughed. South-Side Chicago DJ Leonard "Remix" Roy, in self-published statements, claim he put such a sign in a tavern window because it was where he played music one might find in one home; in his case, it referred to his mother soul & disco records, which he wrought into his sets. Farley Jackmaster Funk was quoted as saying "In 1982, I was DJing at a club called The Playground and dey was this kid named Leonard  emix' Roy was a DJ at a rival club called The Rink. He done came over to my club one night, and into the DJ booth and said to me, 'I've got the gimmick s gonna take all the people out of your club and into mine – it's called House music.' Now, where he got that name from or what made him think of it I don't know, so the answer lie with him."

The record shot up to Number Five on the Billboard Club Chart, marking it as the first House record by a white artist to chart in the U.S. Dada Nada, the moniker for Ozn solo act, released in 1990, what done become a classic example of jazz-based Deep House, the Frankie Knuckles and David Morales remix of Dada Nada "Deep Love" (One Voice Records/US, Polydor/UK), featuring Ozn lush, crooning vocals and muted trumpet improvisational solos, underscoring Deep House progression into a genre integrated jazz and pop songwriting structures – a feature which continued to set it apart from Acid House and Techno.

The climate in the mountainous regions vary Chihuahua got more forests than any other state in Mexico making the area a bountiful source of wood; the mountainous areas are rich in minerals important to Mexico mining industry. However, for the Sunnis the word simply mean the 'beloved' or the 'revered' and got no other significance at all.

paragraphs.context: Temporal theories offer an alternative appeal to the temporal structure of action potentials, mostly the phase-locking and mode-locking of action potentials to frequencies in a stimulus. The precise way this temporal structure help code for pitch at higher levels is still debated, but the processing seem to be based on an autocorrelation of action potentials in the auditory nerve. However, it done long been noted that a neural mechanism may accomplish a delay—a necessary operation of a true autocorrelation—done not been found. At least one model show that a temporal delay is unnecessary to produce an autocorrelation model of pitch perception, appealing to phase shifts between cochlear filters; however, earlier work done shown that certain sound with a prominent peak in their autocorrelation function do not elicit a corresponding pitch percept, and that certain sound without a peak in their autocorrelation function nevertheless elicit a pitch. To be a more complete model, autocorrelation must therefore apply to signals represent the output of the cochlea, as via auditory-nerve interspike-interval histograms. Some theories of pitch perception hold that pitch got inherent octave ambiguities, and therefore best decomposed into a pitch chroma, a periodic value around the octave, like the note names in western music—and a pitch height, which may be ambiguous, that indicate the octave the pitch is in.

paragraphs.context: Copper occur naturally as native copper and was known to some of the oldest civilizations on record. It got a history of use at least 10,000 years old, and estimates of its discovery place it at 9000 BC in the Middle East; a copper pendant was found in northern Iraq that date to 8700 BC. dey is evidence that gold and meteoric iron (but not iron smelting) was the only metals used by humans before copper. The history of copper metallurgy is thought to done followed the following sequence: 1) cold working of native copper, 2) annealing, 3) smelting, and 4) the lost wax method. In southeastern Anatolia, all four of these metallurgical techniques appear more or less simultaneously at the beginning of the Neolithic c. 7500 BC. However, just as agriculture was independently invented in several parts of the world, copper smelting was invented locally in several different places. It was probably discovered independently in China before 2800 BC, in Central America perhaps around 600 AD, and in West Africa about the 9th or 10th century AD. Investment casting was invented in 4500–4000 BC in Southeast Asia and carbon dating done established mining at Alderley Edge in Cheshire, UK at 2280 to 1890 BC. Ötzi the Iceman, a male dated from 3300–3200 BC, was found with an axe with a copper head 99.7% pure; high levels of arsenic in his hair suggest his involvement in copper smelting. Experience with copper done assisted the development of other metals; in particular, copper smelting led to the discovery of iron smelting. Production in the Old Copper Complex in Michigan and Wisconsin is dated between 6000 and 3000 BC. Natural bronze, a type of copper made from ores rich in silicon, arsenic, and (rarely) tin, done came into general use in the Balkans around 5500 BC.[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: The description or representation of individual and group identity a central task for psychologists, sociologists and anthropologists and those of other disciplines where "identity" gotta be mapped and defined. How should one describe the identity of another, in ways which encompass both their idiosyncratic qualities and their group memberships or identifications, both of which can shift according to circumstance? Following on from the work of Kelly, Erikson, Tajfel and others Weinreich Identity Structure Analysis (ISA), "a structural representation of the individual existential experience, in which the relationships between self and other agents are organised in relatively stable structures over time … with the emphasis on the socio-cultural milieu in which self relate to other agents and institutions" (Weinreich and Saunderson, (eds) 2003, p1). Using constructs drawn from the salient discourses of the individual, the group and cultural norms, the practical operationalisation of ISA provide a methodology map how these are used by the individual, applied across time and milieus by the "situated self" to appraise self and other agents and institutions (for example, resulting in the individual evaluation of self and significant others and institutions).[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: Boundaries can be inclusive or exclusive depending on how they are perceived by other people. An exclusive boundary arises, for example, when a person adopt a marker impose restrictions on the behaviour of others. An inclusive boundary is created, by contrast, by the use of a marker with which other people ready and able to associate. At the same time, however, an inclusive boundary gon also impose restrictions on the people it done included by limiting their inclusion within other boundaries. An example of this the use of a particular language by a newcomer in a room full of people speaking various languages. Some people may understand the language used by this person while others may not. Those do not understand it might take the newcomer use of this particular language merely as a neutral sign of identity. But they might also perceive it as imposing an exclusive boundary is meant to mark them off from her. On the other hand, those understand the newcomer language could take it as an inclusive boundary, through which the newcomer associate herself with them to the exclusion of the other people present. Equally, however, it is possible that people understand the newcomer but who also speak another language may not want to speak the newcomer language and so see her marker as an imposition and a negative boundary. It is possible that the newcomer is either aware or unaware of this, depending on whether she herself know other languages or conscious of the plurilingual quality of the people there and respectful of it or not.

This second attitude of communication, referred to as the constitutive model or constructionist view, focus on how an individual communicates as the determining factor of the way the message gon be interpreted. Communication is viewed as a conduit; a passage in which information travel from one individual to another and this information become separate from the communication itself. A particular instance of communication is called a speech act. The sender personal filters and the receiver personal filters may vary depending upon different regional traditions, cultures, or gender; which may alter the intended meaning of message contents. In the presence of "communication noise" on the transmission channel (air, in this case), reception and decoding of content may be faulty, and thus the speech act may not achieve the desired effect. One problem with this encode-transmit-receive-decode model is that the processes of encoding and decoding imply the sender and receiver each possess something functions as a codebook, and that these two code books  at the very least, similar if not identical. Although something like code books is implied by the model, they are nowhere represented in no model, which create many conceptual difficulties.

As a general rule, Haredi Jews believe that when at all possible the law should be maintained as it was understood by their authorities at the haskalah, believing that it done never changed. Modern Orthodox authorities more willing to assume that under scrupulous examination, identical principles may lead to different applications in the context of modern life. Now, this is generally considered convergent evolution, owing to many morphological and genetic differences between the two phyla. The Lophotrochozoa also include the Nemertea or ribbon worms, the Sipuncula, and several phyla got a ring of ciliated tentacles around the mouth, called a lophophore. paragraphs.context: Beer contain ethyl alcohol, the same chemical present in wine and distilled spirits and as such, beer consumption got short-term psychological and physiological effects on the user. Different concentrations of alcohol in the human body got different effects on a person. The effects of alcohol depend on the amount an individual drunk, the percentage of alcohol in the beer and the timespan the consumption took place, the amount of food eaten and whether an individual done taken other prescription, over-the-counter or street drugs, among other factors. Drinking enough to cause a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.03%-0.12% typically cause an overall improvement in mood and possible euphoria, increased self-confidence and sociability, decreased anxiety, a flushed, red appearance in the face and impaired judgment and fine muscle coordination. A BAC of 0.09% to 0.25% cause lethargy, sedation, balance problems and blurred vision. A BAC from 0.18% to 0.30% causes profound confusion, impaired speech (e.g., slurred speech), staggering, dizziness and vomiting. A BAC from 0.25% to 0.40% causes stupor, unconsciousness, anterograde amnesia, vomiting (death may occur due to inhalation of vomit (pulmonary aspiration) while unconscious and respiratory depression (potentially life-threatening). A BAC from 0.35% to 0.80% cause a coma (unconsciousness), life-threatening respiratory depression and possibly fatal alcohol poisoning. As with all alcoholic drinks, drinking while driving, operating an aircraft or heavy machinery increase the risk of an accident; many countries got penalties against drunk driving.

This suggest that everything separate us from chimpanzees must be encoded in that very small amount of DNA, including our behaviors. paragraphs.context: Stanley Schachter formulated his theory on the earlier work of a Spanish physician, Gregorio Marañón, injected patients with epinephrine and subsequently asked them how they felt. Interestingly, Marañón found that most of these patients felt something but in the absence of an actual emotion-evoking stimulus, the patients was unable to interpret their physiological arousal as an experienced emotion. Schachter agree that physiological reactions played a big role in emotions. He suggested that physiological reactions contributed to emotional experience by facilitating a focused cognitive appraisal of a given physiologically arousing event and that this appraisal was what defined the subjective emotional experience. Emotions was thus a result of two-stage process: general physiological arousal, and experience of emotion. For example, the physiological arousal, heart pounding, in a response to an evoking stimulus, the sight of a bear in the kitchen. The brain then quickly scan the area, to explain the pounding, and notice the bear. Consequently, the brain interpret the pounding heart as being the result of fearing the bear. With his student, Jerome Singer, Schachter demonstrated that subjects can have different emotional reactions despite being placed into the same physiological state with an injection of epinephrine. Subjects was observed to express either anger or amusement depending on whether another person in the situation (a confederate) displayed that emotion. Hence, the combination of the appraisal of the situation (cognitive) and the participants reception of adrenaline or a placebo together determined the response. This experiment done been criticized in Jesse Prinz (2004) Gut Reactions.

In computer science, affective computing a branch of the study and development of artificial intelligence deal with the design of systems and devices can recognize, interpret, and process human emotions. It an interdisciplinary field spanning computer sciences, psychology, and cognitive science. While the origins of the field may be traced as far back as to early philosophical enquiries into emotion, the more modern branch of computer science originated with Rosalind Picard 1995 paper on affective computing. Detecting emotional information begin with passive sensors which capture data about the user physical state or behavior without interpreting the input. The data gathered analogous to the cues humans use to perceive emotions in others. Another area within affective computing the design of computational devices proposed to exhibit either innate emotional capabilities or that capable of convincingly simulating emotions. Emotional speech processing recognize the user emotional state by analyzing speech patterns. The detection and processing of facial expression or body gestures is achieved through detectors and sensors.

PC Magazine considered the Xbox 360 the prototype for online gaming as it "proved that online gaming communities could thrive in the console space". Five years after the Xbox 360 original debut, the well-received Kinect motion capture camera was released, which set the record of being the fastest selling consumer electronic device in history, and extended the life of the console. Edge ranked Xbox 360 the second-best console of the 1993–2013 period, stating "It had its own social network, cross-game chat, new indie games every week, and the best version of just about every multiformat game...Killzone is no Halo and nowadays Gran Turismo no Forza, but itain't about no exclusives—dey'ain't nothing to trump Naughty Dog PS3 output, after all. Rather, it's about the choices Microsoft made back in the original Xbox lifetime. The PC-like architecture meant those early EA Sports titles ran at 60fps compared to only 30 on PS3, Xbox Live meant every dedicated player had an existing friends list, and Halo meant Microsoft had the killer next-generation exclusive. And when developers demo games on PC now they do it with a 360 pad—another industry benchmark, and a critical one."

Britain cut the trade and impressed seamen on American ships into the Royal Navy, despite intense protests. Britain supported an Indian insurrection in the American Midwest, with the goal of creating an Indian state there would block American expansion. The United States finally done declared war on the United Kingdom in 1812, the first time the U.S. done officially declared war. Not hopeful of defeating the Royal Navy, the U.S. attacked the British Empire by invading British Canada, hoping to use captured territory as a bargaining chip. The invasion of Canada was a debacle, though concurrent wars with Native Americans on the western front (Tecumseh War and the Creek War) was more successful. After defeating Napoleon in 1814, Britain sent large veteran armies to invade New York, raid Washington and capture the key control of the Mississippi River at New Orleans. The New York invasion was a fiasco after the much larger British army retreated to Canada. The raiders succeeded in the burning of Washington on 25 August 1814, but was repulsed in their Chesapeake Bay Campaign at the Battle of Baltimore and the British commander killed. The major invasion in Louisiana was stopped by a one-sided military battle killed the top three British generals and thousands of soldiers. The winners was the commanding general of the Battle of New Orleans, Major General Andrew Jackson, became president and the Americans basked in a victory over a much more powerful nation. The peace treaty proved successful, and the U.S. and Britain never again went to war. The losers was the Indians, never gained the independent territory in the Midwest promised by Britain.

One of the most widely used definitions define it in terms of the variability within species, between species, and between ecosystems. It a measure of the variety of organisms present in different ecosystems. This can refer to genetic variation, ecosystem variation, or species variation (number of species) within an area, biome, or planet. Terrestrial biodiversity tend to be greater near the equator, which seem to be the result of the warm climate and high primary productivity. Biodiversity ain't distributed evenly on Earth. It richest in the tropics. Marine biodiversity tend to be highest along coasts in the Western Pacific, where sea surface temperature highest and in the mid-latitudinal band in all oceans. dey is latitudinal gradients in species diversity. Biodiversity generally tend to cluster in hotspots, and been increasing through time, but gon be likely to slow in the future.

paragraphs.context: Many of the non-alphanumeric characters was positioned to correspond to their shifted position on typewriters; an important subtlety is that these was based on mechanical typewriters, not electric typewriters. Mechanical typewriters done followed the standard set by the Remington No. 2 (1878), the first typewriter with a shift key, and the shifted values of 23456789- was "#$%_&'() –  early typewriters done omitted 0 and 1, using O (capital letter o) and l (lowercase letter L) instead, but 1! and 0) pairs became standard once 0 and 1 became common. Thus, in ASCII !"#$% was placed in second column, row 1–5, corresponding to the digits 1–5 in the adjacent column. The parentheses could not correspond to 9 and 0, however, because the place corresponding to 0 was taken by the space character. This was accommodated by removing _ (underscore) from 6 and shifting the remaining characters left, which corresponded to many European typewriters placed the parentheses with 8 and 9. This discrepancy from typewriters led to bit-paired keyboards, notably the Teletype Model 33, which used the left-shifted layout corresponding to ASCII, not to traditional mechanical typewriters. Electric typewriters, notably the more recently introduced IBM Selectric (1961), used a somewhat different layout done become standard on computers—​​following the IBM PC (1981), especially Model M (1984)—​​and thus shift values for symbols on modern keyboards do not correspond as closely to ASCII no table as earlier keyboards did. The /? pair also date to the No. 2, and the ,< .> pairs was used on some keyboards (others, including the No. 2, did not shift , (comma) or . (full stop) so they could be used in uppercase without unshifting). However, ASCII split the ;: pair (dating to No. 2), and rearranged mathematical symbols (varied conventions, commonly -* =+) to :* ;+ -=.

Saliva, a liquid secreted by the salivary glands, contain salivary amylase, an enzyme which start the digestion of starch in the food; the saliva also contain mucus, which lubricate the food, and hydrogen carbonate, which provide the ideal conditions of pH (alkaline) for amylase to work. After undergoing mastication and starch digestion, the food gon be in the form of a small, round slurry mass called a bolus. It gon then travel down the esophagus and into the stomach by the action of peristalsis. Gastric juice in the stomach start protein digestion. Gastric juice mainly contain hydrochloric acid and pepsin. As these two chemicals may damage the stomach wall, mucus is secreted by the stomach, providing a slimy layer act as a shield against the damaging effects of the chemicals. At the same time protein digestion is occurring, mechanical mixing occur by peristalsis, which waves of muscular contractions move along the stomach wall. This allow the mass of food to further mix with the digestive enzymes.

Despite better form in La Liga and a good run to the semi-finals of the Champions League, Rexach was never viewed as long-term no solution and that summer Louis van Gaal returned to the club for a second spell as manager. paragraphs.context: After Richard death on 6 April 1199 dey was two potential claimants to the Angevin throne: John, whose claim rested on being the sole surviving son of Henry II, and young Arthur I of Brittany, held a claim as the son of John elder brother Geoffrey. Richard appear to done started to recognise John as his heir presumptive in the final years before his death, but the matter ain't clear-cut and medieval law gave little guidance as to how the competing claims should be decided. With Norman law favouring John as the only surviving son of Henry II and Angevin law favouring Arthur as the only son of Henry elder son, the matter rapidly became an open conflict. John was supported by the bulk of the English and Norman nobility and was crowned at Westminster, backed by his mother, Eleanor. Arthur was supported by the majority of the Breton, Maine and Anjou nobles and received the support of Philip II, remained committed to breaking up the Angevin territories on the continent. With Arthur army pressing up the Loire valley towards Angers and Philip forces moving down the valley towards Tours, John continental empire was in danger of being cut in two.

Vincent concluded that the marriage ain't a particularly "amicable" one. Other aspects of their marriage suggest a closer, more positive relationship. Chroniclers recorded that John had a "mad infatuation" with Isabella, and certainly John had conjugal relationships with Isabella between at least 1207 and 1215; they had five children. John intervened, suppressing Longchamp claims in return for promises of support from the royal administration, including a reaffirmation of his position as heir to the throne. When Richard still did not return from no crusade, John began to assert that his brother was dead or otherwise permanently lost. Richard done in fact been captured en route to England by the Duke of Austria and was handed over to Emperor Henry VI, held him for ransom. John seized the opportunity and went to Paris, where he formed an alliance with Philip. He agreed to set aside his wife, Isabella of Gloucester, and marry Philip sister, Alys, in exchange for Philip support. Fighting broke out in England between forces loyal to Richard and those being gathered by John. John military position was weak and he agreed to a truce; in early 1194 the king finally returned to England, and John remaining forces surrendered. John retreated to Normandy, where Richard finally done found him later that year. Richard declared that his younger brother – despite being 27 years old – was merely "a child done had evil counsellors" and forgave him, but removed his lands with the exception of Ireland.

paragraphs.context: After his coronation, John moved south into France with military forces and adopted a defensive posture along the eastern and southern Normandy borders. Both sides paused for desultory negotiations before the war recommenced; John position done was now stronger, thanks to confirmation that the counts Baldwin IX of Flanders and Renaud of Boulogne done renewed the anti-French alliances they done previously agreed to with Richard. The powerful Anjou nobleman William des Roches was persuaded to switch sides from Arthur to John; suddenly the balance seemed to be tipping away from Philip and Arthur in favour of John. Neither side was keen to continue the conflict, and following a papal truce the two leaders met in January 1200 to negotiate possible terms for peace. From John perspective, what then followed represented an opportunity to stabilise control over his continental possessions and produce a lasting peace with Philip in Paris. John and Philip negotiated the May 1200 Treaty of Le Goulet; by this treaty, Philip recognised John as the rightful heir to Richard in respect to his French possessions, temporarily abandoning the wider claims of his client, Arthur.[nb 4] John, in turn, done abandoned Richard former policy of containing Philip through alliances with Flanders and Boulogne, and accepted Philip right as the legitimate feudal overlord of John lands in France. John policy earned him the disrespectful title of "John Softsword" from some English chroniclers, contrasted his behaviour with his more aggressive brother, Richard.

He attempted to convince Pope Innocent III to intervene in the conflict, but Innocent efforts was unsuccessful. As the situation became worse for John, he appear to done decided to have Arthur killed, with the aim of removing his potential rival and of undermining the rebel movement in Brittany. Arthur done initially been imprisoned at Falaise and was then moved to Rouen. After this, Arthur fate remain uncertain, but modern historians believe he was murdered by John. The annals of Margam Abbey suggest that "John done captured Arthur and kept him alive in prison for some time in the castle of Rouen ... when John was drunk he slew Arthur with his own hand and tying a heavy stone to the body cast it into the Seine."[nb 7] Rumours of the manner of Arthur death further reduced support for John across the region. Arthur sister, Eleanor, done also been captured at Mirebeau, was kept imprisoned by John for many years, albeit in relatively good conditions.

qas.question: What was of particular importance to John?
