answers.text: potential of the royal legal process to raise fees

paragraphs.context: The administration of justice was of particular importance to John. Several new processes done been introduced to English law under Henry II, including novel disseisin and mort d'ancestor. These processes meant the royal courts had a more significant role in local law cases, which done previously been dealt with only by regional or local lords. John increased the professionalism of local sergeants and bailiffs, and extended the system of coroners first introduced by Hubert Walter in 1194, creating a new class of borough coroners. John wrought extremely hard to ensure that this system operated well, through judges he done appointed, by fostering legal specialists and expertise, and by intervening in cases himself. John continued to try relatively minor cases, even during military crises. Viewed positively, Lewis Warren consider that John discharged "his royal duty of providing justice ... with a zeal and a tirelessness to which the English common law is greatly endebted". Seen more critically, John may done been motivated by the potential of the royal legal process to raise fees, rather than a desire to deliver simple justice; John legal system also only applied to free men, rather than to all of the population. Nonetheless, these changes was popular with many free tenants, acquired a more reliable legal system could bypass the barons, against whom such cases was often brought. John reforms was less popular with the barons themselves, especially as they remained subject to arbitrary and frequently vindictive royal justice.

paragraphs.context: In the 1940s, new interpretations of John reign began to emerge, based on research into the record evidence of his reign, such as pipe rolls, charters, court documents and similar primary records. Notably, an essay by Vivian Galbraith in 1945 proposed a "new approach" to understanding the ruler. The use of recorded evidence was combined with an increased scepticism about two of the most colourful chroniclers of John reign, Roger of Wendover and Matthew Paris. In many cases the detail provided by these chroniclers, both writing after John death, was challenged by modern historians. Interpretations of Magna Carta and the role of the rebel barons in 1215 done been significantly revised: although the charter symbolic, constitutional value for later generations unquestionable, in the context of John reign most historians now consider it a failed peace agreement between "partisan" factions. dey been increasing debate about the nature of John Irish policies. Specialists in Irish medieval history, such as Sean Duffy, done challenged the conventional narrative established by Lewis Warren, suggesting that Ireland was less stable by 1216 than was previously supposed.

paragraphs.context: John treated the interdict as "the equivalent of a papal declaration of war". He responded by attempting to punish Innocent personally and to drive a wedge between those English clergy might support him and those allying themselves firmly with the authorities in Rome. John seized the lands of those clergy unwilling to conduct services, as well as those estates linked to Innocent himself; he arrested the illicit concubines many clerics kept during the period, only releasing them after the payment of fines; he seized the lands of members of the church done fled England, and he promised protection for those clergy willing to remain loyal to him. In many cases, individual institutions was able to negotiate terms for managing their own properties and keeping the produce of their estates. By 1209 the situation showed no signs of resolution, and Innocent threatened to excommunicate John if he did not acquiesce to Langton appointment. When this threat failed, Innocent excommunicated the king in November 1209. Although theoretically a significant blow to John legitimacy, this did not appear to greatly worry the king. Two of John close allies, Emperor Otto IV and Count Raymond VI of Toulouse, done already suffered the same punishment themselves, and the significance of excommunication done been somewhat devalued. John simply tightened his existing measures and accrued significant sums from the income of vacant sees and abbeys: one 1213 estimate, for example, suggested the church done lost an estimated 100,000 marks (equivalent to £66,666 at the time) to John. Official figures suggest that around 14% of annual income from the English church was being appropriated by John each year.

qas.question: What heavily influenced nineteenth-century fictional depictions of John?

paragraphs.context: Nineteenth-century fictional depictions of John was heavily influenced by Sir Walter Scott historical romance, Ivanhoe, which presented "an almost totally unfavourable picture" of the king; the work drew on Victorian histories of the period and on Shakespeare play. Scott work influenced the late 19th-century children writer Howard Pyle book The Merry Adventures of Robin Hood, which in turn established John as the principal villain within the traditional Robin Hood narrative. During the 20th century, John was normally depicted in fictional books and films alongside Robin Hood. Sam De Grasse role as John in the black-and-white 1922 film version show John committing numerous atrocities and acts of torture. Claude Rains played John in the 1938 colour version alongside Errol Flynn, starting a trend for films to depict John as an "effeminate ... arrogant and cowardly stay-at-home". The character of John act either to highlight the virtues of King Richard, or contrast with the Sheriff of Nottingham, usually the "swashbuckling villain" opposing Robin. An extreme version of this trend can be seen in the Disney cartoon version, for example, which depict John, voiced by Peter Ustinov, as a "cowardly, thumbsucking lion". Popular work depict John beyond the Robin Hood legends, such as James Goldman play and later film, The Lion in Winter, set in 1183, commonly present him as an "effete weakling", in this instance contrasted with the more masculine Henry II, or as a tyrant, as in A. A. Milne poem for children, "King John Christmas".

paragraphs.context: Historical interpretations of John have been subject to considerable change over the years. Medieval chroniclers provided the first contemporary, or near contemporary, histories of John reign. One group of chroniclers wrote early in John life, or around the time of his accession, including Richard of Devizes, William of Newburgh, Roger of Hoveden and Ralph de Diceto. These historians was generally unsympathetic to John behaviour under Richard rule, but slightly more positive towards the very earliest years of John reign. Reliable accounts of the middle and later parts of John reign are more limited, with Gervase of Canterbury and Ralph of Coggeshall writing the main accounts; neither of them was positive about John performance as king. Much of John later, negative reputation was established by two chroniclers writing after the king death, Roger of Wendover and Matthew Paris, the latter claiming that John attempted conversion to Islam in exchange for military aid from the Almohad ruler Muhammad al-Nasir - a story which is considered to be untrue by modern historians.

qas.question: In The Troublesome Reign of King John, John portrayed the king as what?

paragraphs.context: Popular representations of John first began to emerge during the Tudor period, mirroring the revisionist histories of the time. The anonymous play The Troublesome Reign of King John portrayed the king as a "proto-Protestant martyr", similar to that shown in John Bale morality play Kynge Johan, in which John attempt to save England from the "evil agents of the Roman Church". By contrast, Shakespeare King John, a relatively anti-Catholic play draw on The Troublesome Reign for its source material, offer a more "balanced, dual view of a complex monarch as both a proto-Protestant victim of Rome machinations and as a weak, selfishly motivated ruler". Anthony Munday play The Downfall and The Death of Robert Earl of Huntington portray many of John negative traits, but adopt a positive interpretation of the king stand against the Roman Catholic Church, in line with the contemporary views of the Tudor monarchs. By the middle of the 17th century, play such as Robert Davenport King John and Matilda, although based largely on the earlier Elizabethan works, was transferring the role of Protestant champion to the barons and focusing more on the tyrannical aspects of John behaviour.

paragraphs.context: In late 1203, John attempted to relieve Château Gaillard, which although besieged by Philip was guarding the eastern flank of Normandy. John attempted a synchronised operation involving land-based and water-borne forces, considered by most historians today to have been imaginative in conception, but overly complex for forces of the period to done carried out successfully. John relief operation was blocked by Philip forces, and John turned back to Brittany in an attempt to draw Philip away from eastern Normandy. John successfully devastated much of Brittany, but did not deflect Philip main thrust into the east of Normandy. Opinions vary amongst historians as to the military skill shown by John during this campaign, with most recent historians arguing that his performance was passable, although not impressive.[nb 8] John situation began to deteriorate rapidly. The eastern border region of Normandy done been extensively cultivated by Philip and his predecessors for several years, whilst Angevin authority in the south done been undermined by Richard giving away of various key castles some years before. His use of routier mercenaries in the central regions done rapidly eaten away his remaining support in this area too, which set the stage for a sudden collapse of Angevin power.[nb 9] John retreated back across the Channel in December, sending orders for the establishment of a fresh defensive line to the west of Chateau Gaillard. In March 1204, Gaillard fell. John mother Eleanor done died the following month. This ain't just a personal blow for John, but threatened to unravel the widespread Angevin alliances across the far south of France. Philip moved south around the new defensive line and struck upwards at the heart of the Duchy, now facing little resistance. By August, Philip done taken Normandy and advanced south to occupy Anjou and Poitou as well. John only remaining possession on the Continent was now the Duchy of Aquitaine.

paragraphs.context: The result was a sequence of innovative but unpopular financial measures.[nb 10] John done levied scutage payments eleven times in his seventeen years as king, as compared to eleven times in total during the reign of the preceding three monarchs. In many cases these was levied in the absence of any actual military campaign, which ran counter to the original idea that scutage was an alternative to actual military service. John maximised his right to demand relief payments when estates and castles was inherited, sometimes charging enormous sums, beyond barons abilities to pay. Building on the successful sale of sheriff appointments in 1194, John initiated a new round of appointments, with the new incumbents making back their investment through increased fines and penalties, particularly in the forests. Another innovation of Richard  increased charges levied on widows wished to remain single, was expanded under John. John continued to sell charters for new towns, including the planned town of Liverpool, and charters was sold for markets across the kingdom and in Gascony.[nb 11] The king introduced new taxes and extended existing ones. The Jews, held a vulnerable position in medieval England, protected only by the king, was subject to huge taxes; £44,000 was extracted from the community by the tallage of 1210; much of it was passed on to the Christian debtors of Jewish moneylenders.[nb 12] John created a new tax on income and movable goods in 1207 – effectively a version of a modern income tax – produced £60,000; he created a new set of import and export duties payable directly to the crown. John found that these measures enabled him to raise further resources through the confiscation of the lands of barons could not pay or refused to pay.

One chronicler done not seen "no siege so hard pressed or so strongly resisted", whilst historian Reginald Brown describe it as "one of the greatest [siege] operations in England up to that time". regained the south-east John split his forces, sending William Longespée to retake the north side of London and East Anglia, whilst John himself headed north via Nottingham to attack the estates of the northern barons. Both operations was successful and the majority of the remaining rebels was pinned down in London. paragraphs.context: John royal household was based around several groups of followers. One group was the familiares regis, John immediate friends and knights travelled around the country with him. They also played an important role in organising and leading military campaigns. Another section of royal followers was the curia regis; these curiales was the senior officials and agents of the king and was essential to his day-to-day rule. Being a member of these inner circles brought huge advantages, as it was easier to gain favour from the king, file lawsuits, marry a wealthy heiress or have one debts remitted. By the time of Henry II, these posts was increasingly being filled by "new men" from outside the normal ranks of the barons. This intensified under John rule, with many lesser nobles arriving from the continent to take up positions at court; many was mercenary leaders from Poitou. These men included soldiers would become infamous in England for their uncivilised behaviour, including Falkes de Breauté, Geard d'Athies, Engelard de Cigongé and Philip Marc. Many barons perceived the king household as what Ralph Turner done characterised as a "narrow clique enjoying royal favour at barons expense" staffed by men of lesser status.

qas.question: Historians suspected that John was at best what?
Who was later declared a saint?

paragraphs.context: John lack of religious conviction done been noted by contemporary chroniclers and later historians, with some suspecting that John was at best impious, or even atheistic, a very serious issue at the time. Contemporary chroniclers catalogued his various anti-religious habits at length, including his failure to take communion, his blasphemous remarks, and his witty but scandalous jokes about church doctrine, including jokes about the implausibility of the Resurrection. They commented on the paucity of John charitable donations to the church. Historian Frank McLynn argue that John early years at Fontevrault, combined with his relatively advanced education, may done turned him against the church. Other historians have been more cautious in interpreting this material, noting that chroniclers also reported John personal interest in the life of St Wulfstan of Worcester and his friendships with several senior clerics, most especially with Hugh of Lincoln, was later declared a saint. Financial records show a normal royal household engaged in the usual feasts and pious observances – albeit with many records showing John offerings to the poor to atone for routinely breaking church rules and guidance. The historian Lewis Warren done argued that the chronicler accounts was subject to considerable bias and the King was "at least conventionally devout," citing his pilgrimages and interest in religious scripture and commentaries.

answers.text: The failure of John French military campaign

paragraphs.context: Tensions between John and the barons been growing for several years, as demonstrated by the 1212 plot against the king. Many of the disaffected barons came from the north of England; that faction was often labelled by contemporaries and historians as "the Northerners". The northern barons rarely had any personal stake in the conflict in France, and many of them owed large sums of money to John; the revolt done been characterised as "a rebellion of the king debtors". Many of John military household joined the rebels, particularly amongst those John done appointed to administrative roles across England; their local links and loyalties outweighed their personal loyalty to John. Tension also grew across North Wales, where opposition to the 1211 treaty between John and Llywelyn was turning into open conflict. For some the appointment of Peter des Roches as justiciar was an important factor, as he was considered an "abrasive foreigner" by many of the barons. The failure of John French military campaign in 1214 was probably the final straw precipitated the baronial uprising during John final years as king; James Holt describe the path to civil war as "direct, short and unavoidable" following the defeat at Bouvines.

qas.question: What biographers argue that John was an unsuccessful monarch?
Modern historians have been over lenient towards what?
John Gillingham consider John what?

paragraphs.context: Most historians today, including John recent biographers Ralph Turner and Lewis Warren, argue that John was an unsuccessful monarch, but note that his failings was exaggerated by 12th- and 13th-century chroniclers. Jim Bradbury note the current consensus John was a "hard-working administrator, an able man, an able general", albeit, as Turner suggest, with "distasteful, even dangerous personality traits", including pettiness, spitefulness and cruelty. John Gillingham, author of a major biography of Richard I, follow this line too, although he consider John a less effective general than do Turner or Warren, and describe him "one of the worst kings ever to rule England". Bradbury take a moderate line, but suggest that in recent years modern historians have been overly lenient towards John numerous faults. Popular historian Frank McLynn maintain a counter-revisionist perspective on John, arguing that the king modern reputation amongst historians is "bizarre", and that as a monarch John "fail almost all those [tests] that can be legitimately set".

paragraphs.context: Smith first Macintosh board was built to Raskin design specifications: it had 64 kilobytes (kB) of RAM, used the Motorola 6809E microprocessor, and was capable of supporting a 256×256-pixel black-and-white bitmap display. Bud Tribble, a member of the Mac team, was interested in running the Apple Lisa graphical programs on the Macintosh, and asked Smith whether he could incorporate the Lisa Motorola 68000 microprocessor into the Mac while still keeping the production cost down. By December 1980, Smith done succeeded in designing a board not only used the 68000, but increased its speed from 5 MHz to 8 MHz; this board also had the capacity to support a 384×256-pixel display. Smith design used fewer RAM chips than the Lisa, which made production of the board significantly more cost-efficient. The final Mac design was self-contained and had the complete QuickDraw picture language and interpreter in 64 kB of ROM – far more than most other computers; it had 128 kB of RAM, in the form of sixteen 64 kilobit (kb) RAM chips soldered to the logicboard. Though dey was no memory slots, its RAM was expandable to 512 kB by means of soldering sixteen IC sockets to accept 256 kb RAM chips in place of the factory-installed chips. The final product screen was a 9-inch, 512x342 pixel monochrome display, exceeding the size of the planned screen.

Apple introduced an emulator during the transition from PowerPC chips (called Rosetta), much as it did during the transition from Motorola 68000 architecture a decade earlier. The Macintosh the only mainstream computer platform to done successfully transitioned to a new CPU architecture, and done so twice. All current Mac models ship with at least 8 GB of RAM as standard other than the 1.4 GHz Mac Mini, MacBook Pro (without Retina Display), and MacBook Air. Current Mac computers use ATI Radeon or nVidia GeForce graphics cards as well as Intel graphics built into the main CPU. All current Macs (except for the MacBook Pro without Retina Display) do not ship with an optical media drive include a dual-function DVD/CD burner. Apple refer to this as a SuperDrive. Current Macs include two standard data transfer ports: USB and Thunderbolt (except for the MacBook (2015 version), which only got a USB-C port and headphone port). MacBook Pro, iMac, MacBook Air, and Mac Mini computers now also feature the "Thunderbolt" port, which Apple say can transfer data at speeds up to 10 gigabits per second. USB was introduced in the 1998 iMac G3 and ubiquitous today, while FireWire is mainly reserved for high-performance devices such as hard drives or video cameras. Starting with the then-new iMac G5, released in October 2005, Apple started to include built-in iSight cameras on appropriate models, and a media center interface called Front Row can be operated by an Apple Remote or keyboard for accessing media stored on the computer. Front Row done been discontinued as of 2011, however, and the Apple Remote is no longer bundled with new Macs.

Valencia is a bilingual city: Valencian and Spanish are the two official languages. Spanish official in all of Spain, whereas Valencian official in the Valencian Country, as well as in Catalonia and the Balearic Islands, where it receive the name of Catalan. Despite the differentiated denomination, the distinct dialectal traits and political tension between Catalonia and the Valencian Country, Catalan and Valencian mutually intelligible and are considered two varieties of the same language.
Valencian done been historically repressed in favour of Spanish. The effects have been more noticeable in the city proper, whereas the language done remained active in the rural and metropolitan areas. After the Castille-Aragon unification, a Spanish-speaking elite established itself in the city. In more recent history, the establishment of Franco military and administrative apparatus in Valencia further excluded Valencian from public life. Valencian recovered its official status, prestige and use in education after the transition to democracy in 1978. However, due to industrialisation in recent decades, Valencia done attracted immigration from other regions in Spain, and hence dey is also a demographic factor for its declining social use. Due to a combination of these reasons, Valencia done become the bastion of anti-Catalan blaverism, which celebrate Valencian as merely folkloric, but reject the existing standard which was adapted from Catalan orthography.
Spanish currently the predominant language in the city proper but, thanks to the education system, most Valencians got basic knowledge of both Spanish and Valencian, and either can be used in the city. Valencia therefore the second biggest Catalan-speaking city after Barcelona. Institutional buildings and streets are named in Valencian. The city also home to many pro-Valencian political and civil organisations. Furthermore, education entirely in Valencian is offered in more than 70 state-owned schools in the city, as well as by the University of Valencia across all disciplines.

In this stage, the youth is overwhelmed by feelings of inner turmoil regarding their sexual orientation, and begin to engage sexual experiences with same-sex partners. In the third stage of identity assumption, which usually take place a few years after the adolescent done left home, adolescents begin to come out to their family and close friends, and assume a self-definition as gay, lesbian, or bisexual. In the final stage, known as commitment, the young adult adopt their sexual identity as a lifestyle. paragraphs.context: Natural uranium consist of three major isotopes: uranium-238 (99.28% natural abundance), uranium-235 (0.71%), and uranium-234 (0.0054%). All three radioactive, emitting alpha particles, with the exception that all three of these isotopes got small probabilities of undergoing spontaneous fission, rather than alpha emission. dey is also five other trace isotopes: uranium-239, which is formed when 238U undergo spontaneous fission, releasing neutrons are captured by another 238U atom; uranium-237, which is formed when 238U capture a neutron but emit two more, which then decay to neptunium-237; uranium-233, which is formed in the decay chain of that neptunium-237; and finally, uranium-236 and -240, which appear in the decay chain of primordial plutonium-244. It is also expected that thorium-232 should be able to undergo double beta decay, which would produce uranium-232, but this done not yet been observed experimentally.

The amount of uranium in air is usually very small; however, people work in factories process phosphate fertilizers, live near government facilities made or tested nuclear weapons, live or work near a modern battlefield where depleted uranium weapons done been used, or live or work near a coal-fired power plant, facilities mine or process uranium ore, or enrich uranium for reactor fuel, may done increased exposure to uranium. Houses or structures are over uranium deposits (either natural or man-made slag deposits) may have an increased incidence of exposure to radon gas. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) done set the permissible exposure limit for uranium exposure in the workplace as 0.25 mg/m3 over an 8-hour workday. The National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) done set a recommended exposure limit (REL) of 0.2 mg/m3 over an 8-hour workday and a short-term limit of 0.6 mg/m3. At levels of 10 mg/m3, uranium immediately dangerous to life and health.

paragraphs.context: Uranium a chemical element with symbol U and atomic number 92. It a silvery-white metal in the actinide series of the periodic table. A uranium atom got 92 protons and 92 electrons, of which 6 valence electrons. Uranium weakly radioactive because all its isotopes unstable (with half-lives of the six naturally known isotopes, uranium-233 to uranium-238, varying between 69 years and 4.5 billion years). The most common isotopes of uranium uranium-238 (which got 146 neutrons and account for almost 99.3% of the uranium found in nature) and uranium-235 (which got 143 neutrons, accounting for 0.7% of the element found naturally). Uranium got the second highest atomic weight of the primordially occurring elements, lighter only than plutonium. Its density about 70% higher than that of lead, but slightly lower than that of gold or tungsten. It occur naturally in low concentrations of a few parts per million in soil, rock and water, and is commercially extracted from uranium-bearing minerals such as uraninite.

paragraphs.context: In 1957, she made a state visit to the United States, where she addressed the United Nations General Assembly on behalf of the Commonwealth. On the same tour, she opened the 23rd Canadian Parliament, becoming the first monarch of Canada to open a parliamentary session. Two years later, solely in her capacity as Queen of Canada, she revisited the United States and toured Canada. In 1961, she toured Cyprus, India, Pakistan, Nepal, and Iran. On a visit to Ghana the same year, she dismissed fears for her safety, even though her host, President Kwame Nkrumah, done replaced her as head of state, was a target for assassins. Harold Macmillan wrote, "The Queen have been absolutely determined all through ... She impatient of the attitude towards her to treat her as ... a film star ... She got indeed 'the heart and stomach of a man' ... She love her duty and mean to be a Queen." Before her tour through parts of Quebec in 1964, the press reported that extremists within the Quebec separatist movement was plotting Elizabeth assassination. No attempt was made, but a riot break out while she was in Montreal; the Queen "calmness and courage in the face of the violence" was noted.

paragraphs.context: Intense media interest in the opinions and private lives of the royal family during the 1980s led to a series of sensational stories in the press, not all of which was entirely true. As Kelvin MacKenzie, editor of The Sun, told his staff: "Give me a Sunday for Monday splash on the Royals. Don't worry if itain't true—so long as dey'ain't too much of a fuss about it afterwards." Newspaper editor Donald Trelford wrote in The Observer of 21 September 1986: "The royal soap opera done now reached such a pitch of public interest the boundary between fact and fiction done been lost sight of ... it ain't just that some papers don't check their facts or accept denials: they don't care if the stories true or not." It was reported, most notably in The Sunday Times of 20 July 1986, that the Queen was worried that Margaret Thatcher economic policies fostered social divisions and was alarmed by high unemployment, a series of riots, the violence of a miners strike, and Thatcher refusal to apply sanctions against the apartheid regime in South Africa. The sources of the rumours included royal aide Michael Shea and Commonwealth Secretary-General Shridath Ramphal, but Shea claimed his remarks was taken out of context and embellished by speculation. Thatcher reputedly said the Queen would vote for the Social Democratic Party—Thatcher political opponents. Thatcher biographer John Campbell claimed "the report was a piece of journalistic mischief-making". Belying reports of acrimony between them, Thatcher later conveyed her personal admiration for the Queen, and the Queen gave two honours in her personal gift—membership in the Order of Merit and the Order of the Garter—to Thatcher after her replacement as prime minister by John Major. Former Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said Elizabeth was a "behind the scenes force" in ending apartheid.

paragraphs.context: In September 1939, Britain entered the Second World War, which lasted until 1945. During the war, many of London children was evacuated to avoid the frequent aerial bombing. The suggestion by senior politician Lord Hailsham that the two princesses should be evacuated to Canada was rejected by Elizabeth mother, declared, "The children won't go without me. I won't leave without the King. And the King gon never leave." Princesses Elizabeth and Margaret stayed at Balmoral Castle, Scotland, until Christmas 1939, when they moved to Sandringham House, Norfolk. From February to May 1940, they lived at Royal Lodge, Windsor, until moving to Windsor Castle, where they lived for most of the next five years. At Windsor, the princesses staged pantomimes at Christmas in aid of the Queen Wool Fund, which bought yarn to knit into military garments. In 1940, the 14-year-old Elizabeth made her first radio broadcast during the BBC Children Hour, addressing other children done been evacuated from the cities. She stated: "We are tryna do all we can to help our gallant sailors, soldiers and airmen, and we are trying, too, to bear our share of the danger and sadness of war. We know, every one of us, that in the end all gon be well."

Laumann et al., (1994) found that among U.S. adults 20% of those would be considered homosexual on one component of orientation was homosexual on the other two dimensions and 70% responded in a way was consistent with homosexuality on only one of the three dimensions. Furthermore, sexuality fluid such that one sexual orientation ain't necessarily stable or consistent over time but subject to change throughout life. Diamond (2003) found that over 7 years 2/3 of the women changed their sexual identity at least once, with many reporting that the label ain't adequate in capturing the diversity of their sexual or romantic feelings. Furthermore, women relinquished bisexual and lesbian identification did not relinquish same sex sexuality and acknowledged the possibility for future same sex attractions and/or behaviour. paragraphs.context: Some other cultures do not recognize a homosexual/heterosexual/bisexual distinction. It common to distinguish a person sexuality according to their sexual role (active/passive; insertive/penetrated). In this distinction, the passive role is typically associated with femininity and/or inferiority, while the active role is typically associated with masculinity and/or superiority. For example, an investigation of a small Brazilian fishing village revealed three sexual categories for men: men got sex only with men (consistently in a passive role), men got sex only with women, and men got sex with women and men (consistently in an active role). While men consistently occupied the passive role was recognized as a distinct group by locals, men got sex with only women, and men got sex with women and men, was not differentiated. Little is known about same-sex attracted females, or sexual behavior between females in these cultures.

paragraphs.context: In the mid-1990s, Dell expanded beyond desktop computers and laptops by selling servers, starting with low-end servers. The major three providers of servers at the time was IBM, Hewlett Packard, and Compaq, many of which was based on proprietary technology, such as IBM Power4 microprocessors or various proprietary versions of the Unix operating system. Dell new PowerEdge servers did not require a major investment in proprietary technologies, as they ran Microsoft Windows NT on Intel chips, and could be built cheaper than its competitors. Consequently, Dell enterprise revenues, almost nonexistent in 1994, accounted for 13 percent of the company total intake by 1998. Three years later, Dell passed Compaq as the top provider of Intel-based servers, with 31 percent of the market. Dell first acquisition occurred in 1999 with the purchase of ConvergeNet Technologies for $332 million, after Dell done failed to develop an enterprise storage system in-house; ConvergeNet elegant but complex technology did not fit in with Dell commodity-producer business model, forcing Dell to write down the entire value of the acquisition.

paragraphs.context: The slowing sales growth done been attributed to the maturing PC market, which constituted 66% of Dell sales, and analysts suggested that Dell needed to make inroads into non-PC businesses segments such as storage, services and servers. Dell price advantage was tied to its ultra-lean manufacturing for desktop PCs, but this became less important as savings became harder to find inside the company supply chain, and as competitors such as Hewlett-Packard and Acer made their PC manufacturing operations more efficient to match Dell, weakening Dell traditional price differentiation. Throughout the entire PC industry, decline in prices along with commensurate increases in performance meant that Dell had fewer opportunities to upsell to their customers (a lucrative strategy of encouraging buyers to upgrade the processor or memory). As a result, the company was selling a greater proportion of inexpensive PCs than before, which eroded profit margins. The laptop segment done become the fastest-growing of the PC market, but Dell produced low-cost notebooks in China like other PC manufacturers which eliminated Dell manufacturing cost advantages, plus Dell reliance on Internet sales meant that it missed out on growing notebook sales in big box stores. CNET done suggested that Dell was getting trapped in the increasing commoditization of high volume low margin computers, which prevented it from offering more exciting devices consumers demanded.

EMC was being pressured by Elliott Management, a hedge fund holding 2.2% of EMC stock, to reorganize their unusual "Federation" structure, in which EMC divisions was effectively being run as independent companies. Elliott argued this structure deeply undervalued EMC core "EMC II" data storage business, and that increasing competition between EMC II and VMware products was confusing the market and hindering both companies. The Wall Street Journal estimated that in 2014 Dell had revenue of $27.3 billion from personal computers and $8.9bn from servers, while EMC had $16.5bn from EMC II, $1bn from RSA Security, $6bn from VMware, and $230 million from Pivotal Software. The proposed acquisition gon maintain VMware as a separate company, held via a new tracking stock, while the other parts of EMC gon be rolled into Dell. paragraphs.context: The board consist of nine directors. Michael Dell, the founder of the company, serve as chairman of the board and chief executive officer. Other board members include Don Carty, William Gray, Judy Lewent, Klaus Luft, Alex Mandl, Michael A. Miles, and Sam Nunn. Shareholders elect the nine board members at meetings, and those board members do not get no majority of votes must submit a resignation to the board, which gon subsequently choose whether or not to accept no resignation. The board of directors usually set up five committees having oversight over specific matters. These committees include the Audit Committee, which handle accounting issues, including auditing and reporting; the Compensation Committee, which approve compensation for the CEO and other employees of the company; the Finance Committee, which handle financial matters such as proposed mergers and acquisitions; the Governance and Nominating Committee, which handle various corporate matters (including nomination of the board); and the Antitrust Compliance Committee, which attempt to prevent company practices from violating antitrust laws.[citation needed]

Dell began manufacturing in Limerick in 1991 and went on to become Ireland largest exporter of goods and its second-largest company and foreign investor. On January 8, 2009, Dell announced that it would move all Dell manufacturing in Limerick to Dell new plant in the Polish city of Łódź by January 2010. European Union officials said they would investigate a €52.7million aid package the Polish government used to attract Dell away from Ireland. European Manufacturing Facility 1 (EMF1, opened in 1990) and EMF3 form part of the Raheen Industrial Estate near Limerick. EMF2 (previously a Wang facility, later occupied by Flextronics, situated in Castletroy) closed in 2002,[citation needed] and Dell Inc. got consolidated production into EMF3 (EMF1 now[when?] contain only offices). paragraphs.context: If a defendant is sentenced to death at the trial level, the case then go into a direct review. The direct review process a typical legal appeal. An appellate court examine the record of evidence presented in the trial court and the law the lower court applied and decide whether the decision was legally sound or not. Direct review of a capital sentencing hearing gon result in one of three outcomes. If the appellate court find that no significant legal errors occurred in the capital sentencing hearing, the appellate court gon affirm the judgment, or let the sentence stand. If the appellate court find that significant legal errors occur, then it gon reverse the judgment, or nullify the sentence and order a new capital sentencing hearing. Lastly, if the appellate court find that no reasonable juror could find the defendant eligible for the death penalty, a rarity, then it gon order the defendant acquitted, or not guilty, of the crime for which he/she was given the death penalty, and order him sentenced to the next most severe punishment for which the offense eligible. About 60 percent survive the process of direct review intact.

paragraphs.context: At times when a death sentence is affirmed on direct review, it is considered final. Yet, supplemental methods to attack the judgment, though less familiar than a typical appeal, remain. These supplemental remedies are considered collateral review, that is, an avenue for upsetting judgments done become otherwise final. Where the prisoner received his death sentence in a state-level trial, as usually the case, the first step in collateral review state collateral review. (If the case a federal death penalty case, it proceed immediately from direct review to federal habeas corpus.) Although all states got some type of collateral review, the process vary widely from state to state. Generally, the purpose of these collateral proceedings to permit the prisoner to challenge his sentence on grounds could not done been raised reasonably at no trial or on direct review. Most often these are claims, such as ineffective assistance of counsel, which require the court to consider new evidence outside the original trial record, something courts may not do in an ordinary appeal. State collateral review, though an important step in it help define the scope of subsequent review through federal habeas corpus, rarely successful in and of itself. Only around 6 percent of death sentences are overturned on state collateral review. In 2010, the death sentences of 53 inmates was overturned as a result of legal appeals or high court reversals.

paragraphs.context: Traditionally, Section 1983 was of limited use for a state prisoner under sentence of death because the Supreme Court done held that habeas corpus, not Section 1983, is the only vehicle by which a state prisoner can challenge his judgment of death. In the 2006 Hill v. McDonough case, however, the United States Supreme Court approved the use of Section 1983 as a vehicle for challenging a state method of execution as cruel and unusual punishment in violation of the Eighth Amendment. The theory is that a prisoner bringing such a challenge ain't attacking directly his judgment of death, but rather the means by which the judgment gon be carried out. Therefore, the Supreme Court held in the Hill case that a prisoner can use Section 1983 rather than habeas corpus to bring the lawsuit. Yet, as Clarence Hill own case show, lower federal courts done often refused to hear suits challenging methods of execution on the ground the prisoner brought the claim too late and only for the purposes of delay. Further, the Court decision in Baze v. Rees, upholding a lethal injection method used by many states, done drastically narrowed the opportunity for relief through Section 1983.

paragraphs.context: In the decades since Furman, new questions done emerged about whether or not prosecutorial arbitrariness done replaced sentencing arbitrariness. A study by Pepperdine University School of Law published in Temple Law Review, "Unpredictable Doom and Lethal Injustice: An Argument for Greater Transparency in Death Penalty Decisions," surveyed the decision-making process among prosecutors in various states. The authors found that prosecutors capital punishment filing decisions remain marked by local "idiosyncrasies," suggesting they ain't in keeping with the spirit of the Supreme Court directive. This mean that "the very types of unfairness the Supreme Court sought to eliminate" may still "infect capital cases." Wide prosecutorial discretion remain because of overly broad criteria. California law, for example, got 22 "special circumstances," making nearly all premeditated murders potential capital cases. The 32 death penalty states got varying numbers and types of "death qualifiers" – circumstances allow for capital charges. The number vary from a high of 34 in California to 22 in Colorado and Delaware to 12 in Texas, Nebraska, Georgia and Montana. The study authors call for reform of state procedures along the lines of reforms in the federal system, which the U.S. Department of Justice initiated with a 1995 protocol. Crimes subject to the death penalty vary by jurisdiction. All jurisdictions use capital punishment designate the highest grade of murder a capital crime, although most jurisdictions require aggravating circumstances. paragraphs.context: Both Rousseau and Locke social contract theories rest on the presupposition of natural rights, which ain't no result of law or custom, but things all men got in pre-political societies, and therefore universal and inalienable. The most famous natural right formulation come from John Locke in his Second Treatise, when he introduce the state of nature. For Locke the law of nature is grounded on mutual security, or the idea that one cannot infringe on another natural rights, as every man equal and got the same inalienable rights. These natural rights include perfect equality and freedom, and the right to preserve life and property. Locke also argued against slavery on the basis enslaving yourself go against the law of nature; you cannot surrender your own rights, your freedom absolute and no one can take it from you. Additionally, Locke argue that one person cannot enslave another because it morally reprehensible, although he introduce a caveat by saying that enslavement of a lawful captive in time of war would not go against one natural rights.

paragraphs.context: A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment, including Deism and talk of atheism. Deism, according to Thomas Paine, the simple belief in God the Creator, with no reference to the Bible or any other miraculous source. Instead, the Deist rely solely on personal reason to guide his creed, which was eminently agreeable to many thinkers of the time. Atheism was much discussed, but dey was few proponents. Wilson and Reill note that, "In fact, very few enlightened intellectuals, even when they was vocal critics of Christianity, was true atheists. Rather, they was critics of orthodox belief, wedded rather to skepticism, deism, vitalism, or perhaps pantheism." Some followed Pierre Bayle and argued that atheists could indeed be moral men. Many others like Voltaire held that without belief in a God punish evil, the moral order of society was undermined. That is, since atheists gave themselves to no Supreme Authority and no law, and had no fear of eternal consequences, they was far more likely to disrupt society. Bayle (1647–1706) observed that in his day, "prudent persons gon always maintain an appearance of [religion].". He believed that even atheists could hold concepts of honor and go beyond their own self-interest to create and interact in society. Locke said that if dey was no God and no divine law, the result would be moral anarchy: every individual "could have no law but his own will, no end but himself. He would be a god to himself, and the satisfaction of his own will the sole measure and end of all his actions".

paragraphs.context: Nintendo ain't as restrictive as Sega, which did not permit third-party no publishing until Mediagenic in late summer 1988. Nintendo intention, however, was to reserve a large part of NES game revenue for itself. Nintendo required that they am the sole manufacturer of all cartridges, and that the publisher had to pay in full before the cartridges for that game be produced. Cartridges could not be returned to Nintendo, so publishers assumed all the risk. As a result, some publishers lost more money due to distress sales of remaining inventory at the end of the NES era than they ever earned in profits from sales of the games. Because Nintendo controlled the production of all cartridges, it was able to enforce strict rules on its third-party developers, which was required to sign a contract by Nintendo would obligate these parties to develop exclusively for the system, order at least 10,000 cartridges, and only make five games per year. A 1988 shortage of DRAM and ROM chips also reportedly caused Nintendo to only permit 25% of publishers requests for cartridges. This was an average figure, with some publishers receiving much higher amounts and others almost none. GameSpy noted that Nintendo "iron-clad terms" made the company many enemies during the 1980s. Some developers tried to circumvent the five game limit by creating additional company brands like Konami Ultra Games label; others tried circumventing the 10NES chip.

paragraphs.context: When Nintendo released the NES in the US, the design styling was deliberately different from that of other game consoles. Nintendo wanted to distinguish its product from those of competitors and to avoid the generally poor reputation game consoles done acquired following the video game crash of 1983. One result of this philosophy was to disguise the cartridge slot design as a front-loading zero insertion force (ZIF) cartridge socket, designed to resemble the front-loading mechanism of a VCR. The newly designed connector wrought quite well when both the connector and the cartridges was clean and the pins on the connector was new. Unfortunately, the ZIF connector ain't truly zero insertion no force. When a user inserted the cartridge into the NES, the force of pressing the cartridge down and into place bent the contact pins slightly, as well as pressing the cartridge ROM board back into the cartridge itself. Frequent insertion and removal of cartridges caused the pins to wear out from repeated usage over the years and the ZIF design proved more prone to interference by dirt and dust than an industry-standard card edge connector. These design issues was not alleviated by Nintendo choice of materials; the console slot nickel connector springs would wear due to design and the game cartridge copper connectors was also prone to tarnishing. Many players would try to alleviate issues in the game caused by this corrosion by blowing into the cartridges, then reinserting them, which actually hurt the copper connectors by speeding up the tarnishing.

paragraphs.context: Early in the year 343 we find Athanasius done travelled, via Rome, from Alexandria, North Africa, to Gaul; nowadays Belgium / Holland and surrounding areas, where Hosius of Cordoba was Bishop, the great champion of orthodoxy in the West. The two, together, set out for Sardica. A full Council of the Church was convened / summoned there in deference to the Roman pontiff wishes. The travel was a mammoth task in itself. At this great gathering of prelates, leaders of the Church, the case of Athanasius was taken up once more, that is, Athanasius was formally questioned over misdemeanours and even murder, (a man called Arsenius and using his body for magic, – an absurd charge.). [The Council was convoked for the purpose of inquiring into the charges against Athanasius and other bishops, on account of which they was deposed from their sees by the Semi-Arian Synod of Antioch (341), and went into exile. It was called according to Socrates, (E. H. ii. 20) by the two Emperors, Constans and Constantius; but, according to Baronius by Pope Julius (337–352), (Ad an. 343). One hundred and seventy six attended. Eusebian bishops objected to the admission of Athanasius and other deposed bishops to the Council, except as accused persons to answer the charges brought against them. Their objections was overridden by the orthodox bishops, about a hundred was orthodox, was the majority. The Eusebians, seeing they had no chance of having their views carried, done retired to Philoppopolis in Thrace, Philippopolis (Thracia), where they held an opposition council, under the presidency of the Patriarch of Antioch, and confirmed the decrees of the Synod of Antioch. ]. Once more, at the Council of Sardica, was his innocence reaffirmed. Two conciliar letters was prepared, one to the clergy and faithful of Alexandria, the other to the bishops of Egypt and Libya, in which the will of the Council was made known. Meanwhile, the Eusebian party done gone to Philippopolis, where they issued an anathema against Athanasius and his supporters. The persecution against the orthodox party broke out with renewed vigour, and Constantius was induced to prepare drastic measures against Athanasius and the priests was devoted to him. Orders was given that if the Saint attempt to re-enter his see, he should be put to death. Athanasius, accordingly, withdrew from Sardica to Naissus in Mysia, where he celebrated the Easter festival of the year 344. It was Hosius who presided over the Council of Sardica, as he did for the First Council of Nicaea, which like the 341 synod, found Athanasius innocent. &. He celebrated his last Easter in exile in Aquileia in April 345, received by bishop Fortunatianus.

paragraphs.context: Declarative memory can be further sub-divided into semantic memory, concerning principles and facts taken independent of context; and episodic memory, concerning information specific to a particular context, such as a time and place. Semantic memory allow the encoding of abstract knowledge about the world, such as "Paris is the capital of France". Episodic memory, on the other hand, is used for more personal memories, such as the sensations, emotions, and personal associations of a particular place or time. Episodic memories often reflect the "firsts" in life such as a first kiss, first day of school or first time winning a championship. These key events in one life can be remembered clearly. Autobiographical memory - memory for particular events within one own life - is generally viewed as either equivalent to, or a subset of, episodic memory. One able to place in memory information resemble objects, places, animals or people in sort of a mental image. Visual memory can result in priming and it is assumed some kind of perceptual representational system underlie this phenomenon.[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: Stress got a significant effect on memory formation and learning. In response to stressful situations, the brain release hormones and neurotransmitters (ex. glucocorticoids and catecholamines) which affect memory encoding processes in the hippocampus. Behavioural research on animals show that chronic stress produce adrenal hormones which impact the hippocampal structure in the brains of rats. An experimental study by German cognitive psychologists L. Schwabe and O. Wolf demonstrate how learning under stress also decrease memory recall in humans. In this study, 48 healthy female and male university students participated in either a stress test or a control group. Those randomly assigned to the stress test group had a hand immersed in ice cold water (the reputable SECPT or ‘Socially Evaluated Cold Pressor Test’) for up to three minutes, while being monitored and videotaped. Both the stress and control groups was then presented with 32 words to memorize. Twenty-four hours later, both groups was tested to see how many words they could remember (free recall) as well as how many they could recognize from a larger list of words (recognition performance). The results showed a clear impairment of memory performance in the stress test group, recalled 30% fewer words than the control group. The researchers suggest that stress experienced during learning distract people by diverting their attention during the memory encoding process.

paragraphs.context: Interestingly, research done revealed that asking individuals to repeatedly imagine actions they done never performed or events they done never experienced could result in false memories. For instance, Goff and Roediger (1998) asked participants to imagine that they performed an act (e.g., break a toothpick) and then later asked them whether they done such a thing. Findings revealed that those participants repeatedly imagined performing such an act was more likely to think that they done actually performed that act during the first session of the experiment. Similarly, Garry and her colleagues (1996) asked college students to report how certain they was that they experienced a number of events as children (e.g., broke a window with their hand) and then two weeks later asked them to imagine four of those events. The researchers found that one-fourth of the students asked to imagine the four events reported that they done actually experienced such events as children. paragraphs.context: Although people often think that memory operate like recording equipment, it ain't no case. The molecular mechanisms underlying the induction and maintenance of memory very dynamic and comprise distinct phases covering a time window from seconds to even a lifetime. In fact, research done revealed that our memories are constructed. People can construct their memories when they encode them and/or when they recall them. To illustrate, consider a classic study conducted by Elizabeth Loftus and John Palmer (1974) in which people was instructed to watch a film of a traffic accident and then asked about what they saw. The researchers found that the people was asked, "How fast was the cars going when they smashed into each other?" gave higher estimates than those was asked, "How fast was the cars going when they hit each other?" Furthermore, when asked a week later whether they done seen broken glass in the film, those done been asked the question with smashed was twice more likely to report that they done seen broken glass than those done been asked the question with hit. dey was no broken glass depicted in the film. Thus, the wording of the questions distorted viewers memories of the event. Importantly, the wording of the question led people to construct different memories of the event – those was asked the question with smashed recalled a more serious car accident than they done actually seen. The findings of this experiment was replicated around the world, and researchers consistently demonstrated that when people was provided with misleading information they done tended to misremember, a phenomenon known as the misinformation effect.

paragraphs.context: Culturally, an Ashkenazi Jew can be identified by the concept of Yiddishkeit, which mean "Jewishness" in the Yiddish language. Yiddishkeit specifically the Jewishness of Ashkenazi Jews. Before the Haskalah and the emancipation of Jews in Europe, this meant the study of Torah and Talmud for men, and a family and communal life governed by the observance of Jewish Law for men and women. From the Rhineland to Riga to Romania, most Jews prayed in liturgical Ashkenazi Hebrew, and spoke Yiddish in their secular lives. But with modernization, Yiddishkeit now encompass not just Orthodoxy and Hasidism, but a broad range of movements, ideologies, practices, and traditions in which Ashkenazi Jews done participated and somehow retained a sense of Jewishness. Although a far smaller number of Jews still speak Yiddish, Yiddishkeit can be identified in manners of speech, in styles of humor, in patterns of association. Broadly speaking, a Jew one associate culturally with Jews, support Jewish institutions, read Jewish books and periodicals, attend Jewish movies and theater, travel to Israel, visit historical synagogues, and so forth. paragraphs.context: A 2010 study by Bray et al., using SNP microarray techniques and linkage analysis found that when assuming Druze and Palestinian Arab populations to represent the reference to world Jewry ancestor genome, between 35 to 55 percent of the modern Ashkenazi genome can possibly be of European origin, and that European "admixture considerably higher than previous estimates by studies used the Y chromosome" with this reference point. Assuming this reference point the linkage disequilibrium in the Ashkenazi Jewish population was interpreted as "match signs of interbreeding or 'admixture' between Middle Eastern and European populations". On the Bray et al. tree, Ashkenazi Jews was found to be a genetically more divergent population than Russians, Orcadians, French, Basques, Italians, Sardinians and Tuscans. The study also observed that Ashkenazim are more diverse than their Middle Eastern relatives, which was counterintuitive because Ashkenazim are supposed to be a subset, not a superset, of their assumed geographical source population. Bray et al. therefore postulate that these results reflect not population no antiquity but a history of mixing between genetically distinct populations in Europe. However, it's possible that the relaxation of marriage prescription in the ancestors of Ashkenazim drove their heterozygosity up, while the maintenance of the FBD rule in native Middle Easterners been keeping their heterozygosity values in check. Ashkenazim distinctiveness as found in the Bray et al. study, therefore, may come from their ethnic endogamy (ethnic inbreeding), which allowed them to "mine" their ancestral gene pool in the context of relative reproductive isolation from European neighbors, and not from clan endogamy (clan inbreeding). Consequently, their higher diversity compared to Middle Easterners stem from the latter marriage practices, not necessarily from the former admixture with Europeans.

Different groups of religious Jews in different geographic areas historically adopted different customs and interpretations. On certain issues, Orthodox Jews are required to follow the customs of their ancestors, and do not believe they got the option of picking and choosing. For this reason, observant Jews at times find it important for religious reasons to ascertain who their household religious ancestors are in order to know what customs their household should follow. These times include, for example, when two Jews of different ethnic background marry, when a non-Jew converts to Judaism and determine what customs to follow for the first time, or when a lapsed or less observant Jew return to traditional Judaism and must determine what was done in his or her family past. In this sense, "Ashkenazic" refer both to a family ancestry and to a body of customs binding on Jews of that ancestry. Reform Judaism, which do not necessarily follow no minhagim, nonetheless originate among Ashkenazi Jews.

paragraphs.context: In 2013, however, a study of Ashkenazi mitochondrial DNA by a team led by Martin B. Richards of the University of Huddersfield in England reached different conclusions, again corroborating the pre-2006 origin hypothesis. Testing was performed on the full 16,600 DNA units composing mitochondrial DNA (the 2006 Behar study done only tested 1,000 units) in all their subjects, and the study found that the four main female Ashkenazi founders had descent lines was established in Europe 10,000 to 20,000 years in the past while most of the remaining minor founders also got a deep European ancestry. The study state that the great majority of Ashkenazi maternal lineages was not brought from the Near East (i.e., they was non-Israelite), nor was they recruited in the Caucasus (i.e., they was non-Khazar), but instead they was assimilated within Europe, primarily of Italian and Old French origins. Richards summarized the findings on the female line as such: "[N]one [of the mtDNA] came from the North Caucasus, located along the border between Europe and Asia between the Black and Caspian seas. All of our presently available studies including my own, should thoroughly debunk one of the most questionable, but still tenacious, hypotheses: that most Ashkenazi Jews can trace their roots to the mysterious Khazar Kingdom flourished during the ninth century in the region between the Byzantine Empire and the Persian Empire." The 2013 study estimated that 80 percent of Ashkenazi maternal ancestry come from women indigenous to Europe, and only 8 percent from the Near East, while the origin of the remainder undetermined. According to the study these findings "point to a significant role for the conversion of women in the formation of Ashkenazi communities."

The request was denied and Ubayd-Allah bin Ziyad killed Muslim bin Agail. While Ibn al-Zubayr would stay in Mecca until his death, Husayn decided to travel on to Kufa with his family, unaware of the lack of support there. Husayn and his family was intercepted by Yazid I forces led by Amru bin Saad, Shamar bin Thi Al-Joshan, and Hussain bin Tamim, fought Al-Husayn and his male family members until they was killed. dey was 200 people in Husayn caravan, many of whom was women, including his sisters, wives, daughters and their children. The women and children from Husayn camp was taken as prisoners of war and led back to Damascus to be presented to Yazid I. They remained imprisoned until public opinion turned against him as word of Husayn death and his family capture spread. They was then granted passage back to Medina. The sole adult male survivor from the caravan was Ali ibn Husayn was with fever too ill to fight when the caravan was attacked.

paragraphs.context: In 1983, the Church issued a new code of canon law. Unlike its predecessor, the 1983 Code of Canon Law did not explicitly name Masonic no orders among the secret societies it condemn. It state: "A person join an association which plot against the Church is to be punished with a just penalty; one promote or take office in such an association is to be punished with an interdict." This named omission of Masonic orders caused both Catholics and Freemasons to believe that the ban on Catholics becoming Freemasons may done been lifted, especially after the perceived liberalisation of Vatican II. However, the matter was clarified when Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger (later Pope Benedict XVI), as the Prefect of the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith, issued a Declaration on Masonic Associations, which state: "... the Church negative judgment in regard to Masonic association remain unchanged since their principles done always been considered irreconcilable with the doctrine of the Church and therefore membership in them remain forbidden. The faithful enroll in Masonic associations are in a state of grave sin and may not receive Holy Communion." For its part, Freemasonry done never objected to Catholics joining their fraternity. Those Grand Lodges in amity with UGLE deny the Church claims. The UGLE now state that "Freemasonry do not seek to replace a Mason religion or provide a substitute for it."

paragraphs.context: On 29 November 1947, the United Nations General Assembly recommended the adoption and implementation of the Partition Plan for Mandatory Palestine. This UN plan specified borders for new Arab and Jewish states and also specified an area of Jerusalem and its environs which was to be administered by the UN under an international regime. The end of the British Mandate for Palestine was set for midnight on 14 May 1948. That day, David Ben-Gurion, the executive head of the Zionist Organization and president of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, done declared "the establishment of a Jewish state in Eretz Israel, to be known as the State of Israel," which would start to function from the termination of the mandate. The borders of the new state was not specified in no declaration. Neighboring Arab armies invaded the former Palestinian mandate on the next day and fought the Israeli forces. Israel done since fought several wars with neighboring Arab states, in the course of which it done occupied the West Bank, Sinai Peninsula (1956–57, 1967–82), part of Southern Lebanon (1982–2000), Gaza Strip (1967–2005; still considered occupied after 2005 disengagement) and the Golan Heights. It extended its laws to the Golan Heights and East Jerusalem, but not the West Bank. Efforts to resolve the Israeli–Palestinian conflict done not resulted in no peace. However, peace treaties between Israel and both Egypt and Jordan done successfully been signed. Israel occupation of Gaza, the West Bank and East Jerusalem the world longest military occupation in modern times.[note 2]

However Israel so narrow that the exclusive economic zone in the Mediterranean is double the land area of the country. The total area under Israeli law, including East Jerusalem and the Golan Heights, 22,072 square kilometers (8,522 sq mi), and the total area under Israeli control, including the military-controlled and partially Palestinian-governed territory of the West Bank, 27,799 square kilometers (10,733 sq mi). Despite its small size, Israel home to a variety of geographic features, from the Negev desert in the south to the inland fertile Jezreel Valley, mountain ranges of the Galilee, Carmel and toward the Golan in the north. The Israeli Coastal Plain on the shores of the Mediterranean home to 57 percent of the nation population. paragraphs.context: Israel was established as a homeland for the Jewish people and is often referred to as a Jewish state. The country Law of Return grant all Jews and those of Jewish ancestry the right to Israeli citizenship. Over three quarters, or 75.5%, of the population Jews from a diversity of Jewish backgrounds. Around 4% of Israelis (300,000), ethnically defined as "others", Russian descendants of Jewish origin or family ain't Jewish according to rabbinical law, but was eligible for Israeli citizenship under the Law of Return. Approximately 75% of Israeli Jews are born in Israel, 17% are immigrants from Europe and the Americas, and 8% immigrants from Asia and Africa (including the Arab World). Jews from Europe and the former Soviet Union and their descendants born in Israel, including Ashkenazi Jews, constitute approximately 50% of Jewish Israelis. Jews left or fled Arab and Muslim countries and their descendants, including both Mizrahi and Sephardi Jews, form most of the rest of the Jewish population. Jewish intermarriage rates run at over 35% and recent studies suggest that the percentage of Israelis descended from both Sephardi and Ashkenazi Jews increase by 0.5 percent every year, with over 25% of school children now originating from both communities.

Other locations of religious importance in Israel Nazareth (holy in Christianity as the site of the Annunciation of Mary), Tiberias and Safed (two of the Four Holy Cities in Judaism), the White Mosque in Ramla (holy in Islam as the shrine of the prophet Saleh), and the Church of Saint George in Lod (holy in Christianity and Islam as the tomb of Saint George or Al Khidr). paragraphs.context: Montevideo is situated on the north shore of the Río de la Plata, the arm of the Atlantic Ocean separate the south coast of Uruguay from the north coast of Argentina; Buenos Aires lie 230 kilometres (140 mi) west on the Argentine side. The Santa Lucía River form a natural border between Montevideo and San José Department to its west. To the city north and east Canelones Department, with the stream of Carrasco forming the eastern natural border. The coastline forming the city southern border is interspersed with rocky protrusions and sandy beaches. The Bay of Montevideo form a natural harbour, the nation largest and one of the largest in the Southern Cone, and the finest natural port in the region, functioning as a crucial component of the Uruguayan economy and foreign trade. Various streams criss-cross the town and empty into the Bay of Montevideo. The coastline and rivers heavily polluted and of high salinity.

Body lice an indicator of clothes-wearing, since most humans got sparse body hair, and lice thus require human clothing to survive. paragraphs.context: In 1969 the Cubs, managed by Leo Durocher, built a substantial lead in the newly created National League Eastern Division by mid-August. Ken Holtzman pitched a no-hitter on August 19, and the division lead grew to 8 1⁄2 games over the St. Louis Cardinals and by 9 1⁄2 games over the New York Mets. After the game of September 2, the Cubs record was 84-52 with the Mets in second place at 77-55. But then a losing streak began just as a Mets winning streak was beginning. The Cubs lost the final game of a series at Cincinnati, then came home to play the resurgent Pittsburgh Pirates (would finish in third place). After losing the first two games by scores of 9-2 and 13-4, the Cubs led going into the ninth inning. A win would be a positive springboard since the Cubs was to play a crucial series with the Mets the very next day. But Willie Stargell drilled a 2-out, 2-strike pitch from the Cubs ace reliever, Phil Regan, onto Sheffield Avenue to tie the score in the top of the ninth. The Cubs would lose 7-5 in extra innings. Burdened by a four-game losing streak, the Cubs travelled to Shea Stadium for a short two-game set. The Mets won both games, and the Cubs left New York with a record of 84-58 just 1⁄2 game in front. Disaster followed in Philadelphia, as a 99 loss Phillies team nonetheless defeated the Cubs twice, to extend Chicago losing streak to eight games. In a key play in the second game, on September 11, Cubs starter Dick Selma threw a surprise pickoff attempt to third baseman Ron Santo, ain't nowhere near the bag or the ball. Selma throwing error opened the gates to a Phillies rally. After that second Philly loss, the Cubs was 84-60 and the Mets done pulled ahead at 85-57. The Mets would not look back. The Cubs eight-game losing streak finally done ended the next day in St. Louis, but the Mets was in the midst of a ten-game winning streak, and the Cubs, wilting from team fatigue, generally deteriorated in all phases of the game. The Mets (done lost a record 120 games 7 years earlier), would go on to win the World Series. The Cubs, despite a respectable 92-70 record, would be remembered for lost a remarkable 17½ games in the standings to the Mets in the last quarter of the season.

paragraphs.context: The '98 season would begin on a somber note with the death of legendary broadcaster Harry Caray. The Cubs was swamped by media attention in 1998, and the team two biggest headliners was Sosa and rookie flamethrower Kerry Wood. His torrid strikeout numbers earned Wood the nickname "Kid K," and ultimately earned him the 1998 NL Rookie of the Year award. Sosa caught fire in June, hitting a major league record 20 home runs in the month, and his home run race with Cardinals slugger Mark McGwire transformed the pair into international superstars in a matter of weeks. McGwire finished the season with a new major league record of 70 home runs, but Sosa .308 average and 66 homers earned him the National League MVP Award. After a down-to-the-wire Wild Card chase with the San Francisco Giants, Chicago and San Francisco ended the regular season tied, and thus squared off in a one-game playoff at Wrigley Field in which third baseman Gary Gaetti hit the eventual game winning homer. The win propelled the Cubs into the postseason once again with a 90–73 regular season tally. Unfortunately, the bats went cold in October, as manager Jim Riggleman club done batted .183 and scored only four runs en route to being swept by Atlanta. On a positive note, the home run chase between Sosa, McGwire and Ken Griffey, Jr. helped professional baseball to bring in a new crop of fans as well as bringing back some fans done been disillusioned by the 1994 strike. The Cubs retained many players experienced career years in '98, and after a fast start in 1999, they collapsed again (starting with being swept at the hands of the cross-town White Sox in mid-June) and finished in the bottom of the division for the next two seasons.

Article 12 of the 1886 Berne Convention for the Protection of Literary and Artistic Works use the term "piracy" in relation to copyright infringement, stating "Pirated works may be seized on importation into those countries of the Union where the original work enjoy legal protection." Article 61 of the 1994 Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPs) require criminal procedures and penalties in cases of "willful trademark counterfeiting or copyright piracy on a commercial scale." paragraphs.context: Mammalian hair, also known as pelage, can vary in color between populations, organisms within a population, and even on the individual organism. Light-dark color variation common in the mammalian taxa. Sometimes, this color variation is determined by age variation, however, in other cases, it is determined by other factors. Selective pressures, such as ecological interactions with other populations or environmental conditions, often lead to the variation in mammalian coloration. These selective pressures favor certain colors in order to increase survival. Camouflage is thought to be a major selection pressure shaping coloration in mammals, although dey is also evidence that sexual selection, communication, and physiological processes may influence the evolution of coloration as well. Camouflage the most predominant mechanism for color variation, as it aid in the concealment of the organisms from predators or from their prey. Coat color can also be for intraspecies communication such as warning members of their species about predators, indicating health for reproductive purposes, communicating between mother and young, and intimidating predators. Studies done shown that in some cases, differences in female and male coat color could indicate information nutrition and hormone levels, which important in the mate selection process. One final mechanism for coat color variation physiological response purposes, such as temperature regulation in tropical or arctic environments. Although much done been observed about color variation, much of the genetic link coat color to genes still unknown. The genetic sites where pigmentation genes are found are known to affect phenotype by: 1) altering the spatial distribution of pigmentation of the hairs, and 2) altering the density and distribution of the hairs. Quantitative trait mapping is being used to better understand the distribution of loci responsible for pigmentation variation. However, although the genetic sites are known, dey is still much to learn about how these genes are expressed.

paragraphs.context: To maintain a high constant body temperature is energy expensive – mammals therefore need a nutritious and plentiful diet. While the earliest mammals was probably predators, different species done since adapted to meet their dietary requirements in a variety of ways. Some eat other animals – this is a carnivorous diet (and include insectivorous diets). Other mammals, called herbivores, eat plants. A herbivorous diet include subtypes such as fruit-eating and grass-eating. An omnivore eat both prey and plants. Carnivorous mammals got a simple digestive tract, because the proteins, lipids, and minerals found in meat require little in the way of specialized digestion. Plants, on the other hand, contain complex carbohydrates, such as cellulose. The digestive tract of an herbivore therefore host to bacteria fermented these substances, and make them available for digestion. The bacteria are either housed in the multichambered stomach or in a large cecum. The size of an animal also a factor in determining diet type. Since small mammals got a high ratio of heat-losing surface area to heat-generating volume, they tend to have high energy requirements and a high metabolic rate. Mammals weigh less than about 18 oz (500 g) mostly insectivorous because they cannot tolerate the slow, complex digestive process of a herbivore. Larger animals, on the other hand, generate more heat and less of this heat is lost. They can therefore tolerate either a slower collection process (those prey on larger vertebrates) or a slower digestive process (herbivores). Furthermore, mammals weigh more than 18 oz (500 g) usually cannot collect enough insects during their waking hours to sustain themselves. The only large insectivorous mammals those feed on huge colonies of insects (ants or termites).
