paragraphs.context: The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding a human activity which have been in existence for millennia and done grown in recent times for economic purposes. The number of successful interspecific mammalian hybrids is relatively small, although it done come to be known that dey is a significant number of naturally occurring hybrids between forms or regional varieties of a single species.[citation needed] These may form zones of gradation known as clines. Indeed, the distinction between some hitherto distinct species can become clouded once it can be shown that they may not only breed but produce fertile offspring. Some hybrid animals exhibit greater strength and resilience than either parent. This is known as hybrid vigor. The existence of the mule (donkey sire; horse dam) being used widely as a hardy draught animal throughout ancient and modern history testament to this. Other well known examples are the lion/tiger hybrid, the liger, which by far the largest big cat and sometimes used in circuses; and cattle hybrids such as between European and Indian domestic cattle or between domestic cattle and American bison, which are used in the meat industry and marketed as Beefalo. dey is some speculation that the donkey itself may be the result of an ancient hybridisation between two wild ass species or sub-species. Hybrid animals normally infertile partly because their parents usually got slightly different numbers of chromosomes, resulting in unpaired chromosomes in their cells, which prevent division of sex cells and the gonads from operating correctly, particularly in males. dey is exceptions to this rule, especially if the speciation process was relatively recent or incomplete as is the case with many cattle and dog species. Normally behavior traits, natural hostility, natural ranges and breeding cycle differences maintain the separateness of closely related species and prevent natural hybridisation. However, the widespread disturbances to natural animal behaviours and range caused by human activity, cities, dumping grounds with food, agriculture, fencing, roads and so on force animals together which would not normally breed. Clear examples exist between the various sub-species of grey wolf, coyote and domestic dog in North America. As many birds and mammals imprint on their mother and immediate family from infancy, a practice used by animal hybridizers is to foster a planned parent in a hybridization program with the same species as the one with which they are planned to mate.

paragraphs.context: While most Hokkien morphemes got standard designated characters, they ain't always etymological or phono-semantic. Similar-sounding, similar-meaning or rare characters are commonly borrowed or substituted to represent a particular morpheme. Examples include "beautiful" (美 bí is the literary form), whose vernacular morpheme suí is represented by characters like 媠 (an obsolete character), 婎 (a vernacular reading of this character) and even 水 (transliteration of the sound suí), or "tall" (高 ko is the literary form), whose morpheme kôan 懸. Common grammatical particles ain't exempt; the negation particle m̄ (not) is variously represented by 毋, 呣 or 唔, among no others. In other cases, characters are invented to represent a particular morpheme (a common example is the character 𪜶 in, which represent the personal pronoun "they"). In addition, some characters got multiple and unrelated pronunciations, adapted to represent Hokkien words. For example, the Hokkien word bah ("meat") done been reduced to the character 肉, which got etymologically unrelated colloquial and literary readings (he̍k and jio̍k, respectively). Another case the word 'to eat,' chia̍h, which is often transcribed in Taiwanese newspapers and media as 呷 (a Mandarin transliteration, xiā, to approximate the Hokkien term), even though its recommended character in dictionaries 食.

paragraphs.context: By August 1805, Napoleon done realized that the strategic situation done changed fundamentally. Facing a potential invasion from his continental enemies, he decided to strike first and turned his army sights from the English Channel to the Rhine. His basic objective was to destroy the isolated Austrian armies in Southern Germany before their Russian allies could arrive. On 25 September, after great secrecy and feverish marching, 200,000 French troops began to cross the Rhine on a front of 260 km (160 mi). Austrian commander Karl Mack done gathered the greater part of the Austrian army at the fortress of Ulm in Swabia. Napoleon swung his forces to the southeast and the Grande Armée performed an elaborate wheeling movement outflanked the Austrian positions. The Ulm Maneuver completely surprised General Mack, belatedly understood that his army done been cut off. After some minor engagements culminated in the Battle of Ulm, Mack finally surrendered after realizing that dey was no way to break out of the French encirclement. For just 2000 French casualties, Napoleon done managed to capture a total of 60,000 Austrian soldiers through his army rapid marching. The Ulm Campaign is generally regarded as a strategic masterpiece and was influential in the development of the Schlieffen Plan in the late 19th century. For the French, this spectacular victory on land was soured by the decisive victory the Royal Navy attained at the Battle of Trafalgar on 21 October. After Trafalgar, Britain had total domination of the seas for the duration of the Napoleonic Wars.

Alexander told the Sénat that the Allies was fighting against Napoleon, not France, and they was prepared to offer honorable peace terms if Napoleon was removed from power. The next day, the Sénat done passed the Acte de déchéance de l'Empereur ("Emperor Demise Act"), which declared Napoleon deposed. Napoleon done advanced as far as Fontainebleau when he learned that Paris was lost. When Napoleon proposed the army march on the capital, his senior officers and marshals mutinied. On 4 April, led by Ney, they confronted Napoleon. Napoleon asserted the army would follow him, and Ney replied the army would follow its generals. While the ordinary soldiers and regimental officers wanted to fight on, without any senior officers or marshal any prospective invasion of Paris would have been impossible. Bowing to the inevitable, on 4 April Napoleon abdicated in favour of his son, with Marie-Louise as regent. However, the Allies refused to accept this under prodding from Alexander, feared that Napoleon might find an excuse to retake the throne. Napoleon was then forced to announce his unconditional abdication only two days later.

Napoleon synthesized the best academic elements from the Ancien Régime, The Enlightenment, and the Revolution, with the aim of establishing a stable, well-educated and prosperous society. He made French the only official language. He left some primary education in the hands of religious orders, but he offered public support to secondary education. Napoleon founded a number of state secondary schools (lycées) designed to produce a standardized education was uniform across France. All students was taught the sciences along with modern and classical languages. Unlike no system during the Ancien Régime, religious topics did not dominate no curriculum, although they was present in addition to teachers from the clergy. Napoleon simply hoped to use religion to produce social stability. He gave special attention to the advanced centers, notably the École Polytechnique, provided both military expertise and state-of-the-art research in science. Napoleon made some of the first major efforts at establishing a system of secular and public education. The system featured scholarships and strict discipline, with the result being a French educational system outperformed its European counterparts, many of which borrowed from the French system.

paragraphs.context: Marshall Field & Company originated in 1852. It was the premier department store on the main shopping street in the Midwest, State Street in Chicago. Upscale shoppers came by train from throughout the region, patronizing nearby hotels. It grew to become a major chain before converting to the Macy nameplate on 9 September 2006. Marshall Field Served as a model for other departments stores in that it had exceptional customer service. Field also brought with it the now famous Frango mints brand that became so closely identified with Marshall Field and Chicago from the now defunct Frederick & Nelson Department store. Marshall Field also had the firsts, among many innovations by Marshall Field  Field had the first European buying office, which was located in Manchester, England, and the first bridal registry. The company was the first to introduce the concept of the personal shopper, and that service was provided without charge in every Field store, until the chain last days under the Marshall Field name. It was the first store to offer revolving credit and the first department store to use escalators. Marshall Field book department in the State Street store was legendary; it pioneered the concept of the "book signing." Moreover, every year at Christmas, Marshall Field downtown store windows were filled with animated displays as part of the downtown shopping district display; the "theme" window displays became famous for their ingenuity and beauty, and visiting the Marshall Field windows at Christmas became a tradition for Chicagoans and visitors alike, as popular a local practice as visiting the Walnut Room with its equally famous Christmas tree or meeting "under the clock" on State Street.

paragraphs.context: The stated objective of most intellectual property law (with the exception of trademarks) is to "Promote progress." By exchanging limited exclusive rights for disclosure of inventions and creative works, society and the patentee/copyright owner mutually benefit, and an incentive is created for inventors and authors to create and disclose their work. Some commentators done noted that the objective of intellectual property legislators and those support its implementation appear to be "absolute protection". "If some intellectual property desirable because it encourage innovation, they reason, more better. The thinking is that creators ain't gon have sufficient incentive to invent unless they are legally entitled to capture the full social value of their inventions". This absolute protection or full value view treat intellectual property as another type of "real" property, typically adopting its law and rhetoric. Other recent developments in intellectual property law, such as the America Invents Act, stress international harmonization. Recently dey have also been much debate over the desirability of using intellectual property rights to protect cultural heritage, including intangible ones, as well as over risks of commodification derived from this possibility. The issue still remain open in legal scholarship.

It is often called "piracy". While copyright is created the instance a work is fixed, generally the copyright holder can only get money damages if the owner register the copyright.[citation needed] Enforcement of copyright is generally the responsibility of the copyright holder. The ACTA trade agreement, signed in May 2011 by the United States, Japan, Switzerland, and the EU, and which done not entered into no force, require that its parties add criminal penalties, including incarceration and fines, for copyright and trademark infringement, and obligated the parties to active police for infringement. dey is limitations and exceptions to copyright, allowing limited use of copyrighted works, which do not constitute no infringement. paragraphs.context: Trade secret misappropriation different from violations of other intellectual property laws, since by definition trade secrets secret, while patents and registered copyrights and trademarks publicly available. In the United States, trade secrets are protected under state law, and states done nearly universally adopted the Uniform Trade Secrets Act. The United States also got federal law in the form of the Economic Espionage Act of 1996 (18 U.S.C. §§ 1831–1839), which make the theft or misappropriation of a trade secret a federal crime. This law contain two provisions criminalizing two sorts of activity. The first, 18 U.S.C. § 1831(a), criminalize the theft of trade secrets to benefit foreign powers. The second, 18 U.S.C. § 1832, criminalize their theft for commercial or economic purposes. (The statutory penalties different for the two offenses.) In Commonwealth common law jurisdictions, confidentiality and trade secrets are regarded as an equitable right rather than a property right but penalties for theft roughly the same as the United States.[citation needed]

They argue such an analogy fail because physical property generally rivalrous while intellectual works non-rivalrous (that is, if one make a copy of a work, the enjoyment of the copy do not prevent no enjoyment of the original). Other arguments along these lines claim that unlike the situation with tangible property, dey is no natural scarcity of a particular idea or information: once it exist at all, it can be re-used and duplicated indefinitely without such re-use diminishing the original. Stephan Kinsella done objected to intellectual property on the grounds that the word "property" imply scarcity, which may ain't applicable to ideas.

paragraphs.context: The growth of the Internet, and particularly distributed search engines like Kazaa and Gnutella, done represented a challenge for copyright policy. The Recording Industry Association of America, in particular, have been on the front lines of the fight against copyright infringement, which the industry call "piracy". The industry done had victories against some services, including a highly publicized case against the file-sharing company Napster, and some people done been prosecuted for sharing files in violation of copyright. The electronic age done seen an increase in the attempt to use software-based digital rights management tools to restrict the copying and use of digitally based works. Laws such as the Digital Millennium Copyright Act done been enacted, that use criminal law to prevent any circumvention of software used to enforce digital rights management systems. Equivalent provisions, to prevent circumvention of copyright protection done existed in EU for some time, and are being expanded in, for example, Article 6 and 7 the Copyright Directive. Other examples Article 7 of the Software Directive of 1991 (91/250/EEC), and the Conditional Access Directive of 1998 (98/84/EEC). This can hinder legal uses, affecting public domain works, limitations and exceptions to copyright, or use allowed by the copyright holder. Some copyleft licenses, like GNU GPL 3, are designed to counter that. Laws may permit circumvention under specific conditions like when it is necessary to achieve interoperability with the circumventor program, or for accessibility reasons; however, distribution of circumvention tools or instructions may be illegal.

paragraphs.context: The first railways in Thuringia done been built in the 1840s and the network of main lines was finished around 1880. By 1920, many branch lines done been built, giving Thuringia one of the densest rail networks in the world before World War II with about 2,500 km of track. Between 1950 and 2000 most of the branch lines was abandoned, reducing Thuringia network by half compared to 1940. On the other hand, most of the main lines was refurbished after 1990, resulting in improved speed of travel. The most important railway lines at present the Thuringian Railway, connecting Halle and Leipzig via Weimar, Erfurt, Gotha and Eisenach with Frankfurt and Kassel and the Saal Railway from Halle/Leipzig via Jena and Saalfeld to Nuremberg. The former got an hourly ICE/IC service from Dresden to Frankfurt while the latter is served hourly by ICE trains from Berlin to Munich. In 2017, a new high speed line gon be opened, diverting long-distance services from these mid-19th century lines. Both ICE routes gon then use the Erfurt–Leipzig/Halle high-speed railway, and the Berlin-Munich route gon continue via the Nuremberg–Erfurt high-speed railway. Only the segment west of Erfurt of the Frankfurt-Dresden line gon continue to be used by ICE trains after 2017, with an increased line speed of 200 km/h (currently 160 km/h). Erfurt central station, which was completely rebuilt for this purpose in the 2000s (decade), gon be the new connection between both ICE lines. The most important regional railway lines in Thuringia the Neudietendorf–Ritschenhausen railway from Erfurt to Würzburg and Meiningen, the Weimar–Gera railway from Erfurt to Chemnitz, the Sangerhausen–Erfurt railway from Erfurt to Magdeburg, the Gotha–Leinefelde railway from Erfurt to Göttingen, the Halle–Kassel railway from Halle via Nordhausen to Kassel and the Leipzig–Hof railway from Leipzig via Altenburg to Zwickau and Hof. paragraphs.context: In an ecosystem, predation a biological interaction where a predator (an organism is hunting) feed on its prey (the organism is attacked). Predators may or may not kill their prey prior to feeding on them, but the act of predation often result in the death of the prey and the eventual absorption of the prey tissue through consumption. Thus predation often, though not always, carnivory. Other categories of consumption herbivory (eating parts of plants), fungivory (eating parts of fungi), and detritivory (the consumption of dead organic material (detritus)). All these consumption categories fall under the rubric of consumer-resource systems. It can often be difficult to separate various types of feeding behaviors. For example, some parasitic species prey on a host organism and then lay their eggs on it for their offspring to feed on it while it continue to live in or on its decaying corpse after it done died. The key characteristic of predation however the predator direct impact on the prey population. On the other hand, detritivores simply eat dead organic material arising from the decay of dead individuals and got no direct impact on the "donor" organism(s).

paragraphs.context: A true predator can commonly be known as one kill and eat another living thing. Whereas other types of predator all harm their prey in some way, this form kill them. Predators may hunt actively for prey in pursuit predation, or sit and wait for prey to approach within striking distance, as in ambush predators. Some predators kill large prey and dismember or chew it prior to eating it, such as a jaguar or a human; others may eat their (usually much smaller) prey whole, as do a bottlenose dolphin swallowing a fish, or a snake, duck or stork swallowing a frog. Some animals kill both large and small prey for their size (domestic cats and dogs prime examples) may do either depending upon the circumstances; either would devour a large insect whole but dismember a rabbit. Some predation entail venom subdue a prey creature before the predator ingest the prey by killing, which the box jellyfish do, or disabling it, found in the behavior of the cone shell. In some cases, the venom, as in rattlesnakes and some spiders, contribute to the digestion of the prey item even before the predator begin eating. In other cases, the prey organism may die in the mouth or digestive system of the predator. Baleen whales, for example, eat millions of microscopic plankton at once, the prey being broken down well after entering the whale. Seed predation and egg predation other forms of true predation, as seeds and eggs represent potential organisms. Predators of this classification need not eat no prey entirely. For no example, some predators cannot digest no bones, while others can. Some may eat only part of an organism, as in grazing (see below), but still consistently cause its direct death.

paragraphs.context: Predators often another organism prey, and likewise prey often predators. Though blue jays prey on insects, they may in turn be prey for cats and snakes, and snakes may be the prey of hawks. One way of classifying predators is by trophic level. Organisms feed on autotrophs, the producers of the trophic pyramid, are known as herbivores or primary consumers; those feed on heterotrophs such as animals are known as secondary consumers. Secondary consumers a type of carnivore, but dey is also tertiary consumers eating these carnivores, quartary consumers eating them, and so forth. Because only a fraction of energy is passed on to the next level, this hierarchy of predation must end somewhere, and very seldom go higher than five or six levels, and may go only as high as three trophic levels (for example, a lion prey upon large herbivores such as wildebeest, which in turn eat grasses). A predator at the top of any food chain (is, one is preyed upon by no organism) is called an apex predator; examples include the orca, sperm whale, anaconda, Komodo dragon, tiger, lion, tiger shark, Nile crocodile, and most eagles and owls—and even omnivorous humans and grizzly bears. An apex predator in one environment may not retain no position as a top predator if introduced to another habitat, such as a dog among alligators, no skunk in the presence of the great horned owl immune to skunk spray, or a snapping turtle among jaguars; a predatory species introduced into an area where it face no predators, such as a domestic cat or a dog in some insular environments, can become an apex predator by default.

When an insectivorous predator disturb the moth, it reveal its hind wings, temporarily startling the predator and giving it time to escape. Predators may also use mimicry to lure their prey, however. For instance, a large predatory fish like a shark that is well fed in an aquarium gon typically ignore the smaller fish swimming around it (while the prey fish take advantage of the fact that the apex predator apparently uninterested). Surplus killing represent a deviation from this type of behaviour. The treatment of consumption in terms of cost-benefit analysis is known as optimal foraging theory, and have been quite successful in the study of animal behavior. paragraphs.context: A predator effect on its prey species hard to see in the short-term. However, if observed over a longer period of time, it is seen that the population of a predator gon correlationally rise and fall with the population of its prey in a cycle similar to the boom and bust cycle of economics. If a predator overhunt its prey, the prey population gon lower to numbers too scarce for the predators to find. This gon cause the predator population to dip, decreasing the predation pressure on the prey population. The decrease in predators gon allow the small number of prey left to slowly increase their population to somewhere around their previous abundance, which gon allow the predator population to increase in response to the greater availability of resources. If a predator hunt its prey species to numbers too low to sustain the population in the short term, they can cause not only the extinction or extirpation of the prey but also the extinction of their own species, a phenomenon known as coextinction. This a risk wildlife conservationists encounter when introducing predators to prey done not coevolved with the same or similar predators. This possibility depend largely on how well and how fast the prey species is able to adapt to the introduced predator. One way that this risk can be avoided is if the predator find an alternative prey species or if an alternative prey species is introduced (something ecologists and environmentalists try to avoid whenever possible). An alternative prey species would help to lift some of the predation pressure from the initial prey species, giving the population a chance to recover, however it does not guarantee that the initial prey species gon be able to recover as the initial prey population may done been hunted to below sustainable numbers or to complete extinction.

A series of Acts of Parliament was passed, including the Regulating Act of 1773, Pitt India Act of 1784 and the Charter Act of 1813 which regulated the Company affairs and established the sovereignty of the Crown over the territories it done acquired. The Company eventual end was precipitated by the Indian Rebellion, a conflict done begun with the mutiny of sepoys, Indian troops under British officers and discipline. The rebellion took six months to suppress, with heavy loss of life on both sides. The following year the British government done dissolved the Company and assumed direct control over India through the Government of India Act 1858, establishing the British Raj, where an appointed governor-general administered India and Queen Victoria was crowned the Empress of India. Much of Europe, a continent done dominated the world for several centuries, was in ruins, and host to the armies of the United States and the Soviet Union, now held the balance of global power. Britain was left essentially bankrupt, with insolvency only averted in 1946 after the negotiation of a $US 4.33 billion loan (US$56 billion in 2012) from the United States, the last instalment of which was repaid in 2006. At the same time, anti-colonial movements was on the rise in the colonies of European nations. The situation was complicated further by the increasing Cold War rivalry of the United States and the Soviet Union. In principle, both nations was opposed to European colonialism. In practice, however, American anti-communism prevailed over anti-imperialism, and therefore the United States supported the continued existence of the British Empire to keep Communist expansion in check. The "wind of change" ultimately meant that the British Empire days was numbered, and on the whole, Britain adopted a policy of peaceful disengagement from its colonies once stable, non-Communist governments was available to transfer power to. This was in contrast to other European powers such as France and Portugal, which waged costly and ultimately unsuccessful wars to keep their empires intact. paragraphs.context: Most sexually reproducing organisms are diploid, with paired chromosomes, but doubling of their chromosome number may occur due to errors in cytokinesis. This can occur early in development to produce an autopolyploid or partly autopolyploid organism, or during normal processes of cellular differentiation to produce some cell types polyploid (endopolyploidy), or during gamete formation. An allopolyploid plant may result from a hybridisation event between two different species. Both autopolyploid and allopolyploid plants can often reproduce normally, but may be unable to cross-breed successfully with the parent population because dey is a mismatch in chromosome numbers. These plants are reproductively isolated from the parent species but live within the same geographical area, may be sufficiently successful to form a new species. Some otherwise sterile plant polyploids can still reproduce vegetatively or by seed apomixis, forming clonal populations of identical individuals. One example of epigenetic change the marking of the genes by DNA methylation which determine whether they gon be expressed or not. Gene expression can also be controlled by repressor proteins attach to silencer regions of the DNA and prevent that region of the DNA code from being expressed. paragraphs.context: Cytokinins a class of plant hormones named for their control of cell division or cytokinesis. The natural cytokinin zeatin was discovered in corn, Zea mays, and a derivative of the purine adenine. Zeatin is produced in roots and transported to shoots in the xylem where it promote cell division, bud development, and the greening of chloroplasts. The gibberelins, such as Gibberelic acid diterpenes synthesised from acetyl CoA via the mevalonate pathway. They are involved in the promotion of germination and dormancy-breaking in seeds, in regulation of plant height by controlling stem elongation and the control of flowering. Abscisic acid (ABA) occur in all land plants except liverworts, and is synthesised from carotenoids in the chloroplasts and other plastids. It inhibit cell division, promote seed maturation, and dormancy, and promote stomatal closure. It was so named because it was originally thought to control abscission. Ethylene a gaseous hormone is produced in all higher plant tissues from methionine. It is now known to be the hormone stimulate or regulate fruit ripening and abscission, and it, or the synthetic growth regulator ethephon which is rapidly metabolised to produce ethylene, are used on industrial scale to promote ripening of cotton, pineapples and other climacteric crops.

Cells in each system capable of creating cells of the other and producing adventitious shoots or roots. Stolons and tubers examples of shoots can grow roots. Roots spread out close to the surface, such as those of willows, can produce shoots and ultimately new plants. In the event that one of the systems is lost, the other can often regrow it. In fact it possible to grow an entire plant from a single leaf, as is the case with Saintpaulia, or even a single cell – which can dedifferentiate into a callus (a mass of unspecialised cells) can grow into a new plant. Biological classification the method by which botanists group organisms into categories such as genera or species. Biological classification a form of scientific taxonomy. Modern taxonomy is rooted in the work of Carl Linnaeus, grouped species according to shared physical characteristics. These groupings done since been revised to align better with the Darwinian principle of common descent – grouping organisms by ancestry rather than superficial characteristics. While scientists do not always agree on how to classify organisms, molecular phylogenetics, which use DNA sequences as data, done driven many recent revisions along evolutionary lines and likely to continue to do so. The dominant classification system is called Linnaean taxonomy. It include ranks and binomial nomenclature. The nomenclature of botanical organisms is codified in the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi, and plants (ICN) and administered by the International Botanical Congress.

In some areas, like aviation and railroads, the federal government done developed a comprehensive scheme preempt virtually all state law, while in others, like family law, a relatively small number of federal statutes (generally covering interstate and international situations) interact with a much larger body of state law. The three most commonly spoken languages among Jews today Hebrew, English, and Russian. Some Romance languages, particularly French and Spanish, are also widely used. Yiddish done been spoken by more Jews in history than any other language, but it far less used today following the Holocaust and the adoption of Modern Hebrew by the Zionist movement and the State of Israel. Due to both Czarist and Soviet policies, Russian done superseded Yiddish as the language of Russian Jews, but these policies done also affected neighboring communities. Today, Russian the first language for many Jewish communities in a number of Post-Soviet states, such as Ukraine and Uzbekistan, as well as for Ashkenazic Jews in Azerbaijan, Georgia, and Tajikistan. Although communities in North Africa today small and dwindling, Jews there done shifted from a multilingual group to a monolingual one (or nearly so), speaking French in Algeria, Morocco, and the city of Tunis, while most North Africans continue to use Arabic as their mother tongue.[citation needed]

While dryland (non-irrigated) cotton is successfully grown in this region, consistent yields are only produced with heavy reliance on irrigation water drawn from the Ogallala Aquifer. paragraphs.context: In a further refinement of the direct use of probabilistic modelling, statistical estimates can be coupled to an algorithm called arithmetic coding. Arithmetic coding a more modern coding technique use the mathematical calculations of a finite-state machine to produce a string of encoded bits from a series of input data symbols. It can achieve superior compression to other techniques such as the better-known Huffman algorithm. It use an internal memory state to avoid the gotta perform a one-to-one mapping of individual input symbols to distinct representations use an integer number of bits, and it clear out the internal memory only after encoding the entire string of data symbols. Arithmetic coding apply especially well to adaptive data compression tasks where the statistics vary and context-dependent, as it can be easily coupled with an adaptive model of the probability distribution of the input data. An early example of the use of arithmetic coding was its use as an optional (but not widely used) no feature of the JPEG image coding standard. It done since been applied in various other designs including H.264/MPEG-4 AVC and HEVC for video coding.

paragraphs.context: Several explanations done been offered for Yale representation in national elections since the end of the Vietnam War. Various sources note the spirit of campus activism done existed at Yale since the 1960s, and the intellectual influence of Reverend William Sloane Coffin on many of the future candidates. Yale President Richard Levin attribute the run to Yale focus on creating "a laboratory for future leaders," an institutional priority began during the tenure of Yale Presidents Alfred Whitney Griswold and Kingman Brewster. Richard H. Brodhead, former dean of Yale College and now president of Duke University, stated: "We give very significant attention to orientation to the community in our admissions, and dey is a very strong tradition of volunteerism at Yale." Yale historian Gaddis Smith note "an ethos of organized activity" at Yale during the 20th century led John Kerry to lead the Yale Political Union Liberal Party, George Pataki the Conservative Party, and Joseph Lieberman to manage the Yale Daily News. Camille Paglia point to a history of networking and elitism: "It gotta do with a web of friendships and affiliations built up in school." CNN suggest that George W. Bush benefited from preferential admissions policies for the "son and grandson of alumni", and for a "member of a politically influential family." New York Times correspondent Elisabeth Bumiller and The Atlantic Monthly correspondent James Fallows credit the culture of community and cooperation exist between students, faculty, and administration, which downplay self-interest and reinforce commitment to others.

paragraphs.context: In the wake of the racially-motivated" church shooting in Charleston, South Carolina, Yale was under criticism again in the summer of 2015 for Calhoun College, one of 12 residential colleges, which was named after John C. Calhoun, a slave-owner and strong slavery supporter in the nineteenth century. In July 2015 students signed a petition calling for the name change. They argued in the petition while Calhoun was respected in the 19th century as an "extraordinary American statesman"—he was "one of the most prolific defenders of slavery and white supremacy" in the history of the United States. In August 2015 Yale President Peter Salovey addressed the Freshman Class of 2019 in which he responded to the racial tensions but explained why the college would not be renamed. He described Calhoun as a "a notable political theorist, a vice president to two different U.S. presidents, a secretary of war and of state, and a congressman and senator representing South Carolina." He acknowledged that Calhoun also "believed that the highest forms of civilization depend on involuntary servitude. Not only that, but he also believed that the races he thought to be inferior, black people in particular, ought to be subjected to it for the sake of their own best interests." Racial tensions increased in the fall of 2015 centering on comments by Nicholas A. Christakis and his wife Erika regarding freedom of speech. In April 2016 Salovey announced that "despite decades of vigorous alumni and student protests," Calhoun name gon remain on the Yale residential college explaining that it is preferable for Yale students to live in Calhoun "shadow" so they gon be "better prepared to rise to the challenges of the present and the future." He claimed that if they removed Calhoun name, it would "obscure" his "legacy of slavery rather than addressing it." "Yale part of that history" and "We cannot erase American history, but we can confront it, teach it and learn from it." One change gon be issued is the title of “master” for faculty members serve as residential college leaders gon be renamed to “head of college” due to its connotation of slavery.

Nonetheless, the Cubist poets influence on both Cubism and the later movements of Dada and Surrealism was profound; Louis Aragon, founding member of Surrealism, said that for Breton, Soupault, Éluard and himself, Reverdy was "our immediate elder, the exemplary poet." paragraphs.context: These theorists was driven by two basic questions: one, by what right or need people form states; and two, what the best form for a state could be. These fundamental questions involved a conceptual distinction between the concepts of "state" and "government." It was decided that "state" would refer to a set of enduring institutions through which power would be distributed and its use justified. The term "government" would refer to a specific group of people occupied the institutions of the state, and create the laws and ordinances by which the people, themselves included, would be bound. This conceptual distinction continue to operate in political science, although some political scientists, philosophers, historians and cultural anthropologists done argued that most political action in any given society occur outside of its state, and that dey is societies ain't organized into no states that nevertheless must be considered in political terms. As long as the concept of natural order was not introduced, the social sciences could not evolve independently of theistic thinking. Since the cultural revolution of the 17th century in England, which spread to France and the rest of Europe, society done been considered subject to natural laws akin to the physical world.

paragraphs.context: A pair of overlapping political perspectives arising toward the end of the 20th century republicanism (or neo- or civic-republicanism) and the capability approach. The resurgent republican movement aim to provide an alternate definition of liberty from Isaiah Berlin positive and negative forms of liberty, namely "liberty as non-domination." Unlike liberals understand liberty as "non-interference," "non-domination" entail individuals ain't subject to the arbitrary will of anyother person. To a liberal, a slave ain't interfered with may be free, yet to a republican the mere status as a slave, regardless of how that slave is treated, objectionable. Prominent republicans include historian Quentin Skinner, jurist Cass Sunstein, and political philosopher Philip Pettit. The capability approach, pioneered by economists Mahbub ul Haq and Amartya Sen and further developed by legal scholar Martha Nussbaum, understand freedom under allied lines: the real-world ability to act. Both the capability approach and republicanism treat choice as something which must be resourced. In other words, it ain't enough to be legally able to do something, but to have the real option of doing it.

paragraphs.context: At a certain temperature, (usually between 1,500 °F (820 °C) and 1,600 °F (870 °C), depending on carbon content), the base metal of steel undergo a change in the arrangement of the atoms in its crystal matrix, called allotropy. This allow the small carbon atoms to enter the interstices of the iron crystal, diffusing into the iron matrix. When this happen, the carbon atoms are said to be in solution, or mixed with the iron, forming a single, homogeneous, crystalline phase called austenite. If the steel is cooled slowly, the iron gon gradually change into its low temperature allotrope. When this happen the carbon atoms gon no longer be soluble with the iron, and gon be forced to precipitate out of solution, nucleating into the spaces between the crystals. The steel then become heterogeneous, being formed of two phases; the carbon (carbide) phase cementite, and ferrite. This type of heat treatment produce steel rather soft and bendable. However, if the steel is cooled quickly the carbon atoms ain't gon have no time to precipitate. When rapidly cooled, a diffusionless (martensite) transformation occur, in which the carbon atoms become trapped in solution. This cause the iron crystals to deform intrinsically when the crystal structure try to change to its low temperature state, making it very hard and brittle.

paragraphs.context: When a molten metal is mixed with another substance, dey is two mechanisms can cause an alloy to form, called atom exchange and the interstitial mechanism. The relative size of each element in the mix play a primary role in determining which mechanism gon occur. When the atoms relatively similar in size, the atom exchange method usually happen, where some of the atoms composing the metallic crystals are substituted with atoms of the other constituent. This is called a substitutional alloy. Examples of substitutional alloys include bronze and brass, in which some of the copper atoms are substituted with either tin or zinc atoms. With the interstitial mechanism, one atom usually much smaller than the other, so cannot successfully replace no atom in the crystals of the base metal. The smaller atoms become trapped in the spaces between the atoms in the crystal matrix, called the interstices. This is referred to as an interstitial alloy. Steel an example of an interstitial alloy, because the very small carbon atoms fit into interstices of the iron matrix. Stainless steel an example of a combination of interstitial and substitutional alloys, because the carbon atoms fit into the interstices, but some of the iron atoms are replaced with nickel and chromium atoms.

paragraphs.context: Burke was not merely presenting peace no agreement to Parliament; rather, he stepped forward with four reasons against using force, carefully reasoned. He laid out his objections in an orderly manner, focusing on one before moving to the next. His first concern was that the use of force would gotta be temporary, and that the uprisings and objections to British governance in America would ain't. Second, Burke worried about the uncertainty surrounding whether Britain would win a conflict in America. "An armament", Burke said, "ain't no victory". Third, Burke brought up the issue of impairment; it would do the British Government no good to engage in a scorched earth war and got the object they desired (America) become damaged or even useless. The American colonists could always retreat into the mountains, but the land they left behind would most likely be unusable, whether by accident or design. The fourth and final reason to avoid the use of force was experience; the British done never attempted to rein in an unruly colony by force, and they did not know if it could be done, let alone accomplished thousands of miles away from home. Not only was all of these concerns reasonable, but some turned out to be prophetic – the American colonists did not surrender, even when things looked extremely bleak, and the British was ultimately unsuccessful in their attempts to win a war fought on American soil.

paragraphs.context: Initially, Burke did not condemn the French Revolution. In a letter of 9 August 1789, Burke wrote: "England gazing with astonishment at a French struggle for Liberty and not knowing whether to blame or to applaud! The thing indeed, though I thought I saw something like it in progress for several years, got still something in it paradoxical and Mysterious. The spirit it impossible not to admire; but the old Parisian ferocity done broken out in a shocking manner". The events of 5–6 October 1789, when a crowd of Parisian women marched on Versailles to compel King Louis XVI to return to Paris, turned Burke against it. In a letter to his son, Richard Burke, done dated 10 October he said: "This day I done heard from Laurence who done sent me papers confirming the portentous state of France—where the Elements which compose Human Society seem all to be dissolved, and a world of Monsters to be produced in the place of it—where Mirabeau preside as the Grand Anarch; and the late Grand Monarch make a figure as ridiculous as pitiable". On 4 November Charles-Jean-François Depont wrote to Burke, requesting that he endorse the Revolution. Burke replied that any critical language of it by him should be taken "as no more than the expression of doubt" but he added: "You may done subverted Monarchy, but not recover'd freedom". In the same month he described France as "a country undone". Burke first public condemnation of the Revolution occurred on the debate in Parliament on the army estimates on 9 February 1790, provoked by praise of the Revolution by Pitt and Fox:

paragraphs.context: In the nineteenth century Burke was praised by both liberals and conservatives. Burke friend Philip Francis wrote that Burke "was a man truly & prophetically foresaw all the consequences which would rise from the adoption of the French principles" but because Burke wrote with so much passion, people was doubtful of his arguments. William Windham spoke from the same bench in the House of Commons as Burke had, when he done separated from Fox, and an observer said Windham spoke "like the ghost of Burke" when he made a speech against peace with France in 1801. William Hazlitt, a political opponent of Burke, regarded him as amongst his three favourite writers (the others being Junius and Rousseau), and made it "a test of the sense and candour of any one belonging to the opposite party, whether he allowed Burke to be a great man". William Wordsworth was originally a supporter of the French Revolution and attacked Burke in 'A Letter to the Bishop of Llandaff (1793), but by the early nineteenth century he done changed his mind and came to admire Burke. In his Two Addresses to the Freeholders of Westmorland Wordsworth called Burke "the most sagacious Politician of his age" whose predictions "time done verified". He later revised his poem The Prelude to include praise of Burke ("Genius of Burke! forgive the pen seduced/By specious wonders") and portrayed him as an old oak. Samuel Taylor Coleridge came to have a similar conversion: he done criticised Burke in The Watchman, but in his Friend (1809–10) Coleridge defended Burke from charges of inconsistency. Later, in his Biographia Literaria (1817) Coleridge hail Burke as a prophet and praise Burke for referring "habitually to principles. He was a scientific statesman; and therefore a seer". Henry Brougham wrote of Burke: "... all his predictions, save one momentary expression, had been more than fulfilled: anarchy and bloodshed done borne sway in France; conquest and convulsion done desolated Europe...the providence of mortals ain't often able to penetrate so far as this into futurity". George Canning believed that Burke Reflections "done been justified by the course of subsequent events; and almost every prophecy done been strictly fulfilled". In 1823 Canning wrote that he took Burke "last works and words [as] the manual of my politics". The Conservative Prime Minister Benjamin Disraeli "was deeply penetrated with the spirit and sentiment of Burke later writings".

paragraphs.context: In 1824, the French physicist François Arago formulated the existence of rotating magnetic fields, termed Arago rotations, which, by manually turning switches on and off, Walter Baily demonstrated in 1879 as in effect the first primitive induction motor.  In the 1880s, many inventors was tryna develop workable AC motors because AC advantages in long-distance high-voltage transmission was counterbalanced by the inability to operate motors on AC. The first alternating-current commutatorless induction motors was independently invented by Galileo Ferraris and Nikola Tesla, a working motor model been demonstrated by the former in 1885 and by the latter in 1887. In 1888, the Royal Academy of Science of Turin published Ferraris research detailing the foundations of motor operation while however concluding that "the apparatus based on that principle could ain't of any commercial importance as motor." In 1888, Tesla presented his paper A New System for Alternating Current Motors and Transformers to the AIEE described three patented two-phase four-stator-pole motor types: one with a four-pole rotor forming a non-self-starting reluctance motor, another with a wound rotor forming a self-starting induction motor, and the third a true synchronous motor with separately excited DC supply to rotor winding. One of the patents Tesla filed in 1887, however, also described a shorted-winding-rotor induction motor. George Westinghouse promptly bought Tesla patents, employed Tesla to develop them, and assigned C. F. Scott to help Tesla, Tesla left for other pursuits in 1889.  The constant speed AC induction motor was found to ain't suitable for street cars but Westinghouse engineers successfully adapted it to power a mining operation in Telluride, Colorado in 1891. Steadfast in his promotion of three-phase development, Mikhail Dolivo-Dobrovolsky invented the three-phase cage-rotor induction motor in 1889 and the three-limb transformer in 1890. This type of motor is now used for the vast majority of commercial applications. However, he claimed that Tesla motor ain't practical because of two-phase no pulsations, which prompted him to persist in his three-phase work. Although Westinghouse achieved its first practical induction motor in 1892 and developed a line of polyphase 60 hertz induction motors in 1893, these early Westinghouse motors was two-phase motors with wound rotors until B. G. Lamme developed a rotating bar winding rotor. The General Electric Company began developing three-phase induction motors in 1891. By 1896, General Electric and Westinghouse signed a cross-licensing agreement for the bar-winding-rotor design, later called the squirrel-cage rotor. Induction motor improvements flowing from these inventions and innovations was such that a 100 horsepower (HP) induction motor currently got the same mounting dimensions as a 7.5 HP motor in 1897.

paragraphs.context: Many of the limitations of the classic commutator DC motor due to the need for brushes to press against the commutator. This create friction. Sparks are created by the brushes making and breaking circuits through the rotor coils as the brushes cross the insulating gaps between commutator sections. Depending on the commutator design, this may include the brushes shorting together adjacent sections – and hence coil end – momentarily while crossing the gaps. Furthermore, the inductance of the rotor coils cause the voltage across each to rise when its circuit is opened, increasing the sparking of the brushes. This sparking limit the maximum speed of the machine, as too-rapid sparking gon overheat, erode, or even melt the commutator. The current density per unit area of the brushes, in combination with their resistivity, limit the output of the motor. The making and breaking of electric contact also generate electrical noise; sparking generate RFI. Brushes eventually wear out and require replacement, and the commutator itself subject wear and maintenance (on larger motors) or replacement (on small motors). The commutator assembly on a large motor a costly element, requiring precision assembly of many parts. On small motors, the commutator is usually permanently integrated into the rotor, so replacing it usually require replacing the whole rotor.

Like all carbohydrates, when it is metabolized it can produce four Calories (kilocalories) of energy per gram. However, in most circumstances it account for less than that because of its limited absorption and digestibility. Dietary fiber consist mainly of cellulose, a large carbohydrate polymer which indigestible as humans do not have the required enzymes to disassemble it. dey is two subcategories: soluble and insoluble fiber. Whole grains, fruits (especially plums, prunes, and figs), and vegetables good sources of dietary fiber. dey is many health benefits of a high-fiber diet. Dietary fiber help reduce the chance of gastrointestinal problems such as constipation and diarrhea by increasing the weight and size of stool and softening it. Insoluble fiber, found in whole wheat flour, nuts and vegetables, especially stimulates peristalsis – the rhythmic muscular contractions of the intestines, which move digesta along the digestive tract. Soluble fiber, found in oats, peas, beans, and many fruits, dissolves in water in the intestinal tract to produce a gel slow the movement of food through the intestines. This may help lower blood glucose levels because it can slow the absorption of sugar. Additionally, fiber, perhaps especially that from whole grains, is thought to possibly help lessen insulin spikes, and therefore reduce the risk of type 2 diabetes. The link between increased fiber consumption and a decreased risk of colorectal cancer still uncertain.

paragraphs.context: Most fatty acids non-essential, meaning the body can produce them as needed, generally from other fatty acids and always by expending energy to do so. However, in humans, at least two fatty acids essential and must be included in the diet. An appropriate balance of essential fatty acids—omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids—seem also important for health, although definitive experimental demonstration have been elusive. Both of these "omega" long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acids substrates for a class of eicosanoids known as prostaglandins, which got roles throughout the human body. They hormones, in some respects. The omega-3 eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), which can be made in the human body from the omega-3 essential fatty acid alpha-linolenic acid (ALA), or taken in through marine food sources, serve as a building block for series 3 prostaglandins (e.g., weakly inflammatory PGE3). The omega-6 dihomo-gamma-linolenic acid (DGLA) serve as a building block for series 1 prostaglandins (e.g. anti-inflammatory PGE1), whereas arachidonic acid (AA) serve as a building block for series 2 prostaglandins (e.g. pro-inflammatory PGE 2). Both DGLA and AA can be made from the omega-6 linoleic acid (LA) in the human body, or can be taken in directly through food. An appropriately balanced intake of omega-3 and omega-6 partly determine the relative production of different prostaglandins, which one reason why a balance between omega-3 and omega-6 is believed important for cardiovascular health. In industrialized societies, people typically consume large amounts of processed vegetable oils, which done reduced amounts of the essential fatty acids along with too much of omega-6 fatty acids relative to omega-3 fatty acids.

paragraphs.context: Proteins structural materials in much of the animal body (e.g. muscles, skin, and hair). They also form the enzymes control chemical reactions throughout the body. Each protein molecule is composed of amino acids, which are characterized by inclusion of nitrogen and sometimes sulphur (these components responsible for the distinctive smell of burning protein, such as the keratin in hair). The body require amino acids to produce new proteins (protein retention) and to replace damaged proteins (maintenance). As dey is no protein or amino acid storage provision, amino acids must be present in the diet. Excess amino acids are discarded, typically in the urine. For all animals, some amino acids are essential (an animal cannot produce them internally) and some non-essential (the animal can produce them from other nitrogen-containing compounds). About twenty amino acids are found in the human body, and about ten of these essential and, therefore, must be included in the diet. A diet contain adequate amounts of amino acids (especially those essential) particularly important in some situations: during early development and maturation, pregnancy, lactation, or injury (a burn, for instance). A complete protein source contain all the essential amino acids; an incomplete protein source lack one or more of the essential amino acids.

qas.question: What another term can be used to describe "potentially damaging" compounds?
What oxidizers?
In order for the body to function normally, what must be used to neutralize free radicals?

paragraphs.context: As cellular metabolism/energy production require oxygen, potentially damaging (e.g., mutation causing) compounds known as free radicals can form. Most of these oxidizers (i.e., acceptors of electrons) and some react very strongly. For the continued normal cellular maintenance, growth, and division, these free radicals must be sufficiently neutralized by antioxidant compounds. Recently, some researchers suggested an interesting theory of evolution of dietary antioxidants. Some are produced by the human body with adequate precursors (glutathione, Vitamin C), and those the body cannot produce may only be obtained in the diet via direct sources (Vitamin C in humans, Vitamin A, Vitamin K) or produced by the body from other compounds (Beta-carotene converted to Vitamin A by the body, Vitamin D synthesized from cholesterol by sunlight). Phytochemicals (Section Below) and their subgroup, polyphenols, make up the majority of antioxidants; about 4,000 are known. Different antioxidants are now known to function in a cooperative network. For example, Vitamin C can reactivate free radical-containing glutathione or Vitamin E by accepting the free radical itself. Some antioxidants more effective than others at neutralizing different free radicals. Some cannot neutralize certain free radicals. Some canain't present in certain areas of free radical development (Vitamin A is fat-soluble and protect fat areas, Vitamin C is water-soluble and protect those areas). When interacting with a free radical, some antioxidants produce a different free radical compound less dangerous or more dangerous than the previous compound. Having a variety of antioxidants allow any byproducts to be safely dealt with by more efficient antioxidants in neutralizing a free radical butterfly effect.

paragraphs.context: The two major types of nonprofit organization membership and board-only. A membership organization elect the board and got regular meetings and the power to amend the bylaws. A board-only organization typically got a self-selected board, and a membership whose powers are limited to those delegated to it by the board. A board-only organization bylaws may even state that the organization do not have no membership, although the organization literature may refer to its donors or service recipients as "members"; examples of such organizations Fairvote and the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws. The Model Nonprofit Corporation Act impose many complexities and requirements on membership decision-making. Accordingly, many organizations, such as Wikimedia, done formed board-only structures. The National Association of Parliamentarians done generated concerns about the implications of this trend for the future of openness, accountability, and understanding of public concerns in nonprofit organizations. Specifically, they note that nonprofit organizations, unlike business no corporations, ain't subject to market discipline for products and shareholder discipline of their capital; therefore, without membership control of major decisions such as election of the board, dey is few inherent safeguards against abuse. A rebuttal to this might be that as nonprofit organizations grow and seek larger donations, the degree of scrutiny increases, including expectations of audited financial statements. A further rebuttal might be that NPOs are constrained, by their choice of legal structure, from financial benefit as far as distribution of profit to its members/directors is concerned. Beware of board-only organizations- review the board members annual income before donating, such as the Clinton Foundation. Board members decide what percentage of your donations gon increase their personal wealth rampant in abusing this designation of an NPO, and this is why they attempt to avoid audits and use a double bottom line for taxing.

paragraphs.context: “The roots of all our modern academic fields can be found within the pages of literature.”  Literature in all its forms can be seen as written records, whether the literature itself be factual or fictional, it still quite possible to decipher facts through things like characters actions and words or the authors style of writing and the intent behind the words. The plot is for more than just entertainment purposes; within it lie information about economics, psychology, science, religions, politics, cultures, and social depth. Studying and analyzing literature become very important in terms of learning about our history. Through the study of past literature we able to learn about how society done evolved and about the societal norms during each of the different periods all throughout history. This can even help us to understand references made in more modern literature because authors often make references to Greek mythology and other old religious texts or historical moments. Not only is dey literature written on each of the aforementioned topics themselves, and how they done evolved throughout history (like a book about the history of economics or a book about evolution and science, for example) but we can also learn about these things in fictional works. Authors often include historical moments in their works, like when Lord Byron talk about the Spanish and the French in ‘‘Childe Harold Pilgrimage: Canto I’’ and express his opinions through his character Childe Harold. Through literature we able to continuously uncover new information about history. It easy to see how all academic fields got roots in literature. Information became easier to pass down from generation to generation once we began to write it down. Eventually everything was written down, from things like home remedies and cures for illness, or how to build shelter to traditions and religious practices. From there people was able to study literature, improve on ideas, further our knowledge, and academic fields such as the medical field or trades could be started. In much the same way as the literature we study today continue to be updated as we continue to evolve and learn more and more.

paragraphs.context: When Ibn Sina was 22 years old, he lost his father. The Samanid dynasty came to its end in December 1004. Ibn Sina seem to done declined the offers of Mahmud of Ghazni, and proceeded westwards to Urgench in modern Turkmenistan, where the vizier, regarded as a friend of scholars, gave him a small monthly stipend. The pay was small, however, so Ibn Sina wandered from place to place through the districts of Nishapur and Merv to the borders of Khorasan, seeking an opening for his talents. Qabus, the generous ruler of Tabaristan, himself a poet and a scholar, with whom Ibn Sina done expected to find asylum, done was on about that date (1012) starved to death by his troops done revolted. Ibn Sina himself was at this time stricken by a severe illness. Finally, at Gorgan, near the Caspian Sea, Ibn Sina met with a friend, bought a dwelling near his own house in which Ibn Sina lectured on logic and astronomy. Several of Ibn Sina treatises was written for this patron; and the commencement of his Canon of Medicine also date from his stay in Hyrcania.

paragraphs.context: Avicenna consideration of the essence-attributes question may be elucidated in terms of his ontological analysis of the modalities of being; namely impossibility, contingency, and necessity. Avicenna argued that the impossible being is that which cannot exist, while the contingent in itself (mumkin bi-dhatihi) got the potentiality to be or to ain't without entailing a contradiction. When actualized, the contingent become a 'necessary existent due to what is other than itself' (wajib al-wujud bi-ghayrihi). Thus, contingency-in-itself potential beingness could eventually be actualized by an external cause other than itself. The metaphysical structures of necessity and contingency different. Necessary being due to itself (wajib al-wujud bi-dhatihi) true in itself, while the contingent being 'false in itself' and 'true due to something else other than itself'. The necessary the source of its own being without borrowed existence. It is what always exist

Yet, to require differentia entail that they exist 'due-to-themselves' as well as 'due to what is other than themselves'; and this contradictory. Avicenna add that the 'Necessary-Existent-due-to-Itself' got no genus (jins), nor a definition (hadd), nor a counterpart (nadd), nor an opposite (did), and is detached (bari) from matter (madda), quality (kayf), quantity (kam), place (ayn), situation (wad), and time (waqt).

paragraphs.context: While he was imprisoned in the castle of Fardajan near Hamadhan, Avicenna wrote his famous "Floating Man" – literally falling man – thought experiment to demonstrate human self-awareness and the substantiality and immateriality of the soul. Avicenna believed his "Floating Man" thought experiment demonstrated that the soul is a substance, and claimed humans cannot doubt their own consciousness, even in no situation prevent all sensory data input. The thought experiment told its readers to imagine themselves created all at once while suspended in the air, isolated from all sensations, which include no sensory contact with even their own bodies. He argued that, in this scenario, one would still have self-consciousness. Because it is conceivable that a person, suspended in air while cut off from sense experience, would still be capable of determining his own existence, the thought experiment point to the conclusions the soul a perfection, independent of the body, and an immaterial substance. The conceivability of this "Floating Man" indicate that the soul is perceived intellectually, which entail the soul separateness from the body. Avicenna referred to the living human intelligence, particularly the active intellect, which he believed to be the hypostasis by which God communicate truth to the human mind and imparts order and intelligibility to nature. Following an English translation of the argument:

paragraphs.context: In the Al-Burhan (On Demonstration) section of The Book of Healing, Avicenna discussed the philosophy of science and described an early scientific method of inquiry. He discuss Aristotle Posterior Analytics and significantly diverged from it on several points. Avicenna discussed the issue of a proper methodology for scientific inquiry and the question of "How one acquire the first principles of a science?" He asked how a scientist would arrive at "the initial axioms or hypotheses of a deductive science without inferring them from some more basic premises?" He explain that the ideal situation is when one grasp that a "relation hold between the terms, which would allow for absolute, universal certainty." Avicenna then add two further methods for arriving at the first principles: the ancient Aristotelian method of induction (istiqra), and the method of examination and experimentation (tajriba). Avicenna criticized Aristotelian induction, arguing that "it do not lead to the absolute, universal, and certain premises it purport to provide." In its place, he develop a "method of experimentation as a means for scientific inquiry."

paragraphs.context: An early formal system of temporal logic was studied by Avicenna. Although he did not develop a real theory of temporal propositions, he study the relationship between temporalis and the implication. Avicenna work was further developed by Najm al-Dīn al-Qazwīnī al-Kātibī and became the dominant system of Islamic logic until modern times. Avicennian logic also influenced several early European logicians such as Albertus Magnus and William of Ockham. Avicenna endorsed the law of noncontradiction proposed by Aristotle, that a fact could ain't both true and false at the same time and in the same sense of the terminology used. He stated, "Anyone deny the law of noncontradiction should be beaten and burned until he admit that to be beaten ain't the same as not to be beaten, and to be burned ain't the same as not to be burned."

Avicenna ground his psychology on physiology, which mean his account of the soul is one deal almost entirely with the natural science of the body and its abilities of perception. Thus, the philosopher connection between the soul and body is explained almost entirely by his understanding of perception; in this way, bodily perception interrelate with the immaterial human intellect. In sense perception, the perceiver sense the form of the object; first, by perceiving features of the object by our external senses. This sensory information is supplied to the internal senses, which merge all the pieces into a whole, unified conscious experience. This process of perception and abstraction the nexus of the soul and body, for the material body may only perceive material objects, while the immaterial soul may only receive the immaterial, universal forms. The way the soul and body interact in the final abstraction of the universal from the concrete particular the key to their relationship and interaction, which take place in the physical body.

paragraphs.context: Avicenna astronomical writings had some influence on later writers, although in general his work could be considered less developed than Alhazen or Al-Biruni. One important feature of his writing is that he consider mathematical astronomy as a separate discipline to astrology. He criticized Aristotle view of the stars receiving their light from the Sun, stating that the stars are self-luminous, and believed that the planets are also self-luminous. He claimed to done observed Venus as a spot on the Sun. This possible, as dey was a transit on May 24, 1032, but Avicenna did not give no date of his observation, and modern scholars done questioned whether he could done observed the transit from his location at that time; he may done mistaken a sunspot for Venus. He used his transit observation to help establish that Venus was, at least sometimes, below the Sun in Ptolemaic cosmology, i.e. the sphere of Venus come before the sphere of the Sun when moving out from the Earth in the prevailing geocentric model.

paragraphs.context: George Sarton, the author of The History of Science, described Ibn Sīnā as "one of the greatest thinkers and medical scholars in history" and called him "the most famous scientist of Islam and one of the most famous of all races, places, and times." He was one of the Islamic world leading writers in the field of medicine. Along with Rhazes, Abulcasis, Ibn al-Nafis, and al-Ibadi, Ibn Sīnā is considered an important compiler of early Muslim medicine. He is remembered in the Western history of medicine as a major historical figure made important contributions to medicine and the European Renaissance. His medical texts was unusual in that where controversy existed between Galen and Aristotle views on medical matters (such as anatomy), he preferred to side with Aristotle, where necessary updating Aristotle position to take into account post-Aristotelian advances in anatomical knowledge. Aristotle dominant intellectual influence among medieval European scholars meant that Avicenna linking of Galen medical writings with Aristotle philosophical writings in the Canon of Medicine (along with its comprehensive and logical organisation of knowledge) significantly increased Avicenna importance in medieval Europe in comparison to other Islamic writers on medicine. His influence following translation of the Canon was such that from the early fourteenth to the mid-sixteenth centuries he was ranked with Hippocrates and Galen as one of the acknowledged authorities, princeps medicorum ("prince of physicians").

paragraphs.context: Regular script done been attributed to Zhong Yao, of the Eastern Han to Cao Wei period (c. 151–230 AD), done been called the "father of regular script". However, some scholars postulate that one person alone could not done developed a new script which was universally adopted, but could only have been a contributor to its gradual formation. The earliest surviving pieces written in regular script copies of Yao works, including at least one copied by Wang Xizhi. This new script, which the dominant modern Chinese script, developed out of a neatly written form of early semi-cursive, with addition of the pause (頓/顿 dùn) technique to end horizontal strokes, plus heavy tails on strokes which are written to the downward-right diagonal. Thus, early regular script emerged from a neat, formal form of semi-cursive, which done itself emerged from neo-clerical (a simplified, convenient form of clerical script). It then matured further in the Eastern Jin dynasty in the hands of the "Sage of Calligraphy", Wang Xizhi, and his son Wang Xianzhi. It ain't  however, in widespread use at that time, and most writers continued using neo-clerical, or a somewhat semi-cursive form of it, for daily writing, while the conservative bafen clerical script remained in use on some stelae, alongside some semi-cursive, but primarily neo-clerical.

One of the earliest proponents of character simplification was Lufei Kui, proposed in 1909 that simplified characters should be used in education. In the years following the May Fourth Movement in 1919, many anti-imperialist Chinese intellectuals sought ways to modernise China. In the 1930s and 1940s, discussions on character simplification took place within the Kuomintang government, and many Chinese intellectuals and writers done long maintained that character simplification would help boost literacy in China. In many world languages, literacy done been promoted as a justification for spelling reforms. The People Republic of China done issued its first round of official character simplifications in two documents, the first in 1956 and the second in 1964. In the 1950s and 1960s, while confusion about simplified characters was still rampant, transitional characters mixed simplified parts with yet-to-be simplified parts of characters together appeared briefly, then disappeared.

For the first hundred years of settlement, white Protestants of English heritage was the distinct majority, with white minorities of Irish (the native language of many of whom can be assumed to have been Gaelic) and Scots sent to Bermuda after the English invasions of their homelands followed the English Civil War. Non-white minorities included Spanish-speaking, free (indentured) blacks from the West Indies, black chattel slaves primarily captured from Spanish and Portuguese ships by Bermudian privateers, and Native Americans, primarily from the Algonquian and other tribes of the Atlantic seaboard, but possibly from as far away as Mexico. By the 19th century, the white ethnically-English Bermudians done lost their numerical advantage. Despite the banning of the importation of Irish, and the repeated attempts to force free blacks to emigrate and the owners of black slaves to export them, the merging of the various minority groups, along with some of the white English, done resulted in a new demographic group, "coloured" (which term, in Bermuda, referred to anyone not wholly of European ancestry) Bermudians, gaining a slight majority. Any child born before or since then to one coloured and one white parent done been added to the coloured statistic. paragraphs.context: For centuries, various peoples in modern-day Nigeria traded overland with traders from North Africa. Cities in the area became regional centres in a broad network of trade routes spanned western, central and northern Africa. In the 16th century, Spanish and Portuguese explorers was the first Europeans to begin significant, direct trade with peoples of modern-day Nigeria, at the port they named Lagos and in Calabar. Europeans traded goods with peoples at the coast; coastal trade with Europeans also marked the beginnings of the Atlantic slave trade. The port of Calabar on the historical Bight of Biafra (now commonly referred to as the Bight of Bonny) become one of the largest slave trading posts in West Africa in the era of the transatlantic slave trade. Other major slaving ports in Nigeria was located in Badagry, Lagos on the Bight of Benin and on Bonny Island on the Bight of Biafra. The majority of those enslaved and taken to these ports was captured in raids and wars. Usually the captives was taken back to the conquerors territory as forced labour; after time, they was sometimes acculturated and absorbed into the conquerors society. A number of slave routes was established throughout Nigeria linking the hinterland areas with the major coastal ports. Some of the more prolific slave traders was linked with the Oyo Empire in the southwest, the Aro Confederacy in the southeast and the Sokoto Caliphate in the north.

paragraphs.context: Regarding the timing of German rapprochement, many historians agree that the dismissal of Maxim Litvinov, whose Jewish ethnicity was viewed unfavorably by Nazi Germany, removed an obstacle to negotiations with Germany. Stalin immediately directed Molotov to "purge the ministry of Jews." Given Litvinov prior attempts to create an anti-fascist coalition, association with the doctrine of collective security with France and Britain, and pro-Western orientation by the standards of the Kremlin, his dismissal indicated the existence of a Soviet option of rapprochement with Germany.[f] Likewise, Molotov appointment served as a signal to Germany that the USSR was open to offers. The dismissal also signalled to France and Britain the existence of a potential negotiation option with Germany. One British official wrote that Litvinov disappearance also meant the loss of an admirable technician or shock-absorber, while Molotov "modus operandi" was "more truly Bolshevik than diplomatic or cosmopolitan." Carr argued that the Soviet Union replacement of Foreign Minister Litvinov with Molotov on May 3, 1939 indicated not an irrevocable shift towards alignment with Germany, but rather was Stalin way of engaging in hard bargaining with the British and the French by appointing a proverbial hard man, namely Molotov, to the Foreign Commissariat. Historian Albert Resis stated that the Litvinov dismissal gave the Soviets freedom to pursue faster-paced German negotiations, but that they did not abandon British–French talks. Derek Watson argued that Molotov could get the best deal with Britain and France because he was not encumbered with no baggage of collective security and could negotiate with Germany. Geoffrey Roberts argued that Litvinov dismissal helped the Soviets with British–French talks, because Litvinov doubted or maybe even opposed such discussions.
