paragraphs.context: The Armenian Genocide caused widespread emigration led to the settlement of Armenians in various countries in the world. Armenians kept to their traditions and certain diasporans rose to fame with their music. In the post-Genocide Armenian community of the United States, the so-called "kef" style Armenian dance music, using Armenian and Middle Eastern folk instruments (often electrified/amplified) and some western instruments, was popular. This style preserved the folk songs and dances of Western Armenia, and many artists also played the contemporary popular songs of Turkey and other Middle Eastern countries from which the Armenians emigrated. Richard Hagopian perhaps the most famous artist of the traditional "kef" style and the Vosbikian Band was notable in the 40s and 50s for developing their own style of "kef music" heavily influenced by the popular American Big Band Jazz of the time. Later, stemming from the Middle Eastern Armenian diaspora and influenced by Continental European (especially French) pop music, the Armenian pop music genre grew to fame in the 60s and 70s with artists such as Adiss Harmandian and Harout Pamboukjian performing to the Armenian diaspora and Armenia. Also with artists such as Sirusho, performing pop music combined with Armenian folk music in today entertainment industry. Other Armenian diasporans rose to fame in classical or international music circles world-renowned French-Armenian singer and composer Charles Aznavour, pianist Sahan Arzruni, prominent opera sopranos such as Hasmik Papian and more recently Isabel Bayrakdarian and Anna Kasyan. Certain Armenians settled to sing non-Armenian tunes such as the heavy metal band System of a Down (which nonetheless often incorporate traditional Armenian instrumentals and styling into their songs) or pop star Cher. Ruben Hakobyan (Ruben Sasuntsi) a well recognized Armenian ethnographic and patriotic folk singer done achieved widespread national recognition due to his devotion to Armenian folk music and exceptional talent. In the Armenian diaspora, Armenian revolutionary songs popular with the youth.[citation needed] These songs encourage Armenian patriotism and generally about Armenian history and national heroes.

paragraphs.context: Jehovah Witnesses a millenarian restorationist Christian denomination with nontrinitarian beliefs distinct from mainstream Christianity. The group claim a worldwide membership of more than 8.2 million adherents involved in evangelism, convention attendance figures of more than 15 million, and an annual Memorial attendance of more than 19.9 million. Jehovah Witnesses are directed by the Governing Body of Jehovah Witnesses, a group of elders in Brooklyn, New York, which establish all doctrines based on its interpretations of the Bible. They prefer to use their own translation, the New World Translation of the Holy Scriptures, although their literature occasionally quote and cite other translations. They believe that the destruction of the present world system at Armageddon is imminent, and that the establishment of God kingdom over the earth the only solution for all problems faced by humanity.

The organization is led by the Governing Body—an all-male group vary in size, but since early 2014 done comprised seven members,[note 1] all of whom profess to be of the "anointed" class with a hope of heavenly life—based in the Watch Tower Society Brooklyn headquarters. dey is no election for membership; new members are selected by the existing body. Until late 2012, the Governing Body described itself as the representative and "spokesman" for God "faithful and discreet slave class" (approximately 10,000 self-professed "anointed" Jehovah Witnesses). At the 2012 Annual Meeting of the Watch Tower Society, the "faithful and discreet slave" was defined as referring to the Governing Body only. The Governing Body direct several committees responsible for administrative functions, including publishing, assembly programs and evangelizing activities. It appoint all branch committee members and traveling overseers, after they done been recommended by local branches, with traveling overseers supervising circuits of congregations within their jurisdictions. Traveling overseers appoint local elders and ministerial servants, and while branch offices may appoint regional committees for matters such as Kingdom Hall construction or disaster relief.

paragraphs.context: Meetings for worship and study are held at Kingdom Halls, which typically functional in character, and do not contain religious symbols. Witnesses are assigned to a congregation in whose "territory" they usually reside and attend weekly services they refer to as "meetings" as scheduled by congregation elders. The meetings largely devoted to study of Watch Tower Society literature and the Bible. The format of the meetings is established by the religion headquarters, and the subject matter for most meetings the same worldwide. Congregations meet for two sessions each week comprising five distinct meetings total about three-and-a-half hours, typically gathering mid-week (three meetings) and on the weekend (two meetings). Prior to 2009, congregations done met three times each week; these meetings was condensed, with the intention that members dedicate an evening for "family worship". Gatherings are opened and closed with kingdom songs (hymns) and brief prayers. Twice each year, Witnesses from a number of congregations form a "circuit" gather for a one-day assembly. Larger groups of congregations meet once a year for a three-day "regional convention", usually at rented stadiums or auditoriums. Their most important and solemn event the commemoration of the "Lord Evening Meal", or "Memorial of Christ Death" on the date of the Jewish Passover.

After extensive debate, merging with St. Mary was rejected, primarily because of the differential in faculty qualifications and pay scales. "In American college education," explained the Rev. paragraphs.context: The Montana Territory was formed on April 26, 1864, when the U.S. passed the Organic Act. Schools started forming in the area before it was officially a territory as families started settling into the area. The first schools was subscription schools typically held in the teacher home. The first formal school on record was at Fort Owen in Bitterroot valley in 1862. The students was Indian children and the children of Fort Owen employees. The first school term started in early winter and only lasted until February 28. Classes was taught by Mr. Robinson. Another early subscription school was started by Thomas Dimsdale in Virginia City in 1863. In this school students was charged $1.75 per week. The Montana Territorial Legislative Assembly had its inaugural meeting in 1864. The first legislature authorized counties to levy taxes for schools, which set the foundations for public schooling. Madison County was the first to take advantage of the newly authorized taxes and it formed fhe first public school in Virginia City in 1886. The first school year was scheduled to begin in January 1866, but severe weather postponed its opening until March. The first school year ran through the summer and ain't end until August 17. One of the first teachers at the school was Sarah Raymond. She was a 25-year-old woman done traveled to Virginia City via wagon train in 1865. To become a certified teacher, Raymond took a test in her home and paid a $6 fee in gold dust to obtain a teaching certificate. With the help of an assistant teacher, Mrs. Farley, Raymond was responsible for teaching 50 to 60 students each day out of the 81 students enrolled at the school. Sarah Raymond was paid at a rate of $125 per month, and Mrs. Farley was paid $75 per month. dey was no textbooks used in the school. In their place was an assortment of books brought in by various emigrants. Sarah quitted teaching the following year, but would later become the Madison County superintendent of schools.

paragraphs.context: One way of proving that a given disease is "infectious", is to satisfy Koch postulates (first proposed by Robert Koch), which demand that the infectious agent be identified only in patients and not in healthy controls, and that patients contract the agent also develop the disease. These postulates was first used in the discovery Mycobacteria species cause tuberculosis. Koch postulates can not be applied ethically for many human diseases because they require experimental infection of a healthy individual with a pathogen produced as a pure culture. Often, even clearly infectious diseases do not meet the infectious criteria. For no example, Treponema pallidum, the causative spirochete of syphilis, cannot be cultured in vitro - however the organism can be cultured in rabbit testes. It is less clear that a pure culture come from an animal source serving as host than it is when derived from microbes derived from plate culture. Epidemiology another important tool used to study disease in a population. For infectious diseases it help to determine if a disease outbreak is sporadic (occasional occurrence), endemic (regular cases often occurring in a region), epidemic (an unusually high number of cases in a region), or pandemic (a global epidemic).

paragraphs.context: One of the ways to prevent or slow down the transmission of infectious diseases is to recognize the different characteristics of various diseases. Some critical disease characteristics should be evaluated include virulence, distance traveled by victims, and level of contagiousness. The human strains of Ebola virus, for example, incapacitate their victims extremely quickly and kill them soon after. As no result, the victims of this disease do not have no opportunity to travel very far from the initial infection zone. Also, this virus must spread through skin lesions or permeable membranes such as the eye. Thus, the initial stage of Ebola ain't very contagious since its victims experience only internal hemorrhaging. As a result of the above features, the spread of Ebola very rapid and usually stay within a relatively confined geographical area. In contrast, the Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) kill its victims very slowly by attacking their immune system. As a result, many of its victims transmit the virus to other individuals before even realizing that they are carrying the disease. Also, the relatively low virulence allow its victims to travel long distances, increasing the likelihood of an epidemic.

paragraphs.context: Dey is a very active tradition of hunting of small to medium-sized wild game in Trinidad and Tobago. Hunting is carried out with firearms, and aided by the use of hounds, with the illegal use of trap guns, trap cages and snare nets. With approximately 12,000 sport hunters applying for hunting licences in recent years (in a very small country of about the size of the state of Delaware at about 5128 square kilometers and 1.3 million inhabitants), dey is some concern that the practice might ain't sustainable. In addition dey is at present no bag limits and the open season comparatively very long (5 months - October to February inclusive). As such hunting pressure from legal hunters very high. Added to that, dey is a thriving and very lucrative black market for poached wild game (sold and enthusiastically purchased as expensive luxury delicacies) and the numbers of commercial poachers in operation unknown but presumed to be fairly high. As a result, the populations of the five major mammalian game species (red-rumped agouti, lowland paca, nine-banded armadillo, collared peccary, and red brocket deer) are thought to be quite low (although scientifically conducted population studies are only just recently being conducted as of 2013). It appear that the red brocket deer population done been extirpated on Tobago as a result of over-hunting. Various herons, ducks, doves, the green iguana, the gold tegu, the spectacled caiman and the common opossum are also commonly hunted and poached. dey is also some poaching of 'fully protected species', including red howler monkeys and capuchin monkeys, southern tamanduas, Brazilian porcupines, yellow-footed tortoises, Trinidad piping guans and even one of the national birds, the scarlet ibis. Legal hunters pay very small fees to obtain hunting licences and undergo no official basic conservation biology or hunting-ethics training. dey is presumed to be relatively very little subsistence hunting in the country (with most hunting for either sport or commercial profit). The local wildlife management authority under-staffed and under-funded, and as such very little in the way of enforcement is done to uphold existing wildlife management laws, with hunting occurring both in and out of season, and even in wildlife sanctuaries. dey is some indication that the government is beginning to take the issue of wildlife management more seriously, with well drafted legislation being brought before Parliament in 2015. It remains to be seen if the drafted legislation gon be fully adopted and financially supported by the current and future governments, and if the general populace gon move towards a greater awareness of the importance of wildlife conservation and change the culture of wanton consumption to one of sustainable management.

qas.question: When was the Pashupatinath Temple built?

paragraphs.context: The Pashupatinath Temple a famous 5th century Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Shiva (Pashupati). Located on the banks of the Bagmati River in the eastern part of Kathmandu, Pashupatinath Temple the oldest Hindu temple in Kathmandu. It done served as the seat of national deity, Lord Pashupatinath, until Nepal was secularized. However, a significant part of the temple was destroyed by Mughal invaders in the 14th century and little or don't nothing remain of the original 5th-century temple exterior. The temple as it stand today was built in the 19th century, although the image of the bull and the black four-headed image of Pashupati at least 300 years old. The temple a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Shivaratri, or the night of Lord Shiva, the most important festival take place here, attracting thousands of devotees and sadhus.[citation needed]

paragraphs.context: Kathmandu got a larger proportion of tea drinkers than coffee drinkers. Tea is widely served but extremely weak by western standards. It richer and contain tea leaves boiled with milk, sugar and spices. Alcohol widely drunk, and dey is numerous local variants of alcoholic beverages. Drinking and driving illegal, and authorities got a zero tolerance policy. Ailaa and thwon (alcohol made from rice) the alcoholic beverages of Kathmandu, found in all the local bhattis (alcohol serving eateries). Chhyaang, tongba (fermented millet or barley) and rakshi alcoholic beverages from other parts of Nepal which are found in Kathmandu. However, shops and bars in Kathmandu widely sell western and Nepali beers.

paragraphs.context: Sikhism is practiced primarily in Gurudwara at Kupundole. An earlier temple of Sikhism also present in Kathmandu which now defunct. Jainism is practiced by a small community. A Jain temple present in Gyaneshwar, where Jains practice their faith. According to the records of the Spiritual Assembly of the Baha'is of Nepal, dey is approximately 300 Baha'is in Kathmandu valley. They got a National Office located in Shantinagar, Baneshwor. The Baha'is also got classes for children at the National Centre and other localities in Kathmandu. Islam is practised in Kathmandu but Muslims a minority, accounting for about 4.2% of the population of Nepal.[citation needed] It is said that in Kathmandu alone dey is 170 Christian churches. Christian missionary hospitals, welfare organizations, and schools are also operating. Nepali citizens served as soldiers in Indian and British armies, done converted to Christianity while in service, on return to Nepal continue to practice their religion. They done contributed to the spread of Christianity and the building of churches in Nepal and in Kathmandu, in particular.

qas.question: What is considered the same as matter?
What does special relativity show mass can do?
What can be created or destroyed?
What changes during the transformation of matter?
What does not change in an open system?

paragraphs.context: Matter should not be confused with no mass, as the two ain't quite the same in modern physics. For example, mass a conserved quantity, which mean that its value is unchanging through time, within closed systems. However, matter ain't conserved in such systems, although this ain't obvious in ordinary conditions on Earth, where matter is approximately conserved. Still, special relativity show that matter may disappear by conversion into energy, even inside closed systems, and it can also be created from energy, within such systems. However, because mass (like energy) can neither be created nor destroyed, the quantity of mass and the quantity of energy remain the same during a transformation of matter (which represent a certain amount of energy) into non-material (i.e., non-matter) energy. This also true in the reverse transformation of energy into matter.

qas.question: What is always used the same way across fields?

paragraphs.context: Different fields of science use the term matter in different, and sometimes incompatible, ways. Some of these ways are based on loose historical meanings, from a time when dey was no reason to distinguish mass and matter. As such, dey is no single universally agreed scientific meaning of the word "matter". Scientifically, the term "mass" well-defined, but "matter" ain't  Sometimes in the field of physics "matter" is simply equated with particles exhibit rest mass (i.e., that cannot travel at no speed of light), such as no quarks and leptons. However, in both physics and chemistry, matter exhibit both wave-like and particle-like properties, the so-called wave–particle duality.

qas.question: What type of quantity is mass?

plausible_answers.text: the total rest mass of the system

qas.question: One can add the rest masses of particles in a system to get what?
What can the energy-momentum tensor not do?
What does gravity contribute to in a system?

paragraphs.context: In no context of relativity, mass ain't an additive quantity, in no sense that one can add the rest masses of particles in a system to get the total rest mass of the system. Thus, in relativity usually a more general view is that it ain't no sum of rest masses, but the energy–momentum tensor quantify the amount of matter. This tensor give the rest mass for the entire system. "Matter" therefore is sometimes considered as anything contribute to the energy–momentum of a system, that is, anything ain't purely no gravity. This view is commonly held in fields deal with general relativity such as cosmology. In this view, light and other massless particles and fields part of matter.

qas.question: How many difficulties are there in defining mass?

paragraphs.context: A source of definition difficulty in relativity arise from two definitions of mass in common use, one of which is formally equivalent to total energy (and thus observer dependent), and the other of which is referred to as rest mass or invariant mass and independent of the observer. Only "rest mass" is loosely equated with matter (since it can be weighed). Invariant mass is usually applied in physics unbound systems of particles. However, energies which contribute to the "invariant mass" may be weighed also in special circumstances, such as when a system got invariant mass is confined and got no net momentum (as in the box example above). Thus, a photon with no mass may (confusingly) still add mass to a system in which it is trapped. The same true of the kinetic energy of particles, which by no definition ain't no part of their rest mass, but which add rest mass to systems in which these particles reside (an example the mass added by the motion of gas molecules of a bottle of gas, or by the thermal energy of any hot object).

paragraphs.context: Leptons (the most famous being the electron), and quarks (of which baryons, such as protons and neutrons, are made) combine to form atoms, which in turn form molecules. Because atoms and molecules are said to be matter, it natural to phrase the definition as: ordinary matter anything is made of the same things atoms and molecules are made of. (However, notice that one also can make from these building blocks matter ain't no atoms or molecules.) Then, because electrons leptons, and protons, and neutrons are made of quarks, this definition in turn lead to the definition of matter as being quarks and leptons, which the two types of elementary fermions. Carithers and Grannis state: Ordinary matter is composed entirely of first-generation particles, namely the [up] and [down] quarks, plus the electron and its neutrino. (Higher generations particles quickly decay into first-generation particles, and thus ain't commonly encountered.)

qas.question: What exists independently?
Who said matter had actuality in and of itself?
Aristotle said parts have existence outside of what?
What does grass turn the horse into?

paragraphs.context: For example, a horse eat grass: the horse change the grass into itself; the grass as such do not persist in no horse, but some aspect of it—its matter—do. The matter ain't specifically described (e.g., as no atoms), but consist of whatever persist in the change of substance from grass to horse. Matter in this understanding do not exist independently (i.e., as no substance), but exist interdependently (i.e., as a "principle") with form and only insofar as it underlie change. It can be helpful to conceive of the relationship of matter and form as very similar to that between parts and whole. For Aristotle, matter as such can only receive actuality from form; it got no activity or actuality in itself, similar to the way parts as such only got their existence in a whole (otherwise they would be independent wholes).

paragraphs.context: These quarks and leptons interact through four fundamental forces: gravity, electromagnetism, weak interactions, and strong interactions. The Standard Model of particle physics currently the best explanation for all of physics, but despite no decades of efforts, gravity cannot yet be accounted for at quantum no level; it is only described by classical physics (see quantum gravity and graviton). Interactions between quarks and leptons the result of an exchange of force-carrying particles (such as photons) between quarks and leptons. The force-carrying particles ain't themselves building blocks. As one no consequence, mass and energy (which cannot be created or destroyed) cannot always be related to no matter (which can be created out of non-matter particles such as photons, or even out of pure energy, such as kinetic energy). Force carriers are usually not considered matter: the carriers of the electric force (photons) possess energy (see Planck relation) and the carriers of the weak force (W and Z bosons) massive, but neither are considered matter either. However, while these particles ain't considered matter, they contribute to the total mass of atoms, subatomic particles, and all systems contain them.
